SED

# 

<span key="297819247991400dab6988c9448702e5"><span offset-key="297819247991400dab6988c9448702e5:0">Stream Editor - Overview</span></span>

<span key="0b9ff7092e05475eb1028459617b8afd"><span offset-key="0b9ff7092e05475eb1028459617b8afd:0">The acronym SED stands for </span>**Stream EDitor.**<span offset-key="0b9ff7092e05475eb1028459617b8afd:2"> It is a simple yet powerful utility that parses the text and transforms it seamlessly. SED was developed during 1973–74 by Lee E. McMahon of Bell Labs. Today, it runs on all major operating systems.</span></span>

<span key="91d18f9696094549bcf9b1da92349d1f"><span offset-key="91d18f9696094549bcf9b1da92349d1f:0">McMahon wrote a general-purpose line-oriented editor, which eventually became SED. SED borrowed syntax and many useful features from ed editor. Since its beginning, it has support for regular expressions. SED accepts inputs from files as well as pipes. Additionally, it can also accept inputs from standard input streams.</span></span>

<span key="c323ed005558472cac1256c7321c7fe6"><span offset-key="c323ed005558472cac1256c7321c7fe6:0">SED is written and maintained by the Free Software Foundation (FSF) and it is distributed by GNU/Linux. Hence it is often referred to as </span>**GNU SED.**<span offset-key="c323ed005558472cac1256c7321c7fe6:2"> To a novice user, the syntax of SED may look cryptic. However, once you get familiar with its syntax, you can solve many complex tasks with a few lines of SED script. This is the beauty of SED.</span></span>

## 

<span key="a70e0c9ec4764d9684929c89d9f35e83"><span offset-key="a70e0c9ec4764d9684929c89d9f35e83:0">Typical Uses of SED</span></span>

<span key="eb46d8bd32bb4216b3a2cd51ea787982"><span offset-key="eb46d8bd32bb4216b3a2cd51ea787982:0">SED can be used in many different ways, such as:</span></span>

-   <img src="data:image/svg+xml;base64," class="r-1nf4jbm" />

    <span key="84b2d0713db048858a234daa0054b5b1"><span offset-key="84b2d0713db048858a234daa0054b5b1:0">Text substitution,</span></span>

-   <img src="data:image/svg+xml;base64," class="r-1nf4jbm" />

    <span key="eb91f0f443ed474296a6ece4ad877c84"><span offset-key="eb91f0f443ed474296a6ece4ad877c84:0">Selective printing of text files,</span></span>

-   <img src="data:image/svg+xml;base64," class="r-1nf4jbm" />

    <span key="35e7e6f51658444ba49e31697550e48f"><span offset-key="35e7e6f51658444ba49e31697550e48f:0">In-a-place editing of text files,</span></span>

-   <img src="data:image/svg+xml;base64," class="r-1nf4jbm" />

    <span key="949e0e32a05346509cae7c515ac9ab5d"><span offset-key="949e0e32a05346509cae7c515ac9ab5d:0">Non-interactive editing of text files, and many more.</span></span>

# 

<span key="c1d84c8f41174267b8456325adc05f7b"><span offset-key="c1d84c8f41174267b8456325adc05f7b:0">Stream Editor - Environment</span></span>

<span key="3afdde352c1d48cd916bc8cd1aa1f954"><span offset-key="3afdde352c1d48cd916bc8cd1aa1f954:0">This chapter describes how to set up the SED environment on your GNU/Linux system.</span></span>

## 

<span key="f06d5523fd914ed2a2533aa6d581dcde"><span offset-key="f06d5523fd914ed2a2533aa6d581dcde:0">Installation Using Package Manager</span></span>

<span key="9b2ebfafc7644cf0b34a71211ee64407"><span offset-key="9b2ebfafc7644cf0b34a71211ee64407:0">Generally, SED is available by default on most GNU/Linux distributions. Use </span>**which**<span offset-key="9b2ebfafc7644cf0b34a71211ee64407:2"> command to identify whether it is present on your system or not. If not, then install SED on Debian based GNU/Linux using </span>**apt**<span offset-key="9b2ebfafc7644cf0b34a71211ee64407:4"> package manager as follows:</span></span>

1

<span key="17d7149a697443d49eb5954c59319332"><span offset-key="17d7149a697443d49eb5954c59319332:0">\[jerry\]$ sudo apt-get install sed</span></span>

<img src="data:image/svg+xml;base64," class="r-h7gdob r-10ptun7" />

Copied!

<span key="102f40f7b35846e0b6039c5372ae46d9"><span offset-key="102f40f7b35846e0b6039c5372ae46d9:0">After installation, ensure that SED is accessible via command line.</span></span>

1

<span key="c23f5add242c44e882f1b3ce38a6d69b"><span offset-key="c23f5add242c44e882f1b3ce38a6d69b:0">\[jerry\]$ sed --versio</span></span>

<img src="data:image/svg+xml;base64," class="r-h7gdob r-10ptun7 r-1vzi8xi" />

Copied!

<span key="dcdd0b2ab55140788c7dcbb40157facc"><span offset-key="dcdd0b2ab55140788c7dcbb40157facc:0">On executing the above code, you get the following result:</span></span>

1

<span key="23064c51bcf14e02895cabf61e048d83"><span offset-key="23064c51bcf14e02895cabf61e048d83:0">sed (GNU sed) 4.2.2</span></span>

2

<span key="a675d26cd0504be9bf7860f22f12cf0b"><span offset-key="a675d26cd0504be9bf7860f22f12cf0b:0">Copyright (C) 2012 Free Software Foundation, Inc.</span></span>

3

<span key="326a423ebb684fc1bd909e4768e38085"><span offset-key="326a423ebb684fc1bd909e4768e38085:0">License GPLv3+: GNU GPL version 3 or later .</span></span>

4

<span key="5b89590e0fd44433bc674de9b84864ac"><span offset-key="5b89590e0fd44433bc674de9b84864ac:0">This is free software: you are free to change and redistribute it.</span></span>

5

<span key="20844fa9ab3740219072dfce0f4af26b"><span offset-key="20844fa9ab3740219072dfce0f4af26b:0">There is NO WARRANTY, to the extent permitted by law.</span></span>

6

<span key="76776db460d0428e9f05f19da43315fd"><span offset-key="76776db460d0428e9f05f19da43315fd:0">Written by Jay Fenlason, Tom Lord, Ken Pizzini,</span></span>

7

<span key="158b4324e6014fcfb1d6a0a189fdaba1"><span offset-key="158b4324e6014fcfb1d6a0a189fdaba1:0">and Paolo Bonzini.</span></span>

8

<span key="6e18595ffd89421d9be7565caf879382"><span offset-key="6e18595ffd89421d9be7565caf879382:0">GNU sed home page: .</span></span>

9

<span key="631718169fb04f1ca95e6c761eaafcc6"><span offset-key="631718169fb04f1ca95e6c761eaafcc6:0">General help using GNU software: .</span></span>

10

<span key="72aa19a6c80d4ef7b47a46fd3f12ed89"><span offset-key="72aa19a6c80d4ef7b47a46fd3f12ed89:0">E-mail bug reports to: .</span></span>

11

<span key="397b3d71e7c240389ad4b085aba9459e"><span offset-key="397b3d71e7c240389ad4b085aba9459e:0">Be sure to include the word "sed" somewhere in the "Subject:" field.</span></span>

<img src="data:image/svg+xml;base64," class="r-h7gdob r-10ptun7 r-1vzi8xi" />

Copied!

<span key="016b1160f2564cde81cfff6c652c9b43"><span offset-key="016b1160f2564cde81cfff6c652c9b43:0">Similarly, to install SED on RPM based GNU/Linux, use yum package manager as follows:</span></span>

1

<span key="88e1826b51e5487ea3de1d4194c61fa0"><span offset-key="88e1826b51e5487ea3de1d4194c61fa0:0">\[root\]# yum -y install sed</span></span>

<img src="data:image/svg+xml;base64," class="r-h7gdob r-10ptun7 r-1vzi8xi" />

Copied!

<span key="0b16b01460c342f2b2135ad5e01bf9a0"><span offset-key="0b16b01460c342f2b2135ad5e01bf9a0:0">After installation, ensure that SED is accessible via command line.</span></span>

1

<span key="377ca47ae3a64fef89e867c860a5dff2"><span offset-key="377ca47ae3a64fef89e867c860a5dff2:0">\[root\]# sed --version</span></span>

<img src="data:image/svg+xml;base64," class="r-h7gdob r-10ptun7 r-1vzi8xi" />

Copied!

<span key="859e9af3aef34b6baedd31b883505a96"><span offset-key="859e9af3aef34b6baedd31b883505a96:0">On executing the above code, you get the following result:</span></span>

1

<span key="a7bf3bf34c8c4e69aa6eb05fad2795a6"><span offset-key="a7bf3bf34c8c4e69aa6eb05fad2795a6:0">GNU sed version 4.2.1</span></span>

2

<span key="3d3add203787440181be1d9360e7f514"><span offset-key="3d3add203787440181be1d9360e7f514:0">Copyright (C) 2009 Free Software Foundation, Inc.</span></span>

3

<span key="c3ca0cef153246ae85c1ccc056bdc313"><span offset-key="c3ca0cef153246ae85c1ccc056bdc313:0">This is free software; see the source for copying conditions. There is NO</span></span>

4

<span key="de04f54f49af42348a09cec4a1155f82"><span offset-key="de04f54f49af42348a09cec4a1155f82:0">warranty; not even for MERCHANTABILITY or FITNESS FOR A PARTICULAR PURPOSE,</span></span>

5

<span key="f68c1d9f604f4441b8633309c424541e"><span offset-key="f68c1d9f604f4441b8633309c424541e:0">to the extent permitted by law.</span></span>

6

<span key="8b4814346efe4268908547bfc41e740c"><span offset-key="8b4814346efe4268908547bfc41e740c:0">GNU sed home page: .</span></span>

7

<span key="b456a3cebf614b35925d518e47e74db2"><span offset-key="b456a3cebf614b35925d518e47e74db2:0">General help using GNU software: .</span></span>

8

<span key="4fe3d5a268344b8d898356aee786d934"><span offset-key="4fe3d5a268344b8d898356aee786d934:0">E-mail bug reports to: .</span></span>

9

<span key="833fe49693c24e319f643bd9025bf677"><span offset-key="833fe49693c24e319f643bd9025bf677:0">Be sure to include the word "sed" somewhere in the "Subject:" field.</span></span>

<img src="data:image/svg+xml;base64," class="r-h7gdob r-10ptun7 r-1vzi8xi" />

Copied!

## 

<span key="c80df90a466a4dbc8ecf772b551c40d7"><span offset-key="c80df90a466a4dbc8ecf772b551c40d7:0">Installation from Source Code</span></span>

<span key="63aca687cac64751999da3754b36d3fe"><span offset-key="63aca687cac64751999da3754b36d3fe:0">As GNU SED is a part of the GNU project, its source code is available for free download. We have already seen how to install SED using package manager. Let us now understand how to install SED from its source code.</span></span>

<span key="c50b750b82b64870bf776bb4a5a0e822"><span offset-key="c50b750b82b64870bf776bb4a5a0e822:0">The following installation is applicable to any GNU/Linux software, and for most other freely-available programs as well. Here are the installation steps:</span></span>

-   <img src="data:image/svg+xml;base64," class="r-1nf4jbm r-1vzi8xi" />

    <span key="4e687b2ad5b94b0f988a9a051ec0095e"><span offset-key="4e687b2ad5b94b0f988a9a051ec0095e:0">Download the source code from an authentic place. The command-line utility </span>**wget**<span offset-key="4e687b2ad5b94b0f988a9a051ec0095e:2"> serves this purpose.</span></span>

    1

    <span key="8b7c1b0e96bb4451b8fa9bb6523db9e4"><span offset-key="8b7c1b0e96bb4451b8fa9bb6523db9e4:0">\[jerry\]$ wget ftp://ftp.gnu.org/gnu/sed/sed-4.2.2.tar.bz2</span></span>

    <img src="data:image/svg+xml;base64," class="r-h7gdob r-10ptun7 r-1vzi8xi" />

    Copied!

-   <img src="data:image/svg+xml;base64," class="r-1nf4jbm r-1vzi8xi" />

    <span key="5d61ef5e91a143e898800afe1ca04549"><span offset-key="5d61ef5e91a143e898800afe1ca04549:0">Decompress and extract the downloaded source code.</span></span>

    1

    <span key="1ac54e2e12374ff9acc38acc837f783b"><span offset-key="1ac54e2e12374ff9acc38acc837f783b:0">\[jerry\]$ tar xvf sed-4.2.2.tar.bz2</span></span>

    <img src="data:image/svg+xml;base64," class="r-h7gdob r-10ptun7 r-1vzi8xi" />

    Copied!

-   <img src="data:image/svg+xml;base64," class="r-1nf4jbm r-1vzi8xi" />

    <span key="778ed6c1a16b47948453ee047236836d"><span offset-key="778ed6c1a16b47948453ee047236836d:0">Change into the directory and run configure.</span></span>

    1

    <span key="6bfb8a9b1ca64ec2bb4248f55298cf78"><span offset-key="6bfb8a9b1ca64ec2bb4248f55298cf78:0">\[jerry\]$ ./configure</span></span>

    <img src="data:image/svg+xml;base64," class="r-h7gdob r-10ptun7 r-1vzi8xi" />

    Copied!

-   <img src="data:image/svg+xml;base64," class="r-1nf4jbm r-1vzi8xi" />

    <span key="d11e9f8180c8493bb22fa184ef6bb104"><span offset-key="d11e9f8180c8493bb22fa184ef6bb104:0">Upon successful completion, the </span>**configure**<span offset-key="d11e9f8180c8493bb22fa184ef6bb104:2"> generates Makefile. To compile the source code, issue a </span>**make**<span offset-key="d11e9f8180c8493bb22fa184ef6bb104:4"> command.</span></span>

    1

    <span key="36a25b5ffce34cf2ad61dfc598873ed2"><span offset-key="36a25b5ffce34cf2ad61dfc598873ed2:0">\[jerry\]$ make</span></span>

    <img src="data:image/svg+xml;base64," class="r-h7gdob r-10ptun7 r-1vzi8xi" />

    Copied!

-   <img src="data:image/svg+xml;base64," class="r-1nf4jbm r-1vzi8xi" />

    <span key="256048d1a6e740c9a1cae1449e6320b5"><span offset-key="256048d1a6e740c9a1cae1449e6320b5:0">You can run the test suite to ensure the build is clean. This is an optional step.</span></span>

    1

    <span key="9005ceee4e5348f79a40ec3d680f0a0a"><span offset-key="9005ceee4e5348f79a40ec3d680f0a0a:0">\[jerry\]$ make check</span></span>

    <img src="data:image/svg+xml;base64," class="r-h7gdob r-10ptun7 r-1vzi8xi" />

    Copied!

-   <img src="data:image/svg+xml;base64," class="r-1nf4jbm r-1vzi8xi" />

    <span key="ae5b2216081549c6907f813390c44cfc"><span offset-key="ae5b2216081549c6907f813390c44cfc:0">Finally, install the SED utility. Make sure you have superuser privileges.</span></span>

    1

    <span key="58fcbd028e804a3dbb9a4b1776ecdce6"><span offset-key="58fcbd028e804a3dbb9a4b1776ecdce6:0">\[jerry\]$ sudo make install</span></span>

    <img src="data:image/svg+xml;base64," class="r-h7gdob r-10ptun7 r-1vzi8xi" />

    Copied!

<span key="d5a98b29d52c4f508b2bae9fca659eec"><span offset-key="d5a98b29d52c4f508b2bae9fca659eec:0">That is it! You have successfully compiled and installed SED. Verify it by executing the </span>**sed**<span offset-key="d5a98b29d52c4f508b2bae9fca659eec:2"> command as follows:</span></span>

1

<span key="d283d4ee5503421baa6bc17d514e8667"><span offset-key="d283d4ee5503421baa6bc17d514e8667:0">\[jerry\]$ sed --version</span></span>

<img src="data:image/svg+xml;base64," class="r-h7gdob r-10ptun7 r-1vzi8xi" />

Copied!

<span key="01caf49422f645a3ae31a27d11c5adb6"><span offset-key="01caf49422f645a3ae31a27d11c5adb6:0">On executing the above code, you get the following result:</span></span>

1

<span key="4d53f9f920d344a7b6796d211082fd87"><span offset-key="4d53f9f920d344a7b6796d211082fd87:0">sed (GNU sed) 4.2.2</span></span>

2

<span key="c276f4bbda53426caac8bb21b55bdd21"><span offset-key="c276f4bbda53426caac8bb21b55bdd21:0">Copyright (C) 2012 Free Software Foundation, Inc.</span></span>

# 

<span key="8ddce088fea143779bd18f73cd71ec04"><span offset-key="8ddce088fea143779bd18f73cd71ec04:0">Stream Editor - Workflow</span></span>

<span key="1d824aa3fd4448bf8df2c960ec03e95e"><span offset-key="1d824aa3fd4448bf8df2c960ec03e95e:0">In this chapter, we will explore how SED exactly works. To become an expert SED user, one needs to know its internals. SED follows a simple workflow: Read, Execute, and Display. The following diagram depicts the workflow.</span></span>

<span key="701bf82c4d4b4e24aed75f739938baeb"><span offset-key="701bf82c4d4b4e24aed75f739938baeb:0">Stream Editor Workflow</span></span>

-   <img src="data:image/svg+xml;base64," class="r-1nf4jbm r-1vzi8xi" />

    <span key="6a347f6cc7cf4fab859b02b02055a7d4">**Read**<span offset-key="6a347f6cc7cf4fab859b02b02055a7d4:1">: SED reads a line from the input stream (file, pipe, or stdin) and stores it in its internal buffer called </span>**pattern buffer**<span offset-key="6a347f6cc7cf4fab859b02b02055a7d4:3">.</span></span>

-   <img src="data:image/svg+xml;base64," class="r-1nf4jbm r-1vzi8xi" />

    <span key="c7558a1186d449b48895a44a5f8460bb">**Execute**<span offset-key="c7558a1186d449b48895a44a5f8460bb:1">: All SED commands are applied sequentially on the pattern buffer. By default, SED commands are applied on all lines (globally) unless line addressing is specified.</span></span>

-   <img src="data:image/svg+xml;base64," class="r-1nf4jbm r-1vzi8xi" />

    <span key="e4edccfb4f3f48c694a3c36c1596c2cd">**Display**<span offset-key="e4edccfb4f3f48c694a3c36c1596c2cd:1">: Send the (modified) contents to the output stream. After sending the data, the pattern buffer will be empty.</span></span>

-   <img src="data:image/svg+xml;base64," class="r-1nf4jbm r-1vzi8xi" />

    <span key="3af38e689c4f482fb2c06dee14a5d9f0"><span offset-key="3af38e689c4f482fb2c06dee14a5d9f0:0">The above process repeats until the file is exhausted.</span></span>

## 

<span key="09a774ab99c9432fbf196c1f1e79fb67"><span offset-key="09a774ab99c9432fbf196c1f1e79fb67:0">Points to Note</span></span>

-   <img src="data:image/svg+xml;base64," class="r-1nf4jbm r-1vzi8xi" />

    <span key="cc6aff2c1f1d47bd825edddd304bd52f"><span offset-key="cc6aff2c1f1d47bd825edddd304bd52f:0">Pattern buffer is a private, in-memory, volatile storage area used by the SED.</span></span>

-   <img src="data:image/svg+xml;base64," class="r-1nf4jbm r-1vzi8xi" />

    <span key="4af6396fb8624e72a0146de20357a223"><span offset-key="4af6396fb8624e72a0146de20357a223:0">By default, all SED commands are applied on the pattern buffer, hence the input file remains unchanged. GNU SED provides a way to modify the input file in-a-place. We will explore about it in later sections.</span></span>

-   <img src="data:image/svg+xml;base64," class="r-1nf4jbm r-1vzi8xi" />

    <span key="c8dbe5b2bbb94d8fb5572ec3027368a7"><span offset-key="c8dbe5b2bbb94d8fb5572ec3027368a7:0">There is another memory area called </span>**hold buffer**<span offset-key="c8dbe5b2bbb94d8fb5572ec3027368a7:2"> which is also private, in- memory, volatile storage area. Data can be stored in a hold buffer for later retrieval. At the end of each cycle, SED removes the contents of the pattern buffer but the contents of the hold buffer remains persistent between SED cycles. However SED commands cannot be directly executed on hold buffer, hence SED allows data movement between the hold buffer and the pattern buffer.</span></span>

-   <img src="data:image/svg+xml;base64," class="r-1nf4jbm r-1vzi8xi" />

    <span key="221b521b1c2a425fb4907193217d80e8"><span offset-key="221b521b1c2a425fb4907193217d80e8:0">Initially both pattern and hold buffers are empty.</span></span>

-   <img src="data:image/svg+xml;base64," class="r-1nf4jbm r-1vzi8xi" />

    <span key="42644d58db72410c9155dbe9493f7606"><span offset-key="42644d58db72410c9155dbe9493f7606:0">If no input files are provided, then SED accepts input from the standard input stream (stdin).</span></span>

-   <img src="data:image/svg+xml;base64," class="r-1nf4jbm r-1vzi8xi" />

    <span key="60f19748b87e480a9571792a0858fdef"><span offset-key="60f19748b87e480a9571792a0858fdef:0">If address range is not provided by default, then SED operates on each line.</span></span>

### 

<span key="1162c361b0f340dca476692137eb3f11"><span offset-key="1162c361b0f340dca476692137eb3f11:0">Examples</span></span>

<span key="dd37e343dca147af97826455c1135857"><span offset-key="dd37e343dca147af97826455c1135857:0">Let us create a text file </span>**quote.txt**<span offset-key="dd37e343dca147af97826455c1135857:2"> to contain a quote of the famous author Paulo Coelho.</span></span>

1

<span key="ed076e2d08b64d49b16a0272cb0aea3f"><span offset-key="ed076e2d08b64d49b16a0272cb0aea3f:0">\[jerry\]$ vi quote.txt</span></span>

2

<span key="1dd643536102432c91d30dedd24e9da2"><span offset-key="1dd643536102432c91d30dedd24e9da2:0">There is only one thing that makes a dream impossible to achieve: the fear of failure.</span></span>

3

<span key="03fdb831de85411dbed27de1cdab0e6b"><span offset-key="03fdb831de85411dbed27de1cdab0e6b:0"> - Paulo Coelho, The Alchemist</span></span>

<img src="data:image/svg+xml;base64," class="r-h7gdob r-10ptun7 r-1vzi8xi" />

Copied!

<span key="ff8cb40308b44ba3bd669c29c7ed8f5f"><span offset-key="ff8cb40308b44ba3bd669c29c7ed8f5f:0">To understand the workflow of SED, let us display the contents of the file quote.txt using SED. This example simulates the </span>**cat**<span offset-key="ff8cb40308b44ba3bd669c29c7ed8f5f:2"> command.</span></span>

1

<span key="e5955811315348cda3af24af1babffb8"><span offset-key="e5955811315348cda3af24af1babffb8:0">\[jerry\]$ sed '' quote.txt</span></span>

<img src="data:image/svg+xml;base64," class="r-h7gdob r-10ptun7 r-1vzi8xi" />

Copied!

<span key="8b0aea3cf26a4a619eeb8d7c70f80ae1"><span offset-key="8b0aea3cf26a4a619eeb8d7c70f80ae1:0">When the above code is executed, it will produce the following result.</span></span>

1

<span key="fe787f6e88394deba8d0caa1e93595fd"><span offset-key="fe787f6e88394deba8d0caa1e93595fd:0">There is only one thing that makes a dream impossible to achieve: the fear of failure.</span></span>

<img src="data:image/svg+xml;base64," class="r-h7gdob r-10ptun7 r-1vzi8xi" />

Copied!

<span key="6af1e817050c418db8e1eca8612bfa7b"><span offset-key="6af1e817050c418db8e1eca8612bfa7b:0">In the above example, quote.txt is the input file name and before that there is a pair of single quote that implies the SED command. Let us demystify this operation.</span></span>

<span key="900ffc5edb364700b33d7c2d0e6fa25d"><span offset-key="900ffc5edb364700b33d7c2d0e6fa25d:0">First SED reads a line from the input file quote.txt and stores it in its pattern buffer. Then it applies SED commands on the pattern buffer. In our case, no SED commands are there, hence no operation is performed on the pattern buffer. Finally it deletes and prints the contents of the pattern buffer on the standard output. Isn't it simple?</span></span>

<span key="3408b04474f8489dbdf114fd8b502c6f"><span offset-key="3408b04474f8489dbdf114fd8b502c6f:0">In the following example, SED accepts input from the standard input stream.</span></span>

1

<span key="4814e40a85a541a6ac192a460ab73658"><span offset-key="4814e40a85a541a6ac192a460ab73658:0">\[jerry\]$ sed ''</span></span>

<img src="data:image/svg+xml;base64," class="r-h7gdob r-10ptun7 r-1vzi8xi" />

Copied!

<span key="76001e50fef040959761ae8ad3c27678"><span offset-key="76001e50fef040959761ae8ad3c27678:0">When the above code is executed, it will produce the following result.</span></span>

1

<span key="101fe34035574cf391969fb6ac37a0a2"><span offset-key="101fe34035574cf391969fb6ac37a0a2:0">There is only one thing that makes a dream impossible to achieve: the fear of failure.</span></span>

2

<span key="4f59931b32114dd1a9a770df67a2fbbf"><span offset-key="4f59931b32114dd1a9a770df67a2fbbf:0">There is only one thing that makes a dream impossible to achieve: the fear of failure.</span></span>

<img src="data:image/svg+xml;base64," class="r-h7gdob r-10ptun7 r-1vzi8xi" />

Copied!

<span key="d0da63734d984d07af4cc6454b6901df"><span offset-key="d0da63734d984d07af4cc6454b6901df:0">Here, the first line is entered through keyboard and the second is the output generated by SED. To exit from the SED session, press ctrl-D (^D).</span></span>

# 

<span key="7bb99f6ce79842209fe9fc5b0387bda7"><span offset-key="7bb99f6ce79842209fe9fc5b0387bda7:0">Stream Editor - Basic Syntax</span></span>

<span key="1f45df56e2c4452999dee524d40829b5"><span offset-key="1f45df56e2c4452999dee524d40829b5:0">This chapter introduces the basic commands that SED supports and their command-line syntax. SED can be invoked in the following two forms:</span></span>

1

<span key="022ca64a50ee4d1981a66c5155cfd668"><span offset-key="022ca64a50ee4d1981a66c5155cfd668:0">sed \[-n\] \[-e\] 'command(s)' files</span></span>

2

<span key="d7caa3e59930418a80358d2963201237"><span offset-key="d7caa3e59930418a80358d2963201237:0">sed \[-n\] -f scriptfile files</span></span>

<img src="data:image/svg+xml;base64," class="r-h7gdob r-10ptun7 r-1vzi8xi" />

Copied!

<span key="cbf10c8d0b054a8c8abf3800f7ef9ae7"><span offset-key="cbf10c8d0b054a8c8abf3800f7ef9ae7:0">The first form allows to specify the commands in-line and they are enclosed within single quotes. The later allows to specify a script file that contains SED commands. However, we can use both forms together multiple times. SED provides various command-line options to control its behavior.</span></span>

<span key="5a1607666af84f87a9655d519c259de1"><span offset-key="5a1607666af84f87a9655d519c259de1:0">Let us see how we can specify multiple SED commands. SED provides the </span>**delete**<span offset-key="5a1607666af84f87a9655d519c259de1:2"> command to delete certain lines. Let us delete the 1st, 2nd, and 5th lines. For the time being, ignore all the details of the delete command. We will discuss more about the delete command later.</span></span>

<span key="4a8e159b826246fa8096873171aec262"><span offset-key="4a8e159b826246fa8096873171aec262:0">First, display the file contents using the </span>**cat**<span offset-key="4a8e159b826246fa8096873171aec262:2"> command.</span></span>

1

<span key="cb35a77174154ba78a91c18ddb6b8e91"><span offset-key="cb35a77174154ba78a91c18ddb6b8e91:0">\[jerry\]$ cat books.txt</span></span>

<img src="data:image/svg+xml;base64," class="r-h7gdob r-10ptun7 r-1vzi8xi" />

Copied!

<span key="9a39a709e0ff4d669c7134854201b641"><span offset-key="9a39a709e0ff4d669c7134854201b641:0">On executing the above code, you get the following result:</span></span>

1

<span key="33f4f7eb4ea345cebd8c5e304419034d"><span offset-key="33f4f7eb4ea345cebd8c5e304419034d:0">1) A Storm of Swords, George R. R. Martin, 1216</span></span>

2

<span key="cfff39c7f3744a3ea914b18bc2ebb63d"><span offset-key="cfff39c7f3744a3ea914b18bc2ebb63d:0">2) The Two Towers, J. R. R. Tolkien, 352</span></span>

3

<span key="124f4f16691542d384461bd6b3a27aa3"><span offset-key="124f4f16691542d384461bd6b3a27aa3:0">3) The Alchemist, Paulo Coelho, 197</span></span>

4

<span key="275a307c857041c19855f48c0d744060"><span offset-key="275a307c857041c19855f48c0d744060:0">4) The Fellowship of the Ring, J. R. R. Tolkien, 432</span></span>

5

<span key="572314b782b64e878dacf4e5f665b8f2"><span offset-key="572314b782b64e878dacf4e5f665b8f2:0">5) The Pilgrimage, Paulo Coelho, 288</span></span>

6

<span key="ce03255d564f4cd6a9ceecc2b02af7cd"><span offset-key="ce03255d564f4cd6a9ceecc2b02af7cd:0">6) A Game of Thrones, George R. R. Martin, 864</span></span>

<img src="data:image/svg+xml;base64," class="r-h7gdob r-10ptun7 r-1vzi8xi" />

Copied!

<span key="15506f88aced495bbb1a646766afd99f"><span offset-key="15506f88aced495bbb1a646766afd99f:0">Now instruct SED to remove only certain lines. Here, to delete three lines, we have specified three separate commands with -e option.</span></span>

1

<span key="0f3d2ca4db20428da559486799589d8e"><span offset-key="0f3d2ca4db20428da559486799589d8e:0">\[jerry\]$ sed -e '1d' -e '2d' -e '5d' books.txt</span></span>

<img src="data:image/svg+xml;base64," class="r-h7gdob r-10ptun7 r-1vzi8xi" />

Copied!

<span key="1e87979e2e2642a2bf41d20f902dbb74"><span offset-key="1e87979e2e2642a2bf41d20f902dbb74:0">On executing the above code, you get the following result:</span></span>

1

<span key="26238c0c1de74610b1aa58f7b10c4b2e"><span offset-key="26238c0c1de74610b1aa58f7b10c4b2e:0">3) The Alchemist, Paulo Coelho, 197</span></span>

2

<span key="47147e94f4074cd18b2ea14c353d81d8"><span offset-key="47147e94f4074cd18b2ea14c353d81d8:0">4) The Fellowship of the Ring, J. R. R. Tolkien, 432</span></span>

3

<span key="9ac99e460342439cb08f39e0064f1f4a"><span offset-key="9ac99e460342439cb08f39e0064f1f4a:0">6) A Game of Thrones, George R. R. Martin, 864</span></span>

<img src="data:image/svg+xml;base64," class="r-h7gdob r-10ptun7 r-1vzi8xi" />

Copied!

<span key="7216d3c58f47424daae959086d6c3b07"><span offset-key="7216d3c58f47424daae959086d6c3b07:0">Additionally, we can write multiple SED commands in a text file and provide the text file as an argument to SED. SED can apply each command on the pattern buffer. The following example illustrates the second form of SED.</span></span>

<span key="53560ff5e1044345af45aacb3042be4b"><span offset-key="53560ff5e1044345af45aacb3042be4b:0">First, create a text file containing SED commands. For easy understanding, let us use the same SED commands.</span></span>

1

<span key="ff774abd8d6d426f850a0f847d35fe9e"><span offset-key="ff774abd8d6d426f850a0f847d35fe9e:0">\[jerry\]$ echo -e "1d\\n2d\\n5d" &gt; commands.txt</span></span>

2

<span key="7441b0d57b3d43c6ae7895d9f65c784a"><span offset-key="7441b0d57b3d43c6ae7895d9f65c784a:0">\[jerry\]$ cat commands.txt</span></span>

<img src="data:image/svg+xml;base64," class="r-h7gdob r-10ptun7 r-1vzi8xi" />

Copied!

<span key="72a52a7bd4bd4545817482681157a024"><span offset-key="72a52a7bd4bd4545817482681157a024:0">On executing the above code, you get the following result:</span></span>

1

<span key="6ce0054ab45342f88a0394cab08a57dc"><span offset-key="6ce0054ab45342f88a0394cab08a57dc:0">1d</span></span>

2

<span key="64950f42565f4989913fdb85699d223f"><span offset-key="64950f42565f4989913fdb85699d223f:0">2d</span></span>

3

<span key="b34c5998a8154f7cbf32af0248e02972"><span offset-key="b34c5998a8154f7cbf32af0248e02972:0">5d</span></span>

<img src="data:image/svg+xml;base64," class="r-h7gdob r-10ptun7 r-1vzi8xi" />

Copied!

<span key="e5491fbc739546aeaa8c9c70ddbc7e9c"><span offset-key="e5491fbc739546aeaa8c9c70ddbc7e9c:0">Now instruct the SED to read commands from the text file. Here, we achieve the same result as shown in the above example.</span></span>

1

<span key="f6670148cd304a0a92f08c56bb5d20d7"><span offset-key="f6670148cd304a0a92f08c56bb5d20d7:0">\[jerry\]$ sed -f commands.txt books.txt</span></span>

<img src="data:image/svg+xml;base64," class="r-h7gdob r-10ptun7 r-1vzi8xi" />

Copied!

<span key="088667db83c7472388f4ab4d72b32574"><span offset-key="088667db83c7472388f4ab4d72b32574:0">On executing the above code, you get the following result:</span></span>

1

<span key="d83ffc9ec3814fe0967c019890ee6dfe"><span offset-key="d83ffc9ec3814fe0967c019890ee6dfe:0">3) The Alchemist, Paulo Coelho, 197</span></span>

2

<span key="6a311aaac7f844468a2405e6a0fcf72b"><span offset-key="6a311aaac7f844468a2405e6a0fcf72b:0">4) The Fellowship of the Ring, J. R. R. Tolkien, 432</span></span>

3

<span key="1f96db9766ec46d09c34af9025179ada"><span offset-key="1f96db9766ec46d09c34af9025179ada:0">6) A Game of Thrones,George R. R. Martin, 864</span></span>

<img src="data:image/svg+xml;base64," class="r-h7gdob r-10ptun7 r-1vzi8xi" />

Copied!

## 

<span key="8401134d0d504599bae9e2a40d6e5b3b"><span offset-key="8401134d0d504599bae9e2a40d6e5b3b:0">Standard Options</span></span>

<span key="3031e74aac254e538619ad459ce9a61f"><span offset-key="3031e74aac254e538619ad459ce9a61f:0">SED supports the following standard options:</span></span>

-   <img src="data:image/svg+xml;base64," class="r-1nf4jbm r-1vzi8xi" />

    <span key="3510a7f0629344c0875df6f17a00fa3f"><span offset-key="3510a7f0629344c0875df6f17a00fa3f:0">-n: Default printing of pattern buffer. For example, the following SED command does not show any output:</span></span>

    1

    <span key="b6fdb94e3b494346882287ffe8a09c03"><span offset-key="b6fdb94e3b494346882287ffe8a09c03:0">\[jerry\]$ sed -n '' quote.txt</span></span>

    <img src="data:image/svg+xml;base64," class="r-h7gdob r-10ptun7 r-1vzi8xi" />

    Copied!

-   <img src="data:image/svg+xml;base64," class="r-1nf4jbm r-1vzi8xi" />

    <span key="fcab27f23c484ba596e9f5ce15d42d60"><span offset-key="fcab27f23c484ba596e9f5ce15d42d60:0">-e : Next argument is an editing command. Here, angular brackets imply mandatory parameter. By using this option, we can specify multiple commands. Let us print each line twice:</span></span>

    1

    <span key="9d944069739f490cbff25a1c65de9bc2"><span offset-key="9d944069739f490cbff25a1c65de9bc2:0">\[jerry\]$ sed -e '' -e 'p' quote.txt</span></span>

    <img src="data:image/svg+xml;base64," class="r-h7gdob r-10ptun7 r-1vzi8xi" />

    Copied!

<span key="a33e1ec406934fb4ab306f4c20f735b0"><span offset-key="a33e1ec406934fb4ab306f4c20f735b0:0">On executing the above code, you get the following result:</span></span>

1

<span key="57aa66419fcb4a1eb112b651981d453a"><span offset-key="57aa66419fcb4a1eb112b651981d453a:0">There is only one thing that makes a dream impossible to achieve: the fear of failure.</span></span>

2

<span key="c466765209ee4e418e6e105de37dd735"><span offset-key="c466765209ee4e418e6e105de37dd735:0">There is only one thing that makes a dream impossible to achieve: the fear of failure.</span></span>

3

<span key="034e03b800b74c428c44a6f524413945"><span offset-key="034e03b800b74c428c44a6f524413945:0"> - Paulo Coelho, The Alchemist</span></span>

4

<span key="73beaa7090544678aa6e80f14789f45e"><span offset-key="73beaa7090544678aa6e80f14789f45e:0"> - Paulo Coelho, The Alchemist</span></span>

<img src="data:image/svg+xml;base64," class="r-h7gdob r-10ptun7 r-1vzi8xi" />

Copied!

-   <img src="data:image/svg+xml;base64," class="r-1nf4jbm r-1vzi8xi" />

    <span key="9bfef55ed65842cc98d085c25a8e37c4"><span offset-key="9bfef55ed65842cc98d085c25a8e37c4:0">-f : Next argument is a file containing editing commands. The angular brackets imply mandatory parameter. In the following example, we specify print command through file:</span></span>

1

<span key="72c2c41c5bff470fa65de5ea6182f503"><span offset-key="72c2c41c5bff470fa65de5ea6182f503:0">\[jerry\]$ echo "p" &gt; commands</span></span>

2

<span key="f5b3a0e48a4948daacb1928649409076"><span offset-key="f5b3a0e48a4948daacb1928649409076:0">\[jerry\]$ sed -n -f commands quote.txt</span></span>

<img src="data:image/svg+xml;base64," class="r-h7gdob r-10ptun7 r-1vzi8xi" />

Copied!

<span key="be8d113ace024319afa2d29323cf9ab8"><span offset-key="be8d113ace024319afa2d29323cf9ab8:0">On executing the above code, you get the following result:</span></span>

1

<span key="5a0f23e61653410d9c9fdc81c7aa3b8e"><span offset-key="5a0f23e61653410d9c9fdc81c7aa3b8e:0">There is only one thing that makes a dream impossible to achieve: the fear of failure.</span></span>

2

<span key="4b5c9a40c3fe4ca3a0caa5133a371b51"><span offset-key="4b5c9a40c3fe4ca3a0caa5133a371b51:0"> - Paulo Coelho, The Alchemist</span></span>

<img src="data:image/svg+xml;base64," class="r-h7gdob r-10ptun7 r-1vzi8xi" />

Copied!

## 

<span key="ff27a9007052443897f50e4efa63f135"><span offset-key="ff27a9007052443897f50e4efa63f135:0">GNU Specific Options</span></span>

<span key="9caf9d1fa6224c8e9f04926e97180fc5"><span offset-key="9caf9d1fa6224c8e9f04926e97180fc5:0">Let us quickly go through the GNU specific SED options. Note that these options are GNU specific; and may not be supported by other variants of the SED. In later sections, we will discuss these options in more details.</span></span>

-   <img src="data:image/svg+xml;base64," class="r-1nf4jbm r-1vzi8xi" />

    <span key="a879db7cf4c24a729d81fc395c11de9f"><span offset-key="a879db7cf4c24a729d81fc395c11de9f:0">-n, --quiet, --silent: Same as standard -n option.</span></span>

-   <img src="data:image/svg+xml;base64," class="r-1nf4jbm r-1vzi8xi" />

    <span key="bc2fd95bc967445bb11cc9f74eb2f337"><span offset-key="bc2fd95bc967445bb11cc9f74eb2f337:0">-e script, --expression=script: Same as standard -e option.</span></span>

-   <img src="data:image/svg+xml;base64," class="r-1nf4jbm r-1vzi8xi" />

    <span key="7f43c6a99b8c4de49e34fd684350c9e1"><span offset-key="7f43c6a99b8c4de49e34fd684350c9e1:0">-f script-file, --file=script-file: Same as standard -f option.</span></span>

-   <img src="data:image/svg+xml;base64," class="r-1nf4jbm r-1vzi8xi" />

    <span key="608a4283c53f4f1796aaa68159136b82"><span offset-key="608a4283c53f4f1796aaa68159136b82:0">--follow-symlinks: If this option is provided, the SED follows symbolic links while editing files in place.</span></span>

-   <img src="data:image/svg+xml;base64," class="r-1nf4jbm r-1vzi8xi" />

    <span key="8e263854be7e4e42a693b09c1ff3ee8e"><span offset-key="8e263854be7e4e42a693b09c1ff3ee8e:0">-i\[SUFFIX\], --in-place\[=SUFFIX\]: This option is used to edit file in place. If suffix is provided, it takes a backup of the original file, otherwise it overwrites the original file.</span></span>

-   <img src="data:image/svg+xml;base64," class="r-1nf4jbm r-1vzi8xi" />

    <span key="a50a9ae059944028a29eb46c3482b3df"><span offset-key="a50a9ae059944028a29eb46c3482b3df:0">-l N, --line-lenght=N: This option sets the line length for l command to N characters.</span></span>

-   <img src="data:image/svg+xml;base64," class="r-1nf4jbm r-1vzi8xi" />

    <span key="71e69efe6cc74747a5d074af08aad966"><span offset-key="71e69efe6cc74747a5d074af08aad966:0">--posix: This option disables all GNU extensions.</span></span>

-   <img src="data:image/svg+xml;base64," class="r-1nf4jbm r-1vzi8xi" />

    <span key="9d164da52fac4189baec5384b55ff74c"><span offset-key="9d164da52fac4189baec5384b55ff74c:0">-r, --regexp-extended: This option allows to use extended regular expressions rather than basic regular expressions.</span></span>

-   <img src="data:image/svg+xml;base64," class="r-1nf4jbm r-1vzi8xi" />

    <span key="a1ae06d28d9246ac9dc00c25cf2bf394"><span offset-key="a1ae06d28d9246ac9dc00c25cf2bf394:0">-u, --unbuffered: When this option is provided, the SED loads minimal amount of data from the input files and flushes the output buffers more often. It is useful for editing the output of "tail -f" when you do not want to wait for the output.</span></span>

-   <img src="data:image/svg+xml;base64," class="r-1nf4jbm r-1vzi8xi" />

    <span key="5db0a8ff03164164b7757e351d12e4aa"><span offset-key="5db0a8ff03164164b7757e351d12e4aa:0">-z, --null-data: By default, the SED separates each line by a new-line character. If NULL-data option is provided, it separates the lines by NULL characters.</span></span>

# 

<span key="9463319a88d4449ab5f427f1cb8e6a60"><span offset-key="9463319a88d4449ab5f427f1cb8e6a60:0">Stream Editor - Loops</span></span>

<span key="4ac38d3454c54a9db86183241181a4c8"><span offset-key="4ac38d3454c54a9db86183241181a4c8:0">Like other programming languages, SED too provides a looping and branching facility to control the flow of execution. In this chapter, we are going to explore more about how to use loops and branches in SED.</span></span>

<span key="ea7e684e9cad4ce7bf55af7943a29025"><span offset-key="ea7e684e9cad4ce7bf55af7943a29025:0">A loop in SED works similar to a </span>**goto**<span offset-key="ea7e684e9cad4ce7bf55af7943a29025:2"> statement. SED can jump to the line marked by the label and continue executing the remaining commands. In SED, we can define a </span>**label**<span offset-key="ea7e684e9cad4ce7bf55af7943a29025:4"> as follows:</span></span>

1

<span key="001d1b4be45f47779506c9398b685eb3"><span offset-key="001d1b4be45f47779506c9398b685eb3:0">:label</span></span>

2

<span key="d2069d0cc0954beb9aeb59430e56e9e3"><span offset-key="d2069d0cc0954beb9aeb59430e56e9e3:0">:start</span></span>

3

<span key="b6c1f7b898d0415bab1e0678a9d95a7c"><span offset-key="b6c1f7b898d0415bab1e0678a9d95a7c:0">:end</span></span>

4

<span key="871b268691ff48ff916906ed4a683654"><span offset-key="871b268691ff48ff916906ed4a683654:0">:up</span></span>

<img src="data:image/svg+xml;base64," class="r-h7gdob r-10ptun7 r-1vzi8xi" />

Copied!

<span key="f002be0883254e0d93f7673cd652f102"><span offset-key="f002be0883254e0d93f7673cd652f102:0">In the above example, a name after colon(:) implies the label name.</span></span>

<span key="2d71c01f02494abcb947872e1f6bf058"><span offset-key="2d71c01f02494abcb947872e1f6bf058:0">To jump to a specific label, we can use the </span>**b**<span offset-key="2d71c01f02494abcb947872e1f6bf058:2"> command followed by the label name. If the label name is omitted, then the SED jumps to the end of the SED file.</span></span>

<span key="8b22c08e18304b3699881f19baa257ab"><span offset-key="8b22c08e18304b3699881f19baa257ab:0">Let us write a simple SED script to understand the loops and branches. In our books.txt file, there are several entries of book titles and their authors. The following example combines a book title and its author name in one line separated by a comma. Then it searches for the pattern "Paulo". If the pattern matches, it prints a hyphen(-) in front of the line, otherwise it jumps to the </span>**Print**<span offset-key="8b22c08e18304b3699881f19baa257ab:2"> label which prints the line.</span></span>

1

<span key="9e4230f4bbcc42b5b3fec0dfe7bf0090"><span offset-key="9e4230f4bbcc42b5b3fec0dfe7bf0090:0">\[jerry\]$ sed -n '</span></span>

2

<span key="cec1dcb9bd874efa9c02ccf8aff7a66c"><span offset-key="cec1dcb9bd874efa9c02ccf8aff7a66c:0">h;n;H;x</span></span>

3

<span key="06e8d128a24c43e199502a67a7187e4a"><span offset-key="06e8d128a24c43e199502a67a7187e4a:0">s/\\n/, /</span></span>

4

<span key="0de89ddda4be4183a51bddcebb73392d"><span offset-key="0de89ddda4be4183a51bddcebb73392d:0">/Paulo/!b Print</span></span>

5

<span key="34e37a859f4940ceb82c8aaca301ffac"><span offset-key="34e37a859f4940ceb82c8aaca301ffac:0">s/^/- /</span></span>

6

<span key="66c695cba1af4ea99f2a122c51e9ba89"><span offset-key="66c695cba1af4ea99f2a122c51e9ba89:0">:Print</span></span>

7

<span key="0a5826bc9b704caa96ed1c3087a0137d"><span offset-key="0a5826bc9b704caa96ed1c3087a0137d:0">p' books.txt</span></span>

<img src="data:image/svg+xml;base64," class="r-h7gdob r-10ptun7 r-1vzi8xi" />

Copied!

<span key="91ffad8d40de4ee2b5a0718f450adb18"><span offset-key="91ffad8d40de4ee2b5a0718f450adb18:0">On executing the above code, you get the following result:</span></span>

1

<span key="f4bb5f5469fd4ba2b0df5d7dbfc61d3a"><span offset-key="f4bb5f5469fd4ba2b0df5d7dbfc61d3a:0">A Storm of Swords, George R. R. Martin</span></span>

2

<span key="20795a5ac9094bd083bade64896b44cc"><span offset-key="20795a5ac9094bd083bade64896b44cc:0">The Two Towers, J. R. R. Tolkien</span></span>

3

<span key="bc3634f8f66a43adace2a48d63c2eee7"><span offset-key="bc3634f8f66a43adace2a48d63c2eee7:0">- The Alchemist, Paulo Coelho</span></span>

4

<span key="531a0f0eb46d4c49b3177c15e3b58be3"><span offset-key="531a0f0eb46d4c49b3177c15e3b58be3:0">The Fellowship of the Ring, J. R. R. Tolkien</span></span>

5

<span key="1609b590123a4d2eb4a294966917a9b2"><span offset-key="1609b590123a4d2eb4a294966917a9b2:0">- The Pilgrimage, Paulo Coelho</span></span>

<img src="data:image/svg+xml;base64," class="r-h7gdob r-10ptun7 r-1vzi8xi" />

Copied!

1

<span key="6af09c8169e943c7b8520de8f89529ad"><span offset-key="6af09c8169e943c7b8520de8f89529ad:0">A Game of Thrones, George R. R. Martin</span></span>

<img src="data:image/svg+xml;base64," class="r-h7gdob r-10ptun7 r-1vzi8xi" />

Copied!

<span key="7cba4ffac9244318bc6eb953c8422cc1"><span offset-key="7cba4ffac9244318bc6eb953c8422cc1:0">At first glance, the above script may look cryptic. Let us demystify this.</span></span>

-   <img src="data:image/svg+xml;base64," class="r-1nf4jbm r-1vzi8xi" />

    <span key="c7c13dafb4b84d26b68ef74a3b3c4c76"><span offset-key="c7c13dafb4b84d26b68ef74a3b3c4c76:0">The first two commands are self-explanatory </span>**h;n;H;x**<span offset-key="c7c13dafb4b84d26b68ef74a3b3c4c76:2"> and </span>**s/\\n/, /**<span offset-key="c7c13dafb4b84d26b68ef74a3b3c4c76:4"> combine the book title and its author separated by a comma(,).</span></span>

-   <img src="data:image/svg+xml;base64," class="r-1nf4jbm r-1vzi8xi" />

    <span key="96ce6d2d6a494b49a06096d18b9222da"><span offset-key="96ce6d2d6a494b49a06096d18b9222da:0">The third command jumps to the label </span>**Print**<span offset-key="96ce6d2d6a494b49a06096d18b9222da:2"> only when the pattern does not match, otherwise substitution is performed by the fourth command.</span></span>

-   <img src="data:image/svg+xml;base64," class="r-1nf4jbm r-1vzi8xi" />

    <span key="dc28172d8fcb4dc8a54ecb6703dc233e">**:Print**<span offset-key="dc28172d8fcb4dc8a54ecb6703dc233e:1"> is just a label name and as you already know, </span>**p**<span offset-key="dc28172d8fcb4dc8a54ecb6703dc233e:3"> is the print command.</span></span>

<span key="67dbc16fe428441a9a301bbda339671a"><span offset-key="67dbc16fe428441a9a301bbda339671a:0">To improve readability, each SED command is placed on a separate line. However, one can choose to place all the commands in one line as follows:</span></span>

1

<span key="8b6659721acf4ce2874167ff92c29588"><span offset-key="8b6659721acf4ce2874167ff92c29588:0">\[jerry\]$ sed -n 'h;n;H;x;s/\\n/, /;/Paulo/!b Print; s/^/- /; :Print;p' books.txt</span></span>

<img src="data:image/svg+xml;base64," class="r-h7gdob r-10ptun7 r-1vzi8xi" />

Copied!

<span key="dd5f041757ff42fe93041182d765303a"><span offset-key="dd5f041757ff42fe93041182d765303a:0">On executing the above code, you get the following result:</span></span>

1

<span key="97bb31bd770c416b8bce27c5e322ed9f"><span offset-key="97bb31bd770c416b8bce27c5e322ed9f:0">A Storm of Swords, George R. R. Martin</span></span>

2

<span key="2d1e9406df354b1bbd1ea02708c3b024"><span offset-key="2d1e9406df354b1bbd1ea02708c3b024:0">The Two Towers, J. R. R. Tolkien</span></span>

3

<span key="f0dead15db9340f3a54fd60c5a934837"><span offset-key="f0dead15db9340f3a54fd60c5a934837:0">- The Alchemist, Paulo Coelho</span></span>

4

<span key="014d8d98e2a244c887d6abbecd6c5216"><span offset-key="014d8d98e2a244c887d6abbecd6c5216:0">The Fellowship of the Ring, J. R. R. Tolkien</span></span>

5

<span key="c181c92e564e4d0db23767905d93c227"><span offset-key="c181c92e564e4d0db23767905d93c227:0">- The Pilgrimage, Paulo Coelho</span></span>

6

<span key="401327948e6f491bbb3e993b6f6b264b"><span offset-key="401327948e6f491bbb3e993b6f6b264b:0">A Game of Thrones, George R. R. Martin</span></span>

<img src="data:image/svg+xml;base64," class="r-h7gdob r-10ptun7 r-1vzi8xi" />

Copied!

# 

<span key="1ba0ca43b29e4f90866cd114e9b1b39d"><span offset-key="1ba0ca43b29e4f90866cd114e9b1b39d:0">Stream Editor - Branches</span></span>

<span key="fd4550be7daa4f4e90478c58dfc3464c"><span offset-key="fd4550be7daa4f4e90478c58dfc3464c:0">Branches can be created using the t command. The </span>**t**<span offset-key="fd4550be7daa4f4e90478c58dfc3464c:2"> command jumps to the label only if the previous substitute command was successful. Let us take the same example as in the previous chapter, but instead of printing a single hyphen(-), now we print four hyphens. The following example illustrates the usage of the </span>**t**<span offset-key="fd4550be7daa4f4e90478c58dfc3464c:4"> command.</span></span>

1

<span key="8c456483fa39452ba241cc615f0b4a0c"><span offset-key="8c456483fa39452ba241cc615f0b4a0c:0">\[jerry\]$ sed -n '</span></span>

2

<span key="a2657bf12b19431695b11d0a58aca67f"><span offset-key="a2657bf12b19431695b11d0a58aca67f:0">h;n;H;x</span></span>

3

<span key="2ecd99d435fa4fe0a111b7f68f663e38"><span offset-key="2ecd99d435fa4fe0a111b7f68f663e38:0">s/\\n/, /</span></span>

4

<span key="7d0f5425dbc94f9f83b0a87a8457eaac"><span offset-key="7d0f5425dbc94f9f83b0a87a8457eaac:0">:Loop</span></span>

5

<span key="6a1dc4c9e8c14941afcb8294a61b3ee8"><span offset-key="6a1dc4c9e8c14941afcb8294a61b3ee8:0">/Paulo/s/^/-/</span></span>

6

<span key="b0e821aa01f542bd9407688a9660d1ae"><span offset-key="b0e821aa01f542bd9407688a9660d1ae:0">/----/!t Loop</span></span>

7

<span key="6f12f7f6b9754501a363c0e2f144506d"><span offset-key="6f12f7f6b9754501a363c0e2f144506d:0">p' books.txt</span></span>

<img src="data:image/svg+xml;base64," class="r-h7gdob r-10ptun7 r-1vzi8xi" />

Copied!

<span key="b870c44b5da5490dbe807c18f13261e7"><span offset-key="b870c44b5da5490dbe807c18f13261e7:0">When the above code is executed, it will produce the following result.</span></span>

1

<span key="4393264fef9540ec8ecd17af83926cd9"><span offset-key="4393264fef9540ec8ecd17af83926cd9:0">A Storm of Swords, George R. R. Martin</span></span>

2

<span key="6431eab6c4d74d4e8c23d2c9bf531a40"><span offset-key="6431eab6c4d74d4e8c23d2c9bf531a40:0">The Two Towers, J. R. R. Tolkien</span></span>

3

<span key="087f78035b5c4d7d92644dc0df816900"><span offset-key="087f78035b5c4d7d92644dc0df816900:0">----The Alchemist, Paulo Coelho</span></span>

4

<span key="228b75ab1d2940eab8343c764bba92f6"><span offset-key="228b75ab1d2940eab8343c764bba92f6:0">The Fellowship of the Ring, J. R. R. Tolkien</span></span>

5

<span key="f5299dbad5f1446ca9ae67e5e74d93af"><span offset-key="f5299dbad5f1446ca9ae67e5e74d93af:0">----The Pilgrimage, Paulo Coelho</span></span>

6

<span key="f087cea36fde40d6b89f1a4d4bfe29cb"><span offset-key="f087cea36fde40d6b89f1a4d4bfe29cb:0">A Game of Thrones, George R. R. Martin</span></span>

<img src="data:image/svg+xml;base64," class="r-h7gdob r-10ptun7 r-1vzi8xi" />

Copied!

<span key="2338671f652249399b35c2590ab6f368"><span offset-key="2338671f652249399b35c2590ab6f368:0">In the above example, the first two commands are self-explanatory. The third command defines a label </span>**Loop**<span offset-key="2338671f652249399b35c2590ab6f368:2">. The fourth command prepends hyphen(-) if the line contains the string "Paulo" and the </span>**t**<span offset-key="2338671f652249399b35c2590ab6f368:4"> command repeats the procedure until there are four hyphens at the beginning of the line.</span></span>

<span key="4eb6485a4b27458aabce1706c465b44a"><span offset-key="4eb6485a4b27458aabce1706c465b44a:0">To improve readability, each SED command is written on a separate line. Otherwise, we can write a one-liner SED as follows:</span></span>

1

<span key="dca8a56c6b0d49d2871c60e49b01c57e"><span offset-key="dca8a56c6b0d49d2871c60e49b01c57e:0">\[jerry\]$ sed -n 'h;n;H;x; s/\\n/, /; :Loop;/Paulo/s/^/-/; /----/!t Loop; p' books.txt</span></span>

<img src="data:image/svg+xml;base64," class="r-h7gdob r-10ptun7 r-1vzi8xi" />

Copied!

<span key="507a0844eb034fbe8d6def17a6ef6001"><span offset-key="507a0844eb034fbe8d6def17a6ef6001:0">When the above code is executed, it will produce the following result.</span></span>

1

<span key="7d383a7839b1480c8167c1bb26b20df8"><span offset-key="7d383a7839b1480c8167c1bb26b20df8:0">A Storm of Swords, George R. R. Martin</span></span>

2

<span key="d84b85b3ce3f454d8200768544b44b3f"><span offset-key="d84b85b3ce3f454d8200768544b44b3f:0">The Two Towers, J. R. R. Tolkien</span></span>

3

<span key="2e7a4cec338242a3878257723742c338"><span offset-key="2e7a4cec338242a3878257723742c338:0">----The Alchemist, Paulo Coelho</span></span>

4

<span key="383d2b1630944cbbb711fd52a8597bd4"><span offset-key="383d2b1630944cbbb711fd52a8597bd4:0">The Fellowship of the Ring, J. R. R. Tolkien</span></span>

5

<span key="d1fcb5f468f1417a9733003568e65b30"><span offset-key="d1fcb5f468f1417a9733003568e65b30:0">----The Pilgrimage, Paulo Coelho</span></span>

6

<span key="52742cca8b24447392d6d6e8c2246362"><span offset-key="52742cca8b24447392d6d6e8c2246362:0">A Game of Thrones, George R. R. Martin</span></span>

# 

<span key="5b50911e6ea549d598cab83eb63c4ae1"><span offset-key="5b50911e6ea549d598cab83eb63c4ae1:0">Stream Editor - Pattern Buffer</span></span>

<span key="c35eb8369f2d4e9b8a5b71801d615b46"><span offset-key="c35eb8369f2d4e9b8a5b71801d615b46:0">One of the basic operations we perform on any file is display its contents. For this purpose, we can use the </span>**print**<span offset-key="c35eb8369f2d4e9b8a5b71801d615b46:2"> command which prints the contents of the pattern buffer. So let us learn more about the pattern buffer</span></span>

<span key="b68bce5b183f4b4bbd2f4276c5186f99"><span offset-key="b68bce5b183f4b4bbd2f4276c5186f99:0">First create a file containing the line number, the name of the book, its author, and the number of pages. In this tutorial, we will be using this file. You can use any text file according to your convenience. Our text file will look like this:</span></span>

1

<span key="7b4eaa07467c43409b85659259d8d201"><span offset-key="7b4eaa07467c43409b85659259d8d201:0">\[jerry\]$ vi books.txt</span></span>

2

<span key="8808399f5ebf40a9a12c7753eb21e6e7"><span offset-key="8808399f5ebf40a9a12c7753eb21e6e7:0">1) A Storm of Swords, George R. R. Martin, 1216</span></span>

3

<span key="bfcb40729591429b8274848114e8bc92"><span offset-key="bfcb40729591429b8274848114e8bc92:0">2) The Two Towers, J. R. R. Tolkien, 352</span></span>

4

<span key="ffe207f587d14ce48be9256544a61636"><span offset-key="ffe207f587d14ce48be9256544a61636:0">3) The Alchemist, Paulo Coelho, 197</span></span>

5

<span key="e12dc49605d64045b4f96d6e377d4015"><span offset-key="e12dc49605d64045b4f96d6e377d4015:0">4) The Fellowship of the Ring, J. R. R. Tolkien, 432</span></span>

6

<span key="1e50d3709f3c410bb29ea7d7767b0435"><span offset-key="1e50d3709f3c410bb29ea7d7767b0435:0">5) The Pilgrimage, Paulo Coelho,288</span></span>

7

<span key="e5681e9d27c84e5b8a69bda342b19a8d"><span offset-key="e5681e9d27c84e5b8a69bda342b19a8d:0">6) A Game of Thrones, George R. R. Martin, 864</span></span>

<img src="data:image/svg+xml;base64," class="r-h7gdob r-10ptun7 r-1vzi8xi" />

Copied!

<span key="c2b211fafa4946dc9dd7f61a19a335b8"><span offset-key="c2b211fafa4946dc9dd7f61a19a335b8:0">Now, let us print the file contents.</span></span>

1

<span key="f7ebf1cdf4d0404e858e82e58d75a3af"><span offset-key="f7ebf1cdf4d0404e858e82e58d75a3af:0">\[jerry\]$ sed 'p' books.txt</span></span>

<img src="data:image/svg+xml;base64," class="r-h7gdob r-10ptun7 r-1vzi8xi" />

Copied!

<span key="3a1a3c48e0b94b4b8454a3cb3a43ffdd"><span offset-key="3a1a3c48e0b94b4b8454a3cb3a43ffdd:0">When the above code is executed, it will produce the following result.</span></span>

1

<span key="41709bcbc3464aa6902efe58f5d9d829"><span offset-key="41709bcbc3464aa6902efe58f5d9d829:0">1) A Storm of Swords, George R. R. Martin, 1216</span></span>

2

<span key="07c2dc6ca15b479492e9f9007eab53c6"><span offset-key="07c2dc6ca15b479492e9f9007eab53c6:0">1) A Storm of Swords, George R. R. Martin, 1216</span></span>

3

<span key="493de8faa8504ae6b136a1f0af1408d2"><span offset-key="493de8faa8504ae6b136a1f0af1408d2:0">2) The Two Towers, J. R. R. Tolkien, 352</span></span>

4

<span key="40edc0d2affb4f7fad5c2778f9f258d5"><span offset-key="40edc0d2affb4f7fad5c2778f9f258d5:0">2) The Two Towers, J. R. R. Tolkien, 352</span></span>

5

<span key="dd35d56529df4250b4869024062687aa"><span offset-key="dd35d56529df4250b4869024062687aa:0">3) The Alchemist, Paulo Coelho, 197</span></span>

6

<span key="d2d417b66bd8435fbb5cd1fd864f6781"><span offset-key="d2d417b66bd8435fbb5cd1fd864f6781:0">3) The Alchemist, Paulo Coelho, 197</span></span>

7

<span key="2d16f161267f489991cb4ee860efe20c"><span offset-key="2d16f161267f489991cb4ee860efe20c:0">4) The Fellowship of the Ring, J. R. R. Tolkien, 432</span></span>

8

<span key="9d815dfe656f46b397900f9962d310c3"><span offset-key="9d815dfe656f46b397900f9962d310c3:0">4) The Fellowship of the Ring, J. R. R. Tolkien, 432</span></span>

9

<span key="993ad50c887f422a9b3c1ad51c2e88d3"><span offset-key="993ad50c887f422a9b3c1ad51c2e88d3:0">5) The Pilgrimage, Paulo Coelho, 288</span></span>

10

<span key="bda79f7f46804d3395d84aa3510727ef"><span offset-key="bda79f7f46804d3395d84aa3510727ef:0">5) The Pilgrimage, Paulo Coelho, 288</span></span>

11

<span key="fd177198b94e483a96edebce6fecf753"><span offset-key="fd177198b94e483a96edebce6fecf753:0">6) A Game of Thrones, George R. R. Martin, 864</span></span>

12

<span key="5b5828bd89a14f4e974344e914f1e1ec"><span offset-key="5b5828bd89a14f4e974344e914f1e1ec:0">6) A Game of Thrones, George R. R. Martin, 864</span></span>

<img src="data:image/svg+xml;base64," class="r-h7gdob r-10ptun7 r-1vzi8xi" />

Copied!

<span key="c1980a70538c4524857193f3e730ecc9"><span offset-key="c1980a70538c4524857193f3e730ecc9:0">You might wonder why each line is being displayed twice. Let us find out.</span></span>

<span key="7b3f70b03c2d431b9eeba6bebf836e73"><span offset-key="7b3f70b03c2d431b9eeba6bebf836e73:0">Do you remember the workflow of SED? By default, SED prints the contents of the pattern buffer. In addition, we have included a print command explicitly in our command section. Hence each line is printed twice. But don't worry. SED has the </span>**-n**<span offset-key="7b3f70b03c2d431b9eeba6bebf836e73:2"> option to suppress the default printing of the pattern buffer. The following command illustrates that.</span></span>

1

<span key="60c30fcc59e24e4bac871b9d66600ca6"><span offset-key="60c30fcc59e24e4bac871b9d66600ca6:0">\[jerry\]$ sed -n 'p' books.txt</span></span>

<img src="data:image/svg+xml;base64," class="r-h7gdob r-10ptun7 r-1vzi8xi" />

Copied!

<span key="c1aadb59cae2406faf8ce7336da9b798"><span offset-key="c1aadb59cae2406faf8ce7336da9b798:0">When the above code is executed, it will produce the following result.</span></span>

1

<span key="134f3cbfbdea4fc38ca9f92a1347f9fc"><span offset-key="134f3cbfbdea4fc38ca9f92a1347f9fc:0">1) A Storm of Swords, George R. R. Martin, 1216</span></span>

2

<span key="1793cb5b77024a7b938ef6d22712cb88"><span offset-key="1793cb5b77024a7b938ef6d22712cb88:0">2) The Two Towers, J. R. R. Tolkien, 352</span></span>

3

<span key="42fac0cd04054489888ddc6f0707b64e"><span offset-key="42fac0cd04054489888ddc6f0707b64e:0">3) The Alchemist, Paulo Coelho, 197</span></span>

4

<span key="5dce4012674748c585e8fc8f8d2c3061"><span offset-key="5dce4012674748c585e8fc8f8d2c3061:0">4) The Fellowship of the Ring, J. R. R. Tolkien, 432</span></span>

5

<span key="622ee2e4271848fa951994fa86afcf30"><span offset-key="622ee2e4271848fa951994fa86afcf30:0">5) The Pilgrimage, Paulo Coelho, 288</span></span>

6

<span key="20818555f352400996902e95a46d8de3"><span offset-key="20818555f352400996902e95a46d8de3:0">6) A Game of Thrones, George R. R. Martin, 864</span></span>

<img src="data:image/svg+xml;base64," class="r-h7gdob r-10ptun7 r-1vzi8xi" />

Copied!

<span key="2eb55eaf07464abfbb5f42931ae125e3"><span offset-key="2eb55eaf07464abfbb5f42931ae125e3:0">Congratulations! we got the expected result. By default, SED operates on all lines. But we can force SED to operate only on certain lines. For instance, in the example below, SED only operates on the 3rd line. In this example, we have specified an address range before the SED command.</span></span>

1

<span key="13075f674b444c53aa151a4390dda077"><span offset-key="13075f674b444c53aa151a4390dda077:0">\[jerry\]$ sed -n '3p' books.txt</span></span>

<img src="data:image/svg+xml;base64," class="r-h7gdob r-10ptun7 r-1vzi8xi" />

Copied!

<span key="a16f5afd4d09464495d0be7993f1d97a"><span offset-key="a16f5afd4d09464495d0be7993f1d97a:0">When the above code is executed, it will produce the following result.</span></span>

1

<span key="dbad0e86c4da432db822d3993259dd5e"><span offset-key="dbad0e86c4da432db822d3993259dd5e:0">3) The Alchemist, Paulo Coelho, 197</span></span>

<img src="data:image/svg+xml;base64," class="r-h7gdob r-10ptun7 r-1vzi8xi" />

Copied!

<span key="74abe6bc2fab40d09bcf4879abf3cd56"><span offset-key="74abe6bc2fab40d09bcf4879abf3cd56:0">Additionally, we can also instruct SED to print only certain lines. For instance, the following code prints all the lines from 2 to 5. Here we have used the comma(,) operator to specify the address range.</span></span>

1

<span key="6e378a24613343fb8148005340955307"><span offset-key="6e378a24613343fb8148005340955307:0">\[jerry\]$ sed -n '2,5 p' books.txt</span></span>

<img src="data:image/svg+xml;base64," class="r-h7gdob r-10ptun7 r-1vzi8xi" />

Copied!

<span key="c289c42412e6419484dc8a736855a588"><span offset-key="c289c42412e6419484dc8a736855a588:0">When the above code is executed, it will produce the following result.</span></span>

1

<span key="4ef2782ef2b24ef5a4c675e10dfeb0cb"><span offset-key="4ef2782ef2b24ef5a4c675e10dfeb0cb:0">2) The Two Towers, J. R. R. Tolkien, 352</span></span>

2

<span key="dd372b70fa4f44cdbc9a9e2988831d0d"><span offset-key="dd372b70fa4f44cdbc9a9e2988831d0d:0">3) The Alchemist, Paulo Coelho, 197</span></span>

3

<span key="a86e97db78284a7ab4d2b7879512364d"><span offset-key="a86e97db78284a7ab4d2b7879512364d:0">4) The Fellowship of the Ring, J. R. R. Tolkien, 432</span></span>

4

<span key="6efa1199581d4094bc93babf010f4ed2"><span offset-key="6efa1199581d4094bc93babf010f4ed2:0">5) The Pilgrimage, Paulo Coelho, 288</span></span>

<img src="data:image/svg+xml;base64," class="r-h7gdob r-10ptun7 r-1vzi8xi" />

Copied!

<span key="15e41d56088d44cda2b30e82bf9915f9"><span offset-key="15e41d56088d44cda2b30e82bf9915f9:0">There is also a special character Dollar($) which represents the last line of the file. So let us print the last line of the file.</span></span>

1

<span key="bc0be56785ac49c9b6505a4c48075d04"><span offset-key="bc0be56785ac49c9b6505a4c48075d04:0">\[jerry\]$ sed -n '$ p' books.txt</span></span>

<img src="data:image/svg+xml;base64," class="r-h7gdob r-10ptun7 r-1vzi8xi" />

Copied!

<span key="1164d4cafdf847e18de58aa167d6f4f4"><span offset-key="1164d4cafdf847e18de58aa167d6f4f4:0">When the above code is executed, it will produce the following result.</span></span>

1

<span key="c9239fda0924423eb7bace69fa1398e1"><span offset-key="c9239fda0924423eb7bace69fa1398e1:0">6) A Game of Thrones, George R. R. Martin, 864</span></span>

<img src="data:image/svg+xml;base64," class="r-h7gdob r-10ptun7 r-1vzi8xi" />

Copied!

<span key="11d4e7896c0941668aefa76a2d920603"><span offset-key="11d4e7896c0941668aefa76a2d920603:0">However we can also use Dollar($) character to specify address range. Below example prints through line 3 to last line.</span></span>

1

<span key="2e2a96d1baec41c08cfa210ee5101f41"><span offset-key="2e2a96d1baec41c08cfa210ee5101f41:0">\[jerry\]$ sed -n '3,$ p' books.txt</span></span>

<img src="data:image/svg+xml;base64," class="r-h7gdob r-10ptun7 r-1vzi8xi" />

Copied!

<span key="250cfa6b0dca49dea5c5ac6a4f2da029"><span offset-key="250cfa6b0dca49dea5c5ac6a4f2da029:0">When the above code is executed, it will produce the following result.</span></span>

1

<span key="49748340cec14252ace556c38073d059"><span offset-key="49748340cec14252ace556c38073d059:0">3) The Alchemist, Paulo Coelho, 197 4) The Fellowship of the Ring, J. R. R. Tolkien, 432 5) The Pilgrimage, Paulo Coelho, 288 6) A Game of Thrones, George R. R. Martin, 864</span></span>

<img src="data:image/svg+xml;base64," class="r-h7gdob r-10ptun7 r-1vzi8xi" />

Copied!

<span key="3f565d99787242c180a9020ab019985b"><span offset-key="3f565d99787242c180a9020ab019985b:0">We learnt how to specify an address range using the comma(,) operator. SED supports two more operators that can be used to specify address range. First is the plus(+) operator and it can be used with the comma(,) operator. For instance </span>**M, +n**<span offset-key="3f565d99787242c180a9020ab019985b:2"> will print the next </span>**n**<span offset-key="3f565d99787242c180a9020ab019985b:4"> lines starting from line number </span>**M**<span offset-key="3f565d99787242c180a9020ab019985b:6">. Sounds confusing? Let us check it with a simple example. The following example prints the next 4 lines starting from line number 2.</span></span>

1

<span key="8d85cceb2c024c188421d4aec3130b3f"><span offset-key="8d85cceb2c024c188421d4aec3130b3f:0">\[jerry\]$ sed -n '2,+4 p' books.txt</span></span>

<img src="data:image/svg+xml;base64," class="r-h7gdob r-10ptun7 r-1vzi8xi" />

Copied!

<span key="f9f21a0845184f57bfdcfc4234071c58"><span offset-key="f9f21a0845184f57bfdcfc4234071c58:0">When the above code is executed, it will produce the following result.</span></span>

1

<span key="c7ccbf03032a44ada941d0a3577da46f"><span offset-key="c7ccbf03032a44ada941d0a3577da46f:0">2) The Two Towers, J. R. R. Tolkien, 352</span></span>

2

<span key="6b0c8dbda3fe4dbb9a0d503cdb09799c"><span offset-key="6b0c8dbda3fe4dbb9a0d503cdb09799c:0">3) The Alchemist, Paulo Coelho, 197</span></span>

3

<span key="b607d9d45fb04368994a57257af86ce1"><span offset-key="b607d9d45fb04368994a57257af86ce1:0">4) The Fellowship of the Ring, J. R. R. Tolkien, 432</span></span>

4

<span key="1e0bca35da204bcaaed6f9930b4dc4c6"><span offset-key="1e0bca35da204bcaaed6f9930b4dc4c6:0">5) The Pilgrimage, Paulo Coelho, 288</span></span>

5

<span key="cdcd6fe7fb57466883da0bb64bd2825c"><span offset-key="cdcd6fe7fb57466883da0bb64bd2825c:0">6) A Game of Thrones, George R. R. Martin, 864</span></span>

<img src="data:image/svg+xml;base64," class="r-h7gdob r-10ptun7 r-1vzi8xi" />

Copied!

<span key="ece5ef5feabd4cd7bc6495c3db226486"><span offset-key="ece5ef5feabd4cd7bc6495c3db226486:0">Optionally, we can also specify address range using the tilde(~) operator. It uses </span>**M~n**<span offset-key="ece5ef5feabd4cd7bc6495c3db226486:2"> form. It indicates that SED should start at line number M and process every n(th) line. For instance, </span>**50~5**<span offset-key="ece5ef5feabd4cd7bc6495c3db226486:4"> matches line number 50, 55, 60, 65, and so on. Let us print only odd lines from the file.</span></span>

1

<span key="14258bf80d14487fb122fcfb3da3c6eb"><span offset-key="14258bf80d14487fb122fcfb3da3c6eb:0">\[jerry\]$ sed -n '1~2 p' books.txt</span></span>

<img src="data:image/svg+xml;base64," class="r-h7gdob r-10ptun7 r-1vzi8xi" />

Copied!

<span key="c7dd3806a1a04fd5b175ef67413feacd"><span offset-key="c7dd3806a1a04fd5b175ef67413feacd:0">When the above code is executed, it will produce the following result.</span></span>

1

<span key="5078783e2a82418fb08c0b6d515c0491"><span offset-key="5078783e2a82418fb08c0b6d515c0491:0">1) A Storm of Swords, George R. R. Martin, 1216</span></span>

2

<span key="06c48e5ae21741bcb54c676e8d325666"><span offset-key="06c48e5ae21741bcb54c676e8d325666:0">3) The Alchemist, Paulo Coelho, 197</span></span>

3

<span key="a22d5dce5f334956a1fd31314b848b87"><span offset-key="a22d5dce5f334956a1fd31314b848b87:0">5) The Pilgrimage, Paulo Coelho, 288</span></span>

<img src="data:image/svg+xml;base64," class="r-h7gdob r-10ptun7 r-1vzi8xi" />

Copied!

<span key="c667a88a3f1e4f80907d75970b31a6d2"><span offset-key="c667a88a3f1e4f80907d75970b31a6d2:0">The following code prints only even lines from the file.</span></span>

1

<span key="8951b8ad73934d7abc4f39c5c733bc7d"><span offset-key="8951b8ad73934d7abc4f39c5c733bc7d:0">\[jerry\]$ sed -n '2~2 p' books.txt</span></span>

<img src="data:image/svg+xml;base64," class="r-h7gdob r-10ptun7 r-1vzi8xi" />

Copied!

<span key="83e4f3dc1f924d739524802863c18582"><span offset-key="83e4f3dc1f924d739524802863c18582:0">When the above code is executed, it will produce the following result.</span></span>

1

<span key="0293b18ccf25432386e2f8bf3dcfff0c"><span offset-key="0293b18ccf25432386e2f8bf3dcfff0c:0">2) The Two Towers, J. R. R. Tolkien, 352</span></span>

2

<span key="9b30a51e4873407e8079bda8976dadf6"><span offset-key="9b30a51e4873407e8079bda8976dadf6:0">4) The Fellowship of the Ring, J. R. R. Tolkien, 432</span></span>

3

<span key="60224de9d167452d827932845efb43ca"><span offset-key="60224de9d167452d827932845efb43ca:0">6) A Game of Thrones, George R. R. Martin, 864</span></span>

<img src="data:image/svg+xml;base64," class="r-h7gdob r-10ptun7 r-1vzi8xi" />

Copied!

# 

<span key="d163a00b4fa642b280b334ab3a6d6910"><span offset-key="d163a00b4fa642b280b334ab3a6d6910:0">Stream Editor - Pattern Range</span></span>

<span key="5b3f1731c7f64c7b88a00bceb34bce09"><span offset-key="5b3f1731c7f64c7b88a00bceb34bce09:0">In the previous chapter, we learnt how SED handles an address range. This chapter covers how SED takes care of a pattern range. A pattern range can be a simple text or a complex regular expression. Let us take an example. The following example prints all the books of the author Paulo Coelho.</span></span>

1

<span key="da2d72294dbe454c89009178f0900373"><span offset-key="da2d72294dbe454c89009178f0900373:0">\[jerry\]$ sed -n '/Paulo/ p' books.txt</span></span>

<img src="data:image/svg+xml;base64," class="r-h7gdob r-10ptun7 r-1vzi8xi" />

Copied!

<span key="e0cfe8cea6554f64bde4dcd027d96b1f"><span offset-key="e0cfe8cea6554f64bde4dcd027d96b1f:0">On executing the above code, you get the following result:</span></span>

1

<span key="7597f61265e04ff281e7a0dc3a5edabf"><span offset-key="7597f61265e04ff281e7a0dc3a5edabf:0">3) The Alchemist, Paulo Coelho, 197</span></span>

2

<span key="9703c3c735b44e26a7cbfd6891076c4c"><span offset-key="9703c3c735b44e26a7cbfd6891076c4c:0">5) The Pilgrimage, Paulo Coelho, 288</span></span>

<img src="data:image/svg+xml;base64," class="r-h7gdob r-10ptun7 r-1vzi8xi" />

Copied!

<span key="7b12c1641a6b4200988d92845b930b18"><span offset-key="7b12c1641a6b4200988d92845b930b18:0">In the above example, the SED operates on each line and prints only those lines that match the string Paulo.</span></span>

<span key="3763cd502e514550ab9131415d14b4c8"><span offset-key="3763cd502e514550ab9131415d14b4c8:0">We can also combine a pattern range with an address range. The following example prints lines starting with the first match of Alchemist until the fifth line.</span></span>

1

<span key="3a6b285378014e92bf019b0aa9fe3f47"><span offset-key="3a6b285378014e92bf019b0aa9fe3f47:0">\[jerry\]$ sed -n '/Alchemist/, 5 p' books.txt</span></span>

<img src="data:image/svg+xml;base64," class="r-h7gdob r-10ptun7 r-1vzi8xi" />

Copied!

<span key="6cd2a93f848445f6bca9e9ce0b135cc3"><span offset-key="6cd2a93f848445f6bca9e9ce0b135cc3:0">On executing the above code, you get the following result:</span></span>

1

<span key="8c5cdb314532473db8a8de7f64eba92a"><span offset-key="8c5cdb314532473db8a8de7f64eba92a:0">3) The Alchemist, Paulo Coelho, 197</span></span>

2

<span key="5916aa02f1864ac698ede6590753cd6b"><span offset-key="5916aa02f1864ac698ede6590753cd6b:0">4) The Fellowship of the Ring, J. R. R. Tolkien, 432</span></span>

3

<span key="813224e0aa544d9f8ec61e8380f3ebae"><span offset-key="813224e0aa544d9f8ec61e8380f3ebae:0">5) The Pilgrimage, Paulo Coelho, 288</span></span>

<img src="data:image/svg+xml;base64," class="r-h7gdob r-10ptun7 r-1vzi8xi" />

Copied!

<span key="e5c723f5437b4c3ca2762c826e7d8a7b"><span offset-key="e5c723f5437b4c3ca2762c826e7d8a7b:0">We can use the Dollar($) character to print all the lines after finding the first occurrence of the pattern. The following example finds the first occurrence of the pattern The and immediately prints the remaining lines from the file</span></span>

1

<span key="70f54134285c403b8fc7b1f09470ab30"><span offset-key="70f54134285c403b8fc7b1f09470ab30:0">\[jerry\]$ sed -n '/The/,$ p' books.txt</span></span>

<img src="data:image/svg+xml;base64," class="r-h7gdob r-10ptun7 r-1vzi8xi" />

Copied!

<span key="259bd48942b941fa8f6686153c0cd4e4"><span offset-key="259bd48942b941fa8f6686153c0cd4e4:0">On executing the above code, you get the following result:</span></span>

1

<span key="54147f1b03ab49148d55c707fd46b044"><span offset-key="54147f1b03ab49148d55c707fd46b044:0">2) The Two Towers, J. R. R. Tolkien, 352</span></span>

2

<span key="4361ef93e6644a0ca70f76a3694acd17"><span offset-key="4361ef93e6644a0ca70f76a3694acd17:0">3) The Alchemist, Paulo Coelho, 197</span></span>

3

<span key="5555e3bc964148cc94e497160d7185c3"><span offset-key="5555e3bc964148cc94e497160d7185c3:0">4) The Fellowship of the Ring, J. R. R. Tolkien, 432</span></span>

4

<span key="d13082fdf686432ca94e6578ebb714b8"><span offset-key="d13082fdf686432ca94e6578ebb714b8:0">5) The Pilgrimage, Paulo Coelho, 288</span></span>

5

<span key="5735d645bf7743c5ba647dee62aa24e8"><span offset-key="5735d645bf7743c5ba647dee62aa24e8:0">6) A Game of Thrones, George R. R. Martin, 864</span></span>

<img src="data:image/svg+xml;base64," class="r-h7gdob r-10ptun7 r-1vzi8xi" />

Copied!

<span key="009b7ee37f654b2c9dcf95d5f51b84d9"><span offset-key="009b7ee37f654b2c9dcf95d5f51b84d9:0">We can also specify more than one pattern ranges using the comma(,) operator. The following example prints all the lines that exist between the patterns Two and Pilgrimage.</span></span>

1

<span key="2da5a85110a04d549c1f63ce75712036"><span offset-key="2da5a85110a04d549c1f63ce75712036:0">\[jerry\]$ sed -n '/Two/, /Pilgrimage/ p' books.txt</span></span>

<img src="data:image/svg+xml;base64," class="r-h7gdob r-10ptun7 r-1vzi8xi" />

Copied!

<span key="91a9a41e5f13429da98cdf601cb94350"><span offset-key="91a9a41e5f13429da98cdf601cb94350:0">On executing the above code, you get the following result:</span></span>

1

<span key="a89f36b6a8e143c2b00821c3793a93d9"><span offset-key="a89f36b6a8e143c2b00821c3793a93d9:0">2) The Two Towers, J. R. R. Tolkien, 352</span></span>

2

<span key="8cbbfa5deef74148be21b921a85fd4af"><span offset-key="8cbbfa5deef74148be21b921a85fd4af:0">3) The Alchemist, Paulo Coelho, 197</span></span>

3

<span key="054d7fc291704c12932ee7c27722ebcb"><span offset-key="054d7fc291704c12932ee7c27722ebcb:0">4) The Fellowship of the Ring, J. R. R. Tolkien, 432</span></span>

4

<span key="162df716f05442e5a2e123769b74b451"><span offset-key="162df716f05442e5a2e123769b74b451:0">5) The Pilgrimage, Paulo Coelho, 288</span></span>

<img src="data:image/svg+xml;base64," class="r-h7gdob r-10ptun7 r-1vzi8xi" />

Copied!

<span key="30ae46bb773c41b8811fed662f78ed1e"><span offset-key="30ae46bb773c41b8811fed662f78ed1e:0">Additionally, we can use the plus(+) operator within a pattern range. The following example finds the first occurrence of the pattern Two and prints the next 4 lines after that.</span></span>

1

<span key="b1a8a2652cd6429e8d412635d5dc2370"><span offset-key="b1a8a2652cd6429e8d412635d5dc2370:0">\[jerry\]$ sed -n '/Two/, +4 p' books.txt</span></span>

<img src="data:image/svg+xml;base64," class="r-h7gdob r-10ptun7 r-1vzi8xi" />

Copied!

<span key="89d0bb618d934d0382aff0c81f544cdd"><span offset-key="89d0bb618d934d0382aff0c81f544cdd:0">On executing the above code, you get the following result:</span></span>

1

<span key="23061d8f0b024de78ff98d18840efc4e"><span offset-key="23061d8f0b024de78ff98d18840efc4e:0">2) The Two Towers, J. R. R. Tolkien, 352</span></span>

2

<span key="dec27685284f4c4ea9724f7f66d1374e"><span offset-key="dec27685284f4c4ea9724f7f66d1374e:0">3) The Alchemist, Paulo Coelho, 197</span></span>

3

<span key="612538f2d5ac4ea085dd997c10c2116e"><span offset-key="612538f2d5ac4ea085dd997c10c2116e:0">4) The Fellowship of the Ring, J. R. R. Tolkien, 432</span></span>

4

<span key="4a6624638e6842388e03733423348b89"><span offset-key="4a6624638e6842388e03733423348b89:0">5) The Pilgrimage, Paulo Coelho, 288</span></span>

5

<span key="74412d89ee8a4215adcd50c6af8458e1"><span offset-key="74412d89ee8a4215adcd50c6af8458e1:0">6) A Game of Thrones, George R. R. Martin, 864</span></span>

<img src="data:image/svg+xml;base64," class="r-h7gdob r-10ptun7 r-1vzi8xi" />

Copied!

<span key="343a55b8d3d24537aa57ba27dbcf9baf"><span offset-key="343a55b8d3d24537aa57ba27dbcf9baf:0">We have supplied here only a few examples to get you acquainted with SED. You can always get to know more by trying a few examples on your own.</span></span>

# 

<span key="a901922d3bd544bca7d3455ed534d7f2"><span offset-key="a901922d3bd544bca7d3455ed534d7f2:0">Stream Editor - Basic Commands</span></span>

<span key="4e728816b5c240c8929480b81d3c9577"><span offset-key="4e728816b5c240c8929480b81d3c9577:0">This chapter describes several useful SED commands.</span></span>

## 

<span key="9987dcc66cd44b0f8b8530a9636ebb4b"><span offset-key="9987dcc66cd44b0f8b8530a9636ebb4b:0">Delete Command</span></span>

<span key="18b9486cef6f4df0b0e8b5fb884d94e1"><span offset-key="18b9486cef6f4df0b0e8b5fb884d94e1:0">SED provides various commands to manipulate text. Let us first explore about the </span>**delete**<span offset-key="18b9486cef6f4df0b0e8b5fb884d94e1:2"> command. Here is how you execute a delete command:</span></span>

1

<span key="09c401a9fe4441c38d02468ee58f97d8"><span offset-key="09c401a9fe4441c38d02468ee58f97d8:0">\[address1\[,address2\]\]d</span></span>

<img src="data:image/svg+xml;base64," class="r-h7gdob r-10ptun7 r-1vzi8xi" />

Copied!

<span key="b9541f1da09d49da98c926132fc9e7f4">**address1**<span offset-key="b9541f1da09d49da98c926132fc9e7f4:1"> and </span>**address2**<span offset-key="b9541f1da09d49da98c926132fc9e7f4:3"> are the starting and the ending addresses respectively, which can be either line numbers or pattern strings. Both of these addresses are optional parameters.</span></span>

<span key="9dc2764a360941e6801e26c37b838c5b"><span offset-key="9dc2764a360941e6801e26c37b838c5b:0">As the name suggests, the delete command is used to perform delete operation and since the SED operates on line, we can say that this command is used to delete lines. Note that the delete command removes lines only from the pattern buffer; the line is not sent to the output stream and the original file remains unchanged. The following example illustrates the point.</span></span>

1

<span key="b8f11eab0a634c7d9bbeaaa3634dbdb2"><span offset-key="b8f11eab0a634c7d9bbeaaa3634dbdb2:0">\[jerry\]$ sed 'd' books.txt</span></span>

<img src="data:image/svg+xml;base64," class="r-h7gdob r-10ptun7 r-1vzi8xi" />

Copied!

<span key="2d2852af62bf4f56ad8696b3a029a3e4"><span offset-key="2d2852af62bf4f56ad8696b3a029a3e4:0">But where is the output? If no line address is provided, then the SED operates on every line by default. Hence, it deletes all the lines from the pattern buffer. That is why the command does not print anything on the standard output.</span></span>

<span key="b683ee92e0c54430973852156c8c21b8"><span offset-key="b683ee92e0c54430973852156c8c21b8:0">Let us instruct the SED to operate only on certain lines. The following example removes the 4th line only.</span></span>

1

<span key="14c64f1f37c44f978863a975cb0413e6"><span offset-key="14c64f1f37c44f978863a975cb0413e6:0">\[jerry\]$ sed '4d' books.txt</span></span>

<img src="data:image/svg+xml;base64," class="r-h7gdob r-10ptun7 r-1vzi8xi" />

Copied!

<span key="b178c0040a4f4e4dbf26c72096f16123"><span offset-key="b178c0040a4f4e4dbf26c72096f16123:0">On executing the above code, you get the following result:</span></span>

1

<span key="96556940e20449a2a59a9057c5cc60db"><span offset-key="96556940e20449a2a59a9057c5cc60db:0">1) A Storm of Swords, George R. R. Martin, 1216</span></span>

2

<span key="a06caad583d24d1eb6e43f015f578000"><span offset-key="a06caad583d24d1eb6e43f015f578000:0">2) The Two Towers, J. R. R. Tolkien, 352</span></span>

3

<span key="25abcac86bfd4a92b41234ca05abbd3c"><span offset-key="25abcac86bfd4a92b41234ca05abbd3c:0">3) The Alchemist, Paulo Coelho, 197</span></span>

4

<span key="4bd30ceae2724137a863ff64aa3d5d9b"><span offset-key="4bd30ceae2724137a863ff64aa3d5d9b:0">5) The Pilgrimage, Paulo Coelho, 288</span></span>

5

<span key="5fa049c3635b435f93f79f3b66e9402a"><span offset-key="5fa049c3635b435f93f79f3b66e9402a:0">6) A Game of Thrones, George R. R. Martin, 864</span></span>

<img src="data:image/svg+xml;base64," class="r-h7gdob r-10ptun7 r-1vzi8xi" />

Copied!

<span key="cd0041002b324e27a878f573ec45ccbb"><span offset-key="cd0041002b324e27a878f573ec45ccbb:0">Additionally, SED also accepts address range using comma(,). We can instruct the SED to remove N1 to N2 lines. For instance, the following example deletes all the lines from 2 through 4.</span></span>

1

<span key="2b8e78016f8346d9ac125f1941adefd0"><span offset-key="2b8e78016f8346d9ac125f1941adefd0:0">\[jerry\]$ sed '2, 4 d' books.txt</span></span>

<img src="data:image/svg+xml;base64," class="r-h7gdob r-10ptun7 r-1vzi8xi" />

Copied!

<span key="d9498434b4ed444da1ffc42460c7499c"><span offset-key="d9498434b4ed444da1ffc42460c7499c:0">On executing the above code, you get the following result:</span></span>

1

<span key="83e87e5f70bd4a1ca571aac6c1f3e43d"><span offset-key="83e87e5f70bd4a1ca571aac6c1f3e43d:0">1) A Storm of Swords, George R. R. Martin, 1216</span></span>

2

<span key="4fba5f60f5684e50b24e38dd676d1027"><span offset-key="4fba5f60f5684e50b24e38dd676d1027:0">5) The Pilgrimage, Paulo Coelho, 288</span></span>

3

<span key="1e1d3a54af0d4fbab1ff2a4d71fabaa8"><span offset-key="1e1d3a54af0d4fbab1ff2a4d71fabaa8:0">6) A Game of Thrones, George R. R. Martin, 864</span></span>

<img src="data:image/svg+xml;base64," class="r-h7gdob r-10ptun7 r-1vzi8xi" />

Copied!

<span key="a771b6f4fbb24fabb87a821b6f17e955"><span offset-key="a771b6f4fbb24fabb87a821b6f17e955:0">SED's address range is not only limited to numbers. We can also specify patterns as an address. The following example removes all the books of the author Paulo Coelho.</span></span>

1

<span key="fd235fb8810d410498e3d5d9ff880c7c"><span offset-key="fd235fb8810d410498e3d5d9ff880c7c:0">\[jerry\]$ sed '/Paulo Coelho/d' books.txt</span></span>

<img src="data:image/svg+xml;base64," class="r-h7gdob r-10ptun7 r-1vzi8xi" />

Copied!

<span key="13f3f03e6bec470db6ccaf61955e985e"><span offset-key="13f3f03e6bec470db6ccaf61955e985e:0">On executing the above code, you get the following result:</span></span>

1
