<span key="65cdd5eced7942a7b21e8f2fe83db80f"><span offset-key="65cdd5eced7942a7b21e8f2fe83db80f:0">1) A Storm of Swords, George R. R. Martin, 1216</span></span>

2

<span key="20ae593dd4a24d4ea6b4bfdc521f7f04"><span offset-key="20ae593dd4a24d4ea6b4bfdc521f7f04:0">2) The Two Towers, J. R. R. Tolkien, 352</span></span>

3

<span key="5026af70e30646c598e916e603392987"><span offset-key="5026af70e30646c598e916e603392987:0">4) The Fellowship of the Ring, J. R. R. Tolkien, 432</span></span>

4

<span key="f2745fa2b14e4d5d81cebf61936d9923"><span offset-key="f2745fa2b14e4d5d81cebf61936d9923:0">6) A Game of Thrones, George R. R. Martin, 864</span></span>

<img src="data:image/svg+xml;base64," class="r-h7gdob r-10ptun7 r-1vzi8xi" />

Copied!

<span key="c938d9f0a02245b888c0339ac294194b"><span offset-key="c938d9f0a02245b888c0339ac294194b:0">We can also specify an address range using textual pattern. The following example removes all lines between the patterns </span>**Storm**<span offset-key="c938d9f0a02245b888c0339ac294194b:2"> and </span>**Fellowship**<span offset-key="c938d9f0a02245b888c0339ac294194b:4">.</span></span>

1

<span key="be9cda3e6f8c45e2919bfc9d700361c6"><span offset-key="be9cda3e6f8c45e2919bfc9d700361c6:0">\[jerry\]$ sed '/Storm/,/Fellowship/d' books.txt</span></span>

2

<span key="8685bb8f2e78414bae60b1743a161590"><span offset-key="8685bb8f2e78414bae60b1743a161590:0">5) The Pilgrimage, Paulo Coelho, 288</span></span>

3

<span key="0c303bec253541ec9c0d7a254cee14ae"><span offset-key="0c303bec253541ec9c0d7a254cee14ae:0">6) A Game of Thrones, George R. R. Martin, 864</span></span>

<img src="data:image/svg+xml;base64," class="r-h7gdob r-10ptun7 r-1vzi8xi" />

Copied!

<span key="39a55df61e27404f8d1234f2593230c3"><span offset-key="39a55df61e27404f8d1234f2593230c3:0">In addition to this, we can also use dollar($), plus(+), and tilde(~) operators with SED.</span></span>

## 

<span key="39caa95441ea470da9995d381eac30c4"><span offset-key="39caa95441ea470da9995d381eac30c4:0">Write Command</span></span>

<span key="246e17bcc0484835a44ff395e6960465"><span offset-key="246e17bcc0484835a44ff395e6960465:0">One of the important operations we perform on any file is backup, i.e., we make another copy of the file. SED provides the </span>**write**<span offset-key="246e17bcc0484835a44ff395e6960465:2"> command to store the contents of the pattern buffer in a file. Given below is the syntax of the </span>**write**<span offset-key="246e17bcc0484835a44ff395e6960465:4"> command which is similar to the </span>**delete**<span offset-key="246e17bcc0484835a44ff395e6960465:6"> command.</span></span>

1

<span key="0c28f05d2cbd46ca84477cc1cbc7ec83"><span offset-key="0c28f05d2cbd46ca84477cc1cbc7ec83:0">\[address1\[,address2\]\]w file</span></span>

<img src="data:image/svg+xml;base64," class="r-h7gdob r-10ptun7 r-1vzi8xi" />

Copied!

<span key="a84cb6c0308a41eabf9f7f6c65e24f42"><span offset-key="a84cb6c0308a41eabf9f7f6c65e24f42:0">Here, </span>**address1**<span offset-key="a84cb6c0308a41eabf9f7f6c65e24f42:2"> and </span>**address2**<span offset-key="a84cb6c0308a41eabf9f7f6c65e24f42:4"> are the starting and the ending address respectively, which can be either line numbers or pattern strings. Both of these addresses are optional parameters.</span></span>

<span key="8f90442ffbe241a6ac5eaf59a028a796"><span offset-key="8f90442ffbe241a6ac5eaf59a028a796:0">In the above syntax, </span>**w**<span offset-key="8f90442ffbe241a6ac5eaf59a028a796:2"> refers to the write command and </span>**file**<span offset-key="8f90442ffbe241a6ac5eaf59a028a796:4"> is the file name in which you store contents. Be careful with the </span>**file**<span offset-key="8f90442ffbe241a6ac5eaf59a028a796:6"> parameter. When a file name is provided, the SED creates a file on the fly if it is not present, and overwrites it if it is already present.</span></span>

<span key="bc2844c25dcd4e9d88c1ed5e39c79de2"><span offset-key="bc2844c25dcd4e9d88c1ed5e39c79de2:0">Let us make an exact copy of the file using SED. Note that there must be exactly one space between </span>**w**<span offset-key="bc2844c25dcd4e9d88c1ed5e39c79de2:2"> and </span>**file**<span offset-key="bc2844c25dcd4e9d88c1ed5e39c79de2:4">.</span></span>

1

<span key="059cad0b69754e69bbe819800840cce1"><span offset-key="059cad0b69754e69bbe819800840cce1:0">\[jerry\]$ sed -n 'w books.bak' books.txt</span></span>

<img src="data:image/svg+xml;base64," class="r-h7gdob r-10ptun7 r-1vzi8xi" />

Copied!

<span key="7a702e57a9574aac9e37acc656439365"><span offset-key="7a702e57a9574aac9e37acc656439365:0">We created another file called </span>**books.bak.**<span offset-key="7a702e57a9574aac9e37acc656439365:2"> Now verify that both the files have identical content.</span></span>

1

<span key="694034eae98d4c198a9e778962bb4a36"><span offset-key="694034eae98d4c198a9e778962bb4a36:0">\[jerry\]$ diff books.txt books.bak</span></span>

2

<span key="96e08968faad4d55b0824b172000a7a9"><span offset-key="96e08968faad4d55b0824b172000a7a9:0">\[jerry\]$ echo $?</span></span>

<img src="data:image/svg+xml;base64," class="r-h7gdob r-10ptun7 r-1vzi8xi" />

Copied!

<span key="1318e5fb0f4a4c5b883f395a18b52aeb"><span offset-key="1318e5fb0f4a4c5b883f395a18b52aeb:0">On executing the above code, you get the following result:</span></span>

1

<span key="23ef2966c6c74eb3892dcffcc62db16d"><span offset-key="23ef2966c6c74eb3892dcffcc62db16d:0">0</span></span>

<img src="data:image/svg+xml;base64," class="r-h7gdob r-10ptun7 r-1vzi8xi" />

Copied!

<span key="69118daf7f354463a99e262c5c424080"><span offset-key="69118daf7f354463a99e262c5c424080:0">You may assume that the </span>**cp**<span offset-key="69118daf7f354463a99e262c5c424080:2"> command does exactly the same thing. Yes! The </span>**cp**<span offset-key="69118daf7f354463a99e262c5c424080:4"> command does the same thing, but SED is a matured utility. It allows creating a file containing only certain lines from the source file. Let us store only even lines to another file.</span></span>

1

<span key="23b821168d1c43138d168b3950c6d7d2"><span offset-key="23b821168d1c43138d168b3950c6d7d2:0">\[jerry\]$ sed -n '2~2 w junk.txt' books.txt</span></span>

2

<span key="f8673f6711ca41ffa727fd61d82f3936"><span offset-key="f8673f6711ca41ffa727fd61d82f3936:0">\[jerry\]$ cat junk.txt</span></span>

<img src="data:image/svg+xml;base64," class="r-h7gdob r-10ptun7 r-1vzi8xi" />

Copied!

<span key="2b669bfc659e4ac38b1596203227bd8e"><span offset-key="2b669bfc659e4ac38b1596203227bd8e:0">On executing the above code, you get the following result:</span></span>

1

<span key="248d1c685f34484ab33ec364cb027920"><span offset-key="248d1c685f34484ab33ec364cb027920:0">2) The Two Towers, J. R. R. Tolkien, 352</span></span>

2

<span key="7d0e60cfb5dd43ffbd9a50c5573d556b"><span offset-key="7d0e60cfb5dd43ffbd9a50c5573d556b:0">4) The Fellowship of the Ring, J. R. R. Tolkien, 432</span></span>

3

<span key="29835dc6a1744c79a1f34a737423b6f3"><span offset-key="29835dc6a1744c79a1f34a737423b6f3:0">6) A Game of Thrones, George R. R. Martin, 864</span></span>

<img src="data:image/svg+xml;base64," class="r-h7gdob r-10ptun7 r-1vzi8xi" />

Copied!

<span key="4c031a02c9534c208ed3214c4a430da6"><span offset-key="4c031a02c9534c208ed3214c4a430da6:0">You can also use comma(,), dollar($), and plus(+) operators with the write command.</span></span>

<span key="d3340cc842234bca94b0f646a49c1dd0"><span offset-key="d3340cc842234bca94b0f646a49c1dd0:0">In addition to this, SED also supports pattern matching with the write command. Suppose you want to store all the books of individual authors into a separate file. One boring and lengthy way is do it manually, and the smarter way is to use SED.</span></span>

1

<span key="615ef3d914bf4c578edc317be6843d50"><span offset-key="615ef3d914bf4c578edc317be6843d50:0">\[jerry\]$ sed -n -e '/Martin/ w Martin.txt' -e '/Paulo/ w Paulo.txt' -e '/Tolkien/ w</span></span>

2

<span key="355bc267cdf941df8d0518f3f06a4c1b"><span offset-key="355bc267cdf941df8d0518f3f06a4c1b:0">Tolkien.txt' books.txt</span></span>

<img src="data:image/svg+xml;base64," class="r-h7gdob r-10ptun7 r-1vzi8xi" />

Copied!

<span key="a118f075042c442cbdd50884e5693358"><span offset-key="a118f075042c442cbdd50884e5693358:0">In the above example, we are matching each line against a pattern and storing the matched line in a particular file. It is very simple. To specify multiple commands, we used </span>**-e**<span offset-key="a118f075042c442cbdd50884e5693358:2"> switch of the SED command. Now let use see what each file contains:</span></span>

1

<span key="6a7396dbc37f4b2bb8300a8f53e65a0d"><span offset-key="6a7396dbc37f4b2bb8300a8f53e65a0d:0">\[jerry\]$ cat Martin.txt</span></span>

<img src="data:image/svg+xml;base64," class="r-h7gdob r-10ptun7 r-1vzi8xi" />

Copied!

<span key="34a259cd3136478c88238fce5b897c88"><span offset-key="34a259cd3136478c88238fce5b897c88:0">On executing the above code, you get the following result:</span></span>

1

<span key="879786f92e8c441794ead36268fd07af"><span offset-key="879786f92e8c441794ead36268fd07af:0">1) A Storm of Swords, George R. R. Martin, 1216</span></span>

2

<span key="89a11e137849406089d6c88fa8b5d4e3"><span offset-key="89a11e137849406089d6c88fa8b5d4e3:0">6) A Game of Thrones, George R. R. Martin, 864</span></span>

<img src="data:image/svg+xml;base64," class="r-h7gdob r-10ptun7 r-1vzi8xi" />

Copied!

<span key="9b05085f456e42d39436c6b033b96220"><span offset-key="9b05085f456e42d39436c6b033b96220:0">Let us display the file contents.</span></span>

1

<span key="9b6a66b4d4514730badf3575b06e7c1f"><span offset-key="9b6a66b4d4514730badf3575b06e7c1f:0">\[jerry\]$ cat Paulo.txt</span></span>

<img src="data:image/svg+xml;base64," class="r-h7gdob r-10ptun7 r-1vzi8xi" />

Copied!

<span key="6b6554e6985c42d7869f82e7aff97920"><span offset-key="6b6554e6985c42d7869f82e7aff97920:0">On executing the above code, you get the following result:</span></span>

1

<span key="55efd40da6ec4b68b60b6409c9e4da88"><span offset-key="55efd40da6ec4b68b60b6409c9e4da88:0">3) The Alchemist, Paulo Coelho, 197</span></span>

2

<span key="a36227d7f09b4fc59fd3ded5b55e0df3"><span offset-key="a36227d7f09b4fc59fd3ded5b55e0df3:0">5) The Pilgrimage, Paulo Coelho, 288</span></span>

<img src="data:image/svg+xml;base64," class="r-h7gdob r-10ptun7 r-1vzi8xi" />

Copied!

<span key="befc0b113264446d85c00adb75225425"><span offset-key="befc0b113264446d85c00adb75225425:0">Let us display the file contents.</span></span>

1

<span key="18a678cf9f5e422487200ce6f893c38a"><span offset-key="18a678cf9f5e422487200ce6f893c38a:0">\[jerry\]$ cat Tolkien.txt</span></span>

<img src="data:image/svg+xml;base64," class="r-h7gdob r-10ptun7 r-1vzi8xi" />

Copied!

<span key="4930d97b043147e389ed0ba478740616"><span offset-key="4930d97b043147e389ed0ba478740616:0">On executing the above code, you get the following result:</span></span>

1

<span key="45291fb2484c4fc781475e8f4373be5e"><span offset-key="45291fb2484c4fc781475e8f4373be5e:0">2) The Two Towers, J. R. R. Tolkien, 352</span></span>

2

<span key="a8bd69783c354ee98ec97add670b20cb"><span offset-key="a8bd69783c354ee98ec97add670b20cb:0">4) The Fellowship of the Ring, J. R. R. Tolkien, 432</span></span>

<img src="data:image/svg+xml;base64," class="r-h7gdob r-10ptun7 r-1vzi8xi" />

Copied!

<span key="e4254b86b819482ebe58898282e85600"><span offset-key="e4254b86b819482ebe58898282e85600:0">Excellent! We got the expected result. SED is really an amazing utility.</span></span>

## 

<span key="b41ad60f39554875845f43b1093ec071"><span offset-key="b41ad60f39554875845f43b1093ec071:0">Append Command</span></span>

<span key="6ddbbadfd353407d847ef7629271dc45"><span offset-key="6ddbbadfd353407d847ef7629271dc45:0">One of the most useful operations of any text editor is to provide append functionality. SED supports this operation through its append command. Given below is the syntax of append:</span></span>

1

<span key="4d4a868abaf84c94823e48b4133f6292"><span offset-key="4d4a868abaf84c94823e48b4133f6292:0">\[address\]a\\</span></span>

2

<span key="69bc7cc797bb4cc68fed4cd7ea34baf0"><span offset-key="69bc7cc797bb4cc68fed4cd7ea34baf0:0">Append text</span></span>

<img src="data:image/svg+xml;base64," class="r-h7gdob r-10ptun7 r-1vzi8xi" />

Copied!

<span key="07543ed22c2d4315ab9ad1369d9a5c85"><span offset-key="07543ed22c2d4315ab9ad1369d9a5c85:0">Let us append a new book entry after line number 4. The following example shows how to do it</span></span>

1

<span key="9c9274ad914b44d4bbe24b6d45395e33"><span offset-key="9c9274ad914b44d4bbe24b6d45395e33:0">\[jerry\]$ sed '4 a 7) Adultry, Paulo Coelho, 234' books.txt</span></span>

<img src="data:image/svg+xml;base64," class="r-h7gdob r-10ptun7 r-1vzi8xi" />

Copied!

<span key="92fdc3ba1e2745519ef073ee89235d21"><span offset-key="92fdc3ba1e2745519ef073ee89235d21:0">On executing the above code, you get the following result:</span></span>

1

<span key="f0341125d33c4a8bb5518475697023ad"><span offset-key="f0341125d33c4a8bb5518475697023ad:0">1) A Storm of Swords, George R. R. Martin, 1216</span></span>

2

<span key="b35661591b98423d85891b7a4e18dbe7"><span offset-key="b35661591b98423d85891b7a4e18dbe7:0">2) The Two Towers, J. R. R. Tolkien, 352</span></span>

3

<span key="7f27d215efd64e049bef6387dabbf662"><span offset-key="7f27d215efd64e049bef6387dabbf662:0">3) The Alchemist, Paulo Coelho, 197</span></span>

4

<span key="0b35a40f5c754afa822e51bce669031d"><span offset-key="0b35a40f5c754afa822e51bce669031d:0">4) The Fellowship of the Ring, J. R. R. Tolkien, 432</span></span>

5

<span key="cfc8ad659f32488b8e32658c169d4df0"><span offset-key="cfc8ad659f32488b8e32658c169d4df0:0">7) Adultry, Paulo Coelho, 234</span></span>

6

<span key="dbba311297624ebc812ab5970f7ee0c2"><span offset-key="dbba311297624ebc812ab5970f7ee0c2:0">5) The Pilgrimage, Paulo Coelho, 288</span></span>

7

<span key="a15ed5ec073542e19da32c9f1d8f687a"><span offset-key="a15ed5ec073542e19da32c9f1d8f687a:0">6) A Game of Thrones, George R. R. Martin, 864</span></span>

<img src="data:image/svg+xml;base64," class="r-h7gdob r-10ptun7 r-1vzi8xi" />

Copied!

<span key="99f74251fed942f98a6bb28e69bd801d"><span offset-key="99f74251fed942f98a6bb28e69bd801d:0">In the command section, </span>**4**<span offset-key="99f74251fed942f98a6bb28e69bd801d:2"> implies the line number, </span>**a**<span offset-key="99f74251fed942f98a6bb28e69bd801d:4"> is the append command, and the remaining part is the text to be appended.</span></span>

<span key="80648f5fe9f548d6b1148dd60a909894"><span offset-key="80648f5fe9f548d6b1148dd60a909894:0">Let us insert a text line at the end of the file. To do this, use </span>**$**<span offset-key="80648f5fe9f548d6b1148dd60a909894:2"> as the address. The following example illustrates this:</span></span>

1

<span key="2c3993df23ef4919a9c750087d401023"><span offset-key="2c3993df23ef4919a9c750087d401023:0">\[jerry\]$ sed '$ a 7) Adultry, Paulo Coelho, 234' books.txt</span></span>

<img src="data:image/svg+xml;base64," class="r-h7gdob r-10ptun7 r-1vzi8xi" />

Copied!

<span key="0fb04d70c34f483fb947b214831350f9"><span offset-key="0fb04d70c34f483fb947b214831350f9:0">On executing the above code, you get the following result:</span></span>

1

<span key="e229b95d5342436e9e5f8195b0deb05f"><span offset-key="e229b95d5342436e9e5f8195b0deb05f:0">1) A Storm of Swords, George R. R. Martin, 1216</span></span>

2

<span key="8eaec200ba234b47b7147ef24d01185c"><span offset-key="8eaec200ba234b47b7147ef24d01185c:0">2) The Two Towers, J. R. R. Tolkien, 352</span></span>

3

<span key="30ccd1aa3fa54c12b2a7b7d3e1e2946f"><span offset-key="30ccd1aa3fa54c12b2a7b7d3e1e2946f:0">3) The Alchemist, Paulo Coelho, 197</span></span>

4

<span key="dd0cd3f7320c4e3f9b4904a057a65920"><span offset-key="dd0cd3f7320c4e3f9b4904a057a65920:0">4) The Fellowship of the Ring, J. R. R. Tolkien, 432</span></span>

5

<span key="94ebfcac1643455499b4f6b0af479a2a"><span offset-key="94ebfcac1643455499b4f6b0af479a2a:0">5) The Pilgrimage, Paulo Coelho, 288</span></span>

6

<span key="4d8a9ac4c3f54c62868fb2b15c28f87a"><span offset-key="4d8a9ac4c3f54c62868fb2b15c28f87a:0">6) A Game of Thrones, George R. R. Martin, 864</span></span>

7

<span key="63d19538f1fb4adc97c382b00f8e5e8f"><span offset-key="63d19538f1fb4adc97c382b00f8e5e8f:0">7) Adultry, Paulo Coelho, 234</span></span>

<img src="data:image/svg+xml;base64," class="r-h7gdob r-10ptun7 r-1vzi8xi" />

Copied!

<span key="c0a3c81893a14377b33e621a45984cf0"><span offset-key="c0a3c81893a14377b33e621a45984cf0:0">Apart from line number, we can also specify an address using textual pattern. For instance, the following example appends text after matching the string </span>**The Alchemist**<span offset-key="c0a3c81893a14377b33e621a45984cf0:2">.</span></span>

1

<span key="3a0c232e462b43728d7224af0a811492"><span offset-key="3a0c232e462b43728d7224af0a811492:0">\[jerry\]$ sed '/The Alchemist/ a 7) Adultry, Paulo Coelho, 234' books.txt</span></span>

<img src="data:image/svg+xml;base64," class="r-h7gdob r-10ptun7 r-1vzi8xi" />

Copied!

<span key="a61e1570887048bf86593b93117e3593"><span offset-key="a61e1570887048bf86593b93117e3593:0">On executing the above code, you get the following result:</span></span>

1

<span key="3628a41f11e34f3ab2699de6106b094f"><span offset-key="3628a41f11e34f3ab2699de6106b094f:0">1) A Storm of Swords, George R. R. Martin, 1216</span></span>

2

<span key="1ae029223d214e4c8c6090fcdf2fb280"><span offset-key="1ae029223d214e4c8c6090fcdf2fb280:0">2) The Two Towers, J. R. R. Tolkien, 352</span></span>

3

<span key="beb895180c854d3c849ae96ead2f0123"><span offset-key="beb895180c854d3c849ae96ead2f0123:0">3) The Alchemist, Paulo Coelho, 197</span></span>

4

<span key="94d2944f05fa4c91943e073d67e761ea"><span offset-key="94d2944f05fa4c91943e073d67e761ea:0">7) Adultry, Paulo Coelho, 234</span></span>

5

<span key="f546934d6df64faba408cf11edecfe11"><span offset-key="f546934d6df64faba408cf11edecfe11:0">4) The Fellowship of the Ring, J. R. R. Tolkien, 432</span></span>

6

<span key="6cc1f3c732c842c8b84eacdafd67beb2"><span offset-key="6cc1f3c732c842c8b84eacdafd67beb2:0">5) The Pilgrimage, Paulo Coelho, 288</span></span>

7

<span key="f8b3265ca3e041cebacfd03988f37d66"><span offset-key="f8b3265ca3e041cebacfd03988f37d66:0">6) A Game of Thrones, George R. R. Martin, 864</span></span>

<img src="data:image/svg+xml;base64," class="r-h7gdob r-10ptun7 r-1vzi8xi" />

Copied!

<span key="e4be8dcd05b643908724be26a716eda8"><span offset-key="e4be8dcd05b643908724be26a716eda8:0">Note that if there are multiple patterns matching, then the text is appended after each match. The following example illustrates this scenario.</span></span>

1

<span key="8c4648c62eb34cb8af806e51ccbe981e"><span offset-key="8c4648c62eb34cb8af806e51ccbe981e:0">\[jerry\]$ sed '/The/ a 7) Adultry, Paulo Coelho, 234' books.txt</span></span>

<img src="data:image/svg+xml;base64," class="r-h7gdob r-10ptun7 r-1vzi8xi" />

Copied!

<span key="21c9553be3f842afa480427e29080ea3"><span offset-key="21c9553be3f842afa480427e29080ea3:0">On executing the above code, you get the following result:</span></span>

1

<span key="6b6b800c2b1b4d32a58f13854b748813"><span offset-key="6b6b800c2b1b4d32a58f13854b748813:0">1) A Storm of Swords, George R. R. Martin, 1216</span></span>

2

<span key="895da4ac94f34a7690e1e5c27080775c"><span offset-key="895da4ac94f34a7690e1e5c27080775c:0">2) The Two Towers, J. R. R. Tolkien, 352</span></span>

3

<span key="61428784b1cc4d23b187970e3dfaeae9"><span offset-key="61428784b1cc4d23b187970e3dfaeae9:0">7) Adultry, Paulo Coelho, 234</span></span>

4

<span key="37670b1716de4329983358d02b228802"><span offset-key="37670b1716de4329983358d02b228802:0">3) The Alchemist, Paulo Coelho, 197</span></span>

5

<span key="135a12c291e6405f93ca969bdcbba86d"><span offset-key="135a12c291e6405f93ca969bdcbba86d:0">7) Adultry, Paulo Coelho, 234</span></span>

6

<span key="e3516e7d21744c2f9c902db870139d70"><span offset-key="e3516e7d21744c2f9c902db870139d70:0">4) The Fellowship of the Ring, J. R. R. Tolkien, 432</span></span>

7

<span key="c4883e2a650e4298ae1a75768a6c9f49"><span offset-key="c4883e2a650e4298ae1a75768a6c9f49:0">7) Adultry, Paulo Coelho, 234</span></span>

8

<span key="2bb02dfe9c56407da50d1011441b2f59"><span offset-key="2bb02dfe9c56407da50d1011441b2f59:0">5) The Pilgrimage, Paulo Coelho, 288</span></span>

9

<span key="57cf5e258c624d7097bb210981c2bf2c"><span offset-key="57cf5e258c624d7097bb210981c2bf2c:0">7) Adultry, Paulo Coelho, 234</span></span>

10

<span key="9d5f5eae8f26426282b29059b1ab3fee"><span offset-key="9d5f5eae8f26426282b29059b1ab3fee:0">6) A Game of Thrones, George R. R. Martin, 864</span></span>

<img src="data:image/svg+xml;base64," class="r-h7gdob r-10ptun7 r-1vzi8xi" />

Copied!

## 

<span key="415a3c7d4dae4affb1b84093223cf582"><span offset-key="415a3c7d4dae4affb1b84093223cf582:0">Change Command</span></span>

<span key="2bc550f5817942a4a6d37d70fa82fe39"><span offset-key="2bc550f5817942a4a6d37d70fa82fe39:0">SED provides </span>**change**<span offset-key="2bc550f5817942a4a6d37d70fa82fe39:2"> or </span>**replace**<span offset-key="2bc550f5817942a4a6d37d70fa82fe39:4"> command which is represented by c. This command helps replace an existing line with new text. When line range is provided, all the lines are replaced as a group by a single text line. Given below is the syntax of the change command:</span></span>

1

<span key="e84267b2eb8948f68207a8fa5062be65"><span offset-key="e84267b2eb8948f68207a8fa5062be65:0">\[address1\[,address2\]\]c\\</span></span>

2

<span key="a8c2cbb5d1954d52bd6a89a3c3003570"><span offset-key="a8c2cbb5d1954d52bd6a89a3c3003570:0">Replace text</span></span>

<img src="data:image/svg+xml;base64," class="r-h7gdob r-10ptun7 r-1vzi8xi" />

Copied!

<span key="8501bfdf238747778fe45476e2e8b4c0"><span offset-key="8501bfdf238747778fe45476e2e8b4c0:0">Let us replace the third line with some other text.</span></span>

1

<span key="b62f4300345a428f8eb5f81719bfb5f0"><span offset-key="b62f4300345a428f8eb5f81719bfb5f0:0">\[jerry\]$ sed '3 c 3) Adultry, Paulo Coelho, 324' books.txt</span></span>

<img src="data:image/svg+xml;base64," class="r-h7gdob r-10ptun7 r-1vzi8xi" />

Copied!

<span key="b4ecf412a90746aeab55e70af29b4c08"><span offset-key="b4ecf412a90746aeab55e70af29b4c08:0">On executing the above code, you get the following result:</span></span>

1

<span key="d2d632ba6f674c2bb6f5ff689b3c0ef8"><span offset-key="d2d632ba6f674c2bb6f5ff689b3c0ef8:0">1) A Storm of Swords, George R. R. Martin, 1216</span></span>

2

<span key="9e840cfd1e26470c9d5013160665921d"><span offset-key="9e840cfd1e26470c9d5013160665921d:0">2) The Two Towers, J. R. R. Tolkien, 352</span></span>

3

<span key="b1623c3a28eb427e870d0b58502efdf1"><span offset-key="b1623c3a28eb427e870d0b58502efdf1:0">3) Adultry, Paulo Coelho, 324</span></span>

4

<span key="af583897ab784fa5ba2b364b77abe876"><span offset-key="af583897ab784fa5ba2b364b77abe876:0">4) The Fellowship of the Ring, J. R. R. Tolkien, 432</span></span>

5

<span key="db1348f7a8d9445a9ea9043282c71c32"><span offset-key="db1348f7a8d9445a9ea9043282c71c32:0">5) The Pilgrimage, Paulo Coelho, 288</span></span>

6

<span key="b28d5e8b7cd74d9a97a39c7eccc6d990"><span offset-key="b28d5e8b7cd74d9a97a39c7eccc6d990:0">6) A Game of Thrones, George R. R. Martin, 864</span></span>

<img src="data:image/svg+xml;base64," class="r-h7gdob r-10ptun7 r-1vzi8xi" />

Copied!

<span key="26252c6ff49446418be99a18e63c2032"><span offset-key="26252c6ff49446418be99a18e63c2032:0">SED also accepts patterns as an address. In the following example, a line is replaced when the pattern match succeeds.</span></span>

1

<span key="404fdb1b19a342a09627db36b4aaba9c"><span offset-key="404fdb1b19a342a09627db36b4aaba9c:0">\[jerry\]$ sed '/The Alchemist/ c 3) Adultry, Paulo Coelho, 324' books.txt</span></span>

<img src="data:image/svg+xml;base64," class="r-h7gdob r-10ptun7 r-1vzi8xi" />

Copied!

<span key="32e24bc7f4bf4b9a8f64c77a19a7ba48"><span offset-key="32e24bc7f4bf4b9a8f64c77a19a7ba48:0">On executing the above code, you get the following result:</span></span>

1

<span key="579df36d549042709800d585c749924c"><span offset-key="579df36d549042709800d585c749924c:0">1) A Storm of Swords, George R. R. Martin, 1216</span></span>

2

<span key="40d10fdd7d2c44aca2aa2c73fab9b85d"><span offset-key="40d10fdd7d2c44aca2aa2c73fab9b85d:0">2) The Two Towers, J. R. R. Tolkien, 352</span></span>

3

<span key="0453dd77fae547038c18a9057f06d4f3"><span offset-key="0453dd77fae547038c18a9057f06d4f3:0">3) Adultry, Paulo Coelho, 324</span></span>

4

<span key="5379daac3435417b965e43628b79b106"><span offset-key="5379daac3435417b965e43628b79b106:0">4) The Fellowship of the Ring, J. R. R. Tolkien, 432</span></span>

5

<span key="7f77b2ebe8f342beaf728d2e09ed1484"><span offset-key="7f77b2ebe8f342beaf728d2e09ed1484:0">5) The Pilgrimage, Paulo Coelho, 288</span></span>

6

<span key="5c833e0f25534ba397ca084b3f628462"><span offset-key="5c833e0f25534ba397ca084b3f628462:0">6) A Game of Thrones, George R. R. Martin, 864</span></span>

<img src="data:image/svg+xml;base64," class="r-h7gdob r-10ptun7 r-1vzi8xi" />

Copied!

<span key="27ca74e492394d27bb7e6d21e25a7cd5"><span offset-key="27ca74e492394d27bb7e6d21e25a7cd5:0">SED also allows replacement of multiple lines with a single line. The following example removes lines from fourth through sixth and replaces them with new text.</span></span>

1

<span key="b5d88835ac064f9caaeaa1a226d2031f"><span offset-key="b5d88835ac064f9caaeaa1a226d2031f:0">\[jerry\]$ sed '4, 6 c 4) Adultry, Paulo Coelho, 324' books.txt</span></span>

<img src="data:image/svg+xml;base64," class="r-h7gdob r-10ptun7 r-1vzi8xi" />

Copied!

<span key="f818801284044f3192c37de93657665a"><span offset-key="f818801284044f3192c37de93657665a:0">On executing the above code, you get the following result:</span></span>

1

<span key="3c8aefc3841d4d748b7bf96009394b4e"><span offset-key="3c8aefc3841d4d748b7bf96009394b4e:0">1) A Storm of Swords, George R. R. Martin, 1216</span></span>

2

<span key="987fcd8fc315477fb5de30a4cc274e2b"><span offset-key="987fcd8fc315477fb5de30a4cc274e2b:0">2) The Two Towers, J. R. R. Tolkien, 352</span></span>

3

<span key="86afc8ad6211493d8e11251e8d3e372e"><span offset-key="86afc8ad6211493d8e11251e8d3e372e:0">3) The Alchemist, Paulo Coelho, 197</span></span>

4

<span key="942a26457c5d4d28927c42d4d459cdf9"><span offset-key="942a26457c5d4d28927c42d4d459cdf9:0">4) Adultry, Paulo Coelho, 324</span></span>

<img src="data:image/svg+xml;base64," class="r-h7gdob r-10ptun7 r-1vzi8xi" />

Copied!

## 

<span key="aa8f23529e434294a4be9a091ec8e401"><span offset-key="aa8f23529e434294a4be9a091ec8e401:0">Insert Command</span></span>

<span key="15ce289492324a97b6aefb7cb3f0e73c"><span offset-key="15ce289492324a97b6aefb7cb3f0e73c:0">The insert command works much in the same way as append does. The only difference is that it inserts a line before a specific position. Given below is the syntax of the insert command:</span></span>

1

<span key="15f55e169cee496490a94b462ad79869"><span offset-key="15f55e169cee496490a94b462ad79869:0">\[address\]i\\</span></span>

2

<span key="fcff311b041740c8b7ca081730d1ba8b"><span offset-key="fcff311b041740c8b7ca081730d1ba8b:0">Insert text</span></span>

<img src="data:image/svg+xml;base64," class="r-h7gdob r-10ptun7 r-1vzi8xi" />

Copied!

<span key="e6bcdf156dbc4f87b085b01f211d5dca"><span offset-key="e6bcdf156dbc4f87b085b01f211d5dca:0">Let us understand the insert command with some examples. The following command inserts a new entry before the fourth line.</span></span>

1

<span key="6aa76665e3804ebca727ebfa5af47c3b"><span offset-key="6aa76665e3804ebca727ebfa5af47c3b:0">\[jerry\]$ sed '4 i 7) Adultry, Paulo Coelho, 324' books.txt</span></span>

<img src="data:image/svg+xml;base64," class="r-h7gdob r-10ptun7 r-1vzi8xi" />

Copied!

<span key="8cd71026ea7d45ef98b737cbd70e41e9"><span offset-key="8cd71026ea7d45ef98b737cbd70e41e9:0">On executing the above code, you get the following result:</span></span>

1

<span key="7ba6bea8cf5b497fb85df281f9afadf8"><span offset-key="7ba6bea8cf5b497fb85df281f9afadf8:0">1) A Storm of Swords, George R. R. Martin, 1216</span></span>

2

<span key="d87bb4dcfa7f489ba7bbf2362d73013f"><span offset-key="d87bb4dcfa7f489ba7bbf2362d73013f:0">2) The Two Towers, J. R. R. Tolkien, 352</span></span>

3

<span key="0c4e0fbfe02849ce82f344de9c43061c"><span offset-key="0c4e0fbfe02849ce82f344de9c43061c:0">3) The Alchemist, Paulo Coelho, 197</span></span>

4

<span key="9270d1edd3044f38bf69dfdf75845186"><span offset-key="9270d1edd3044f38bf69dfdf75845186:0">7) Adultry, Paulo Coelho, 324</span></span>

5

<span key="f7ff82efce9346888662f6bca131128a"><span offset-key="f7ff82efce9346888662f6bca131128a:0">4) The Fellowship of the Ring, J. R. R. Tolkien, 432</span></span>

6

<span key="42c5c16ede28493aaecb3e7d2e48def8"><span offset-key="42c5c16ede28493aaecb3e7d2e48def8:0">5) The Pilgrimage, Paulo Coelho, 288</span></span>

7

<span key="1172c850a64442f0b0fa31921ad7c2e7"><span offset-key="1172c850a64442f0b0fa31921ad7c2e7:0">6) A Game of Thrones, George R. R. Martin, 864</span></span>

<img src="data:image/svg+xml;base64," class="r-h7gdob r-10ptun7 r-1vzi8xi" />

Copied!

<span key="7eb982d8f57c4258928e40b27e232e3a"><span offset-key="7eb982d8f57c4258928e40b27e232e3a:0">In the above example, </span>**4**<span offset-key="7eb982d8f57c4258928e40b27e232e3a:2"> is the location number, </span>**i**<span offset-key="7eb982d8f57c4258928e40b27e232e3a:4"> implies the insert command, and the remaining part is the text to be inserted.</span></span>

<span key="b37199a67d284c86a7311de49e63ee07"><span offset-key="b37199a67d284c86a7311de49e63ee07:0">To insert text at the start of a file, provide the line address as </span>**1**<span offset-key="b37199a67d284c86a7311de49e63ee07:2">. The following command illustrates this:</span></span>

1

<span key="3ed4acd20c464d6f8bab6ffccd680718"><span offset-key="3ed4acd20c464d6f8bab6ffccd680718:0">\[jerry\]$ sed '1 i 7) Adultry, Paulo Coelho, 324' books.txt</span></span>

<img src="data:image/svg+xml;base64," class="r-h7gdob r-10ptun7 r-1vzi8xi" />

Copied!

<span key="227690f1f0a045028da3de1b6330b61b"><span offset-key="227690f1f0a045028da3de1b6330b61b:0">On executing the above code, you get the following result:</span></span>

1

<span key="cf1870d060f448e4810bdcca31d17086"><span offset-key="cf1870d060f448e4810bdcca31d17086:0">7) Adultry, Paulo Coelho, 324</span></span>

<img src="data:image/svg+xml;base64," class="r-h7gdob r-10ptun7 r-1vzi8xi" />

Copied!

1

<span key="bcaf76333b44415da99dd2530be0b847"><span offset-key="bcaf76333b44415da99dd2530be0b847:0">1) A Storm of Swords, George R. R. Martin, 1216</span></span>

2

<span key="2d6d31cd84744404989ab93a3643227a"><span offset-key="2d6d31cd84744404989ab93a3643227a:0">2) The Two Towers, J. R. R. Tolkien, 352</span></span>

3

<span key="c07c5c3c6801492794d40394517ba4f7"><span offset-key="c07c5c3c6801492794d40394517ba4f7:0">3) The Alchemist, Paulo Coelho, 197</span></span>

4

<span key="c93d14705ffe4c8abee863d9d618cb8f"><span offset-key="c93d14705ffe4c8abee863d9d618cb8f:0">4) The Fellowship of the Ring, J. R. R. Tolkien, 432</span></span>

5

<span key="7419c5f06ceb47489532c7a9483d134f"><span offset-key="7419c5f06ceb47489532c7a9483d134f:0">5) The Pilgrimage, Paulo Coelho, 288</span></span>

6

<span key="66640462e43346d7aa906f375caa40d7"><span offset-key="66640462e43346d7aa906f375caa40d7:0">6) A Game of Thrones, George R. R. Martin, 864</span></span>

<img src="data:image/svg+xml;base64," class="r-h7gdob r-10ptun7 r-1vzi8xi" />

Copied!

<span key="25dfcebd148d42c2ace9fe12ba3bb222"><span offset-key="25dfcebd148d42c2ace9fe12ba3bb222:0">Additionally, we can insert multiple lines. The following command inserts two lines before the last line.</span></span>

1

<span key="ce343f52a048474d8787abf25e44e5ff"><span offset-key="ce343f52a048474d8787abf25e44e5ff:0">\[jerry\]$ sed '$ i 7) Adultry, Paulo Coelho, 324</span></span>

<img src="data:image/svg+xml;base64," class="r-h7gdob r-10ptun7 r-1vzi8xi" />

Copied!

<span key="4459fc73f6814aea8065973a269b0d0a"><span offset-key="4459fc73f6814aea8065973a269b0d0a:0">On executing the above code, you get the following result:</span></span>

1

<span key="1ae7db09218f405b96b3445ac95f84d8"><span offset-key="1ae7db09218f405b96b3445ac95f84d8:0">8) Eleven Minutes, Paulo Coelho, 304' books.txt</span></span>

2

<span key="a7d1fc399bfb4f8baa3bd3f72a90b2d2"><span offset-key="a7d1fc399bfb4f8baa3bd3f72a90b2d2:0">1) A Storm of Swords, George R. R. Martin, 1216</span></span>

3

<span key="c169ebb86d3642b8955fee975136b8ca"><span offset-key="c169ebb86d3642b8955fee975136b8ca:0">2) The Two Towers, J. R. R. Tolkien, 352</span></span>

4

<span key="e0f7411810a24f81a47018b7c6c77d93"><span offset-key="e0f7411810a24f81a47018b7c6c77d93:0">3) The Alchemist, Paulo Coelho, 197</span></span>

5

<span key="fb61c8586dc14486b953da316e7a0718"><span offset-key="fb61c8586dc14486b953da316e7a0718:0">4) The Fellowship of the Ring, J. R. R. Tolkien, 432</span></span>

6

<span key="97b33214643f48d09ef881ce3064f962"><span offset-key="97b33214643f48d09ef881ce3064f962:0">5) The Pilgrimage,Paulo Coelho, 288</span></span>

7

<span key="bde36451402443cf9e621fbecf9448b8"><span offset-key="bde36451402443cf9e621fbecf9448b8:0">7) Adultry, Paulo Coelho, 324</span></span>

8

<span key="d4e7ff109fc5463a86eaa51512c49f9a"><span offset-key="d4e7ff109fc5463a86eaa51512c49f9a:0">8) Eleven Minutes, Paulo Coelho, 304</span></span>

9

<span key="6e33f8b1d14a4b37b30e9394e09efb44"><span offset-key="6e33f8b1d14a4b37b30e9394e09efb44:0">6) A Game of Thrones, George R. R. Martin, 864</span></span>

<img src="data:image/svg+xml;base64," class="r-h7gdob r-10ptun7 r-1vzi8xi" />

Copied!

<span key="90973ccaa8914090a1c2dab159b446a0"><span offset-key="90973ccaa8914090a1c2dab159b446a0:0">Note that the entries to be inserted are entered on separate lines and delimited by the backslash(\\) character.</span></span>

## 

<span key="141acbc1aae649a3ba54eb606121b6d7"><span offset-key="141acbc1aae649a3ba54eb606121b6d7:0">Translate Command</span></span>

<span key="5cbb47aaf2504fb7800f7c716bb9ddf0"><span offset-key="5cbb47aaf2504fb7800f7c716bb9ddf0:0">SED provides a command to translate characters and it is represented as </span>**y**<span offset-key="5cbb47aaf2504fb7800f7c716bb9ddf0:2">. It transforms the characters by position. Given below is the syntax of the translate command:</span></span>

1

<span key="9640658ff4604679b05d7c82a5ae1b9f"><span offset-key="9640658ff4604679b05d7c82a5ae1b9f:0">\[address1\[,address2\]\]y/list-1/list-2/</span></span>

<img src="data:image/svg+xml;base64," class="r-h7gdob r-10ptun7 r-1vzi8xi" />

Copied!

<span key="405cce104e5b44e5a582e3f19213f384"><span offset-key="405cce104e5b44e5a582e3f19213f384:0">Note that translation is based on the position of the character from </span>**list 1**<span offset-key="405cce104e5b44e5a582e3f19213f384:2"> to the character in the same position in </span>**list 2**<span offset-key="405cce104e5b44e5a582e3f19213f384:4"> and both lists must be explicit character lists. Regular expressions and character classes are unsupported. Additionally, the size of </span>**list 1**<span offset-key="405cce104e5b44e5a582e3f19213f384:6"> and </span>**list 2**<span offset-key="405cce104e5b44e5a582e3f19213f384:8"> must be same.</span></span>

<span key="4a7848eb126a4912b95b57404b1c7c19"><span offset-key="4a7848eb126a4912b95b57404b1c7c19:0">The following example converts Arabic numbers to Roman numbers.</span></span>

1

<span key="0047dbba433043ce903b32e8cef91fe1"><span offset-key="0047dbba433043ce903b32e8cef91fe1:0">\[jerry\]$ echo "1 5 15 20" | sed 'y/151520/IVXVXX/'</span></span>

<img src="data:image/svg+xml;base64," class="r-h7gdob r-10ptun7 r-1vzi8xi" />

Copied!

<span key="4a22f503018c4363b75678419195acd1"><span offset-key="4a22f503018c4363b75678419195acd1:0">On executing the above code, you get the following result:</span></span>

1

<span key="0f8e7f8502394dcea9f57b0bd3d7c5e1"><span offset-key="0f8e7f8502394dcea9f57b0bd3d7c5e1:0">I V IV XX</span></span>

<img src="data:image/svg+xml;base64," class="r-h7gdob r-10ptun7 r-1vzi8xi" />

Copied!

## 

<span key="841031f49035417dbb22e5fc4ba049da"><span offset-key="841031f49035417dbb22e5fc4ba049da:0">l command</span></span>

<span key="7ef0a679f4184a9aa6bca40dfc3a0d5a"><span offset-key="7ef0a679f4184a9aa6bca40dfc3a0d5a:0">Can you differentiate between words separated by spaces and words separated by tab characters only by looking at them? Certainly not. But SED can do this for you. SED uses the </span>**l**<span offset-key="7ef0a679f4184a9aa6bca40dfc3a0d5a:2"> command to display hidden characters in the text. For example, tab character with and End-Of-Line with </span>**$**<span offset-key="7ef0a679f4184a9aa6bca40dfc3a0d5a:4"> character. Given below is the syntax of the </span>**l**<span offset-key="7ef0a679f4184a9aa6bca40dfc3a0d5a:6"> command.</span></span>

1

<span key="a3568f4cd7a24575930510a34474d752"><span offset-key="a3568f4cd7a24575930510a34474d752:0">\[address1\[,address2\]\]l</span></span>

2

<span key="da32131999604145a31f66127eff7f6e"><span offset-key="da32131999604145a31f66127eff7f6e:0">\[address1\[,address2\]\]l \[len\]</span></span>

<img src="data:image/svg+xml;base64," class="r-h7gdob r-10ptun7 r-1vzi8xi" />

Copied!

<span key="07eb28dd74b041a0b4a821d878bd4068"><span offset-key="07eb28dd74b041a0b4a821d878bd4068:0">Let us create a file with tab characters for demonstration. For simplicity, we are going to use the same file, just by replacing spaces with tabs. Wait! But how to do that — by opening the file in a text editor and replacing each space with tab? Certainly not! We can make use of SED commands for that.</span></span>

1

<span key="65ac7c1fc9504085bcedc5ab69574ea5"><span offset-key="65ac7c1fc9504085bcedc5ab69574ea5:0">\[jerry\]$ sed 's/ /\\t/g' books.txt &gt; junk.txt</span></span>

<img src="data:image/svg+xml;base64," class="r-h7gdob r-10ptun7 r-1vzi8xi" />

Copied!

<span key="a7a593883b1044a4a5cc62a4597b141d"><span offset-key="a7a593883b1044a4a5cc62a4597b141d:0">Now let us display the hidden characters by using the </span>**l**<span offset-key="a7a593883b1044a4a5cc62a4597b141d:2"> command:</span></span>

1

<span key="aaf73cd02b1b418e8a2d01f832c35631"><span offset-key="aaf73cd02b1b418e8a2d01f832c35631:0">\[jerry\]$ sed -n 'l' junk.txt</span></span>

<img src="data:image/svg+xml;base64," class="r-h7gdob r-10ptun7 r-1vzi8xi" />

Copied!

<span key="1b64de4216464606af3f552c8397e3b7"><span offset-key="1b64de4216464606af3f552c8397e3b7:0">On executing the above code, you get the following result:</span></span>

1

<span key="01edb15c40e64778997af9d7444f1269"><span offset-key="01edb15c40e64778997af9d7444f1269:0">1)\\tA\\tStorm\\tof\\tSwords,George\\tR.\\tR.\\tMartin,1216$</span></span>

2

<span key="29bf8478217341468b14128c82ac1a63"><span offset-key="29bf8478217341468b14128c82ac1a63:0">2)\\tThe\\tTwo\\tTowers,J.\\tR.\\tR.\\tTolkien,352$</span></span>

3

<span key="39948857cafc43689b64d7d7c625ecb8"><span offset-key="39948857cafc43689b64d7d7c625ecb8:0">3)\\tThe\\tAlchemist,Paulo\\tCoelho,197$</span></span>

4

<span key="bff605380f6c4255a990de17d98090b8"><span offset-key="bff605380f6c4255a990de17d98090b8:0">4)\\tThe\\tFellowship\\tof\\tthe\\tRing,J.\\tR.\\tR.\\tTolkien,432$</span></span>

5

<span key="fb1cc7e18e354812ac1c00331bb26340"><span offset-key="fb1cc7e18e354812ac1c00331bb26340:0">5)\\tThe\\tPilgrimage,Paulo\\tCoelho,288$</span></span>

6

<span key="381ba4c18aca473381004ac4703b358c"><span offset-key="381ba4c18aca473381004ac4703b358c:0">6)\\tA\\tGame\\tof\\tThrones,George\\tR.\\tR.\\tMartin\\t,864$</span></span>

<img src="data:image/svg+xml;base64," class="r-h7gdob r-10ptun7 r-1vzi8xi" />

Copied!

<span key="97a864f6e1bb4f69aacd30aec95b16e3"><span offset-key="97a864f6e1bb4f69aacd30aec95b16e3:0">Like other SED commands, it also accepts line numbers and patterns as an address. You can try it yourselves.</span></span>

<span key="5cb666e2bc124181a5f802104070e07f"><span offset-key="5cb666e2bc124181a5f802104070e07f:0">Let us take a close look at another interesting feature of SED. We can instruct the SED to perform line wrapping after a certain number of characters. The following example wraps lines after 25 characters.</span></span>

1

<span key="94871aaa2a9a4b7f92c2263f472b5055"><span offset-key="94871aaa2a9a4b7f92c2263f472b5055:0">\[jerry\]$ sed -n 'l 25' books.txt</span></span>

<img src="data:image/svg+xml;base64," class="r-h7gdob r-10ptun7 r-1vzi8xi" />

Copied!

<span key="9f0b8548b27c4dfa98aa789e50333609"><span offset-key="9f0b8548b27c4dfa98aa789e50333609:0">On executing the above code, you get the following result:</span></span>

1

<span key="b8bfa6bdfd6b488f93017e5897ed8129"><span offset-key="b8bfa6bdfd6b488f93017e5897ed8129:0">1) A Storm of Swords,Geo\\</span></span>

2

<span key="32a83507478c49cda86aae85f80d852c"><span offset-key="32a83507478c49cda86aae85f80d852c:0">rge R. R. Martin,1216$</span></span>

3

<span key="4162109847b0436db22c8bf8826e29bb"><span offset-key="4162109847b0436db22c8bf8826e29bb:0">2) The Two Towers,J. R. \\</span></span>

4

<span key="81b2db516d4549f29f8f4b125f1671f1"><span offset-key="81b2db516d4549f29f8f4b125f1671f1:0">R. Tolkien,352$</span></span>

5

<span key="486f44b91bd648d98d4a6ef1452b15ad"><span offset-key="486f44b91bd648d98d4a6ef1452b15ad:0">3) The Alchemist,Paulo C\\</span></span>

6

<span key="6f09632169fd450e8697c8bb2cf3da5c"><span offset-key="6f09632169fd450e8697c8bb2cf3da5c:0">oelho,197$</span></span>

7

<span key="b5d0a208f8844cdd940ca9612246615f"><span offset-key="b5d0a208f8844cdd940ca9612246615f:0">4) The Fellowship of the\\</span></span>

8

<span key="0e92bcdc44134779b6a06ed4f11f6f50"><span offset-key="0e92bcdc44134779b6a06ed4f11f6f50:0"> Ring,J. R. R. Tolkien,4\\</span></span>

9

<span key="e61e6010c2ae49248b0434b47ca73396"><span offset-key="e61e6010c2ae49248b0434b47ca73396:0">32$</span></span>

10

<span key="5615ea2fc3fc47b1a6eafa813dc5d89e"><span offset-key="5615ea2fc3fc47b1a6eafa813dc5d89e:0">5) The Pilgrimage,Paulo \\</span></span>

11

<span key="8688096a0aae4ca792d5d6fdc68f363e"><span offset-key="8688096a0aae4ca792d5d6fdc68f363e:0">Coelho,288$</span></span>

12

<span key="510e95e0b52f45b7b4dfe69a9fe40627"><span offset-key="510e95e0b52f45b7b4dfe69a9fe40627:0">6) A Game of Thrones,Geo\\</span></span>

13

<span key="58c5f51dea89411685cb1575c1c34286"><span offset-key="58c5f51dea89411685cb1575c1c34286:0">rge R. R. Martin ,864$</span></span>

<img src="data:image/svg+xml;base64," class="r-h7gdob r-10ptun7 r-1vzi8xi" />

Copied!

<span key="44e72f4f9c5f435dbdcdb40280791530"><span offset-key="44e72f4f9c5f435dbdcdb40280791530:0">Note that in the above example, wrap limit is provided after l command. In this case, it is 25 characters. This option is GNU specific and may not work with other variants of the SED.</span></span>

<span key="6fb74bf7546744dd8025d3fd65d45d43"><span offset-key="6fb74bf7546744dd8025d3fd65d45d43:0">A wrap limit of 0 means never break the line unless there is a new line character. The following simple command illustrates this.</span></span>

1

<span key="79a7569081bb4e75b4b6c7c9bdd72e9b"><span offset-key="79a7569081bb4e75b4b6c7c9bdd72e9b:0">\[jerry\]$ sed -n 'l 0' books.txt</span></span>

<img src="data:image/svg+xml;base64," class="r-h7gdob r-10ptun7 r-1vzi8xi" />

Copied!

<span key="1cad889d7fc1437ba4507cc99f9e74bc"><span offset-key="1cad889d7fc1437ba4507cc99f9e74bc:0">On executing the above code, you get the following result:</span></span>

1

<span key="6ea2cd918b7842f0bc0207a06c5ebf98"><span offset-key="6ea2cd918b7842f0bc0207a06c5ebf98:0">1) A Storm of Swords,George R. R. Martin,1216$</span></span>

2

<span key="90f71f274a014df0be916a3156b405f4"><span offset-key="90f71f274a014df0be916a3156b405f4:0">2) The Two Towers,J. R. R. Tolkien,352$</span></span>

3

<span key="32184aa95d574264b93442438367b338"><span offset-key="32184aa95d574264b93442438367b338:0">3) The Alchemist,Paulo Coelho,197$</span></span>

4

<span key="2426550f3d854290b0b0be60eb74a4bb"><span offset-key="2426550f3d854290b0b0be60eb74a4bb:0">4) The Fellowship of the Ring,J. R. R. Tolkien,432$</span></span>

5

<span key="f4d5005e583541b5a80f8ebd762bf461"><span offset-key="f4d5005e583541b5a80f8ebd762bf461:0">5) The Pilgrimage,Paulo Coelho,288$</span></span>

6

<span key="85558df09edf417d8d88c53479caa464"><span offset-key="85558df09edf417d8d88c53479caa464:0">6) A Game of Thrones,George R. R. Martin,864$</span></span>

<img src="data:image/svg+xml;base64," class="r-h7gdob r-10ptun7 r-1vzi8xi" />

Copied!

## 

<span key="b38c427b32c64240b1ea42ca8bd6ad51"><span offset-key="b38c427b32c64240b1ea42ca8bd6ad51:0">Quit Command</span></span>

<span key="2496cd0bf29249118ad1a6bc74e76579"><span offset-key="2496cd0bf29249118ad1a6bc74e76579:0">Quit command instructs the SED to quit the current execution flow. It is represented by the </span>**q**<span offset-key="2496cd0bf29249118ad1a6bc74e76579:2"> command. Given below is the syntax of the quit command:</span></span>

1

<span key="cb978165af0c4cd28b805362cc8b14a6"><span offset-key="cb978165af0c4cd28b805362cc8b14a6:0">\[address\]q</span></span>

2

<span key="46a752709f024774833867cc834c876d"><span offset-key="46a752709f024774833867cc834c876d:0">\[address\]q \[value\]</span></span>

<img src="data:image/svg+xml;base64," class="r-h7gdob r-10ptun7 r-1vzi8xi" />

Copied!

<span key="73dae58aac044f87875e8456ea78dd47"><span offset-key="73dae58aac044f87875e8456ea78dd47:0">Note that the quit command does not accept range of addresses, it only supports a single address. By default, SED follows read, execute, and repeat workflow; but when the quit command is encountered, it simply stops the current execution.</span></span>

<span key="505267044ec84a589eea4e14d94979b8"><span offset-key="505267044ec84a589eea4e14d94979b8:0">Let us print the first 3 lines from the file.</span></span>

1

<span key="3dd7bfaf6ecf482ea320b083c8ddaf67"><span offset-key="3dd7bfaf6ecf482ea320b083c8ddaf67:0">\[jerry\]$ sed '3 q' books.txt</span></span>

<img src="data:image/svg+xml;base64," class="r-h7gdob r-10ptun7 r-1vzi8xi" />

Copied!

<span key="a85f0dfd43244131a157740843579bb8"><span offset-key="a85f0dfd43244131a157740843579bb8:0">On executing the above code, you get the following result:</span></span>

1

<span key="b39a6a4f8c8446fda9909965376ab79e"><span offset-key="b39a6a4f8c8446fda9909965376ab79e:0">1) A Storm of Swords, George R. R. Martin, 1216</span></span>

2

<span key="4901b33b720c4b949723ca8087c11223"><span offset-key="4901b33b720c4b949723ca8087c11223:0">2) The Two Towers, J. R. R. Tolkien, 352</span></span>

3

<span key="968226c4d42b4099b500b4fe4608a141"><span offset-key="968226c4d42b4099b500b4fe4608a141:0">3) The Alchemist, Paulo Coelho, 197</span></span>

<img src="data:image/svg+xml;base64," class="r-h7gdob r-10ptun7 r-1vzi8xi" />

Copied!

<span key="6ead3e67a49244b88d025d1848525fbb"><span offset-key="6ead3e67a49244b88d025d1848525fbb:0">In addition to line number, we can also use textual patterns. The following command quits when pattern match succeeds.</span></span>

1

<span key="0ebeaafc36f24d6da4c2a20ca2dc2b9a"><span offset-key="0ebeaafc36f24d6da4c2a20ca2dc2b9a:0">\[jerry\]$ sed '/The Alchemist/ q' books.txt</span></span>

<img src="data:image/svg+xml;base64," class="r-h7gdob r-10ptun7 r-1vzi8xi" />

Copied!

<span key="c52d11c078db4353af61370970c410d2"><span offset-key="c52d11c078db4353af61370970c410d2:0">On executing the above code, you get the following result:</span></span>

1

<span key="1fc252c37ec943c09b53f13e619fc919"><span offset-key="1fc252c37ec943c09b53f13e619fc919:0">1) A Storm of Swords, George R. R. Martin, 1216</span></span>

2

<span key="c44175901a174fbaa6e9e84f32da7d9e"><span offset-key="c44175901a174fbaa6e9e84f32da7d9e:0">2) The Two Towers, J. R. R. Tolkien, 352</span></span>

3

<span key="83af46004b334faf963c21e7d79843df"><span offset-key="83af46004b334faf963c21e7d79843df:0">3) The Alchemist, Paulo Coelho, 197</span></span>

<img src="data:image/svg+xml;base64," class="r-h7gdob r-10ptun7 r-1vzi8xi" />

Copied!

<span key="d5073c3e5b984c7bbf9347e319153bcf"><span offset-key="d5073c3e5b984c7bbf9347e319153bcf:0">In addition to this, SED can also accept a </span>**value**<span offset-key="d5073c3e5b984c7bbf9347e319153bcf:2"> which can be used as the exit status. The following command shows its exit status as 100.</span></span>

1

<span key="6b61886480084885ae8730dc40acf5ab"><span offset-key="6b61886480084885ae8730dc40acf5ab:0">\[jerry\]$ sed '/The Alchemist/ q 100' books.txt</span></span>

<img src="data:image/svg+xml;base64," class="r-h7gdob r-10ptun7 r-1vzi8xi" />

Copied!

<span key="caa464d1ae2849e998f4b23aaa4d531a"><span offset-key="caa464d1ae2849e998f4b23aaa4d531a:0">On executing the above code, you get the following result:</span></span>

1

<span key="62ba9644363e40e48685875524186854"><span offset-key="62ba9644363e40e48685875524186854:0">1) A Storm of Swords, George R. R. Martin, 1216</span></span>

2

<span key="85225723af0747b1b2cf75ee77e5c0c0"><span offset-key="85225723af0747b1b2cf75ee77e5c0c0:0">2) The Two Towers, J. R. R. Tolkien, 352</span></span>

3

<span key="22778d9a3d0d4b0f87b7a87e28dd9ef1"><span offset-key="22778d9a3d0d4b0f87b7a87e28dd9ef1:0">3) The Alchemist, Paulo Coelho, 197</span></span>

<img src="data:image/svg+xml;base64," class="r-h7gdob r-10ptun7 r-1vzi8xi" />

Copied!

<span key="d0d9cb47403a4d708d834d8640bef2d3"><span offset-key="d0d9cb47403a4d708d834d8640bef2d3:0">Now let us verify the exit status.</span></span>

1

<span key="e8164e0651724fa28035cdd649152e79"><span offset-key="e8164e0651724fa28035cdd649152e79:0">\[jerry\]$ echo $?</span></span>

<img src="data:image/svg+xml;base64," class="r-h7gdob r-10ptun7 r-1vzi8xi" />

Copied!

<span key="b57f734b04f84cfc8e287bac44e75758"><span offset-key="b57f734b04f84cfc8e287bac44e75758:0">On executing the above code, you get the following result:</span></span>

1

<span key="700f26810f7649cea5cb066227b9af8f"><span offset-key="700f26810f7649cea5cb066227b9af8f:0">100</span></span>

<img src="data:image/svg+xml;base64," class="r-h7gdob r-10ptun7 r-1vzi8xi" />

Copied!

## 

<span key="baaf069144834c04aa259174d62b3e58"><span offset-key="baaf069144834c04aa259174d62b3e58:0">Read Command</span></span>

<span key="43be8f23a25247718e569ba9a963b3d9"><span offset-key="43be8f23a25247718e569ba9a963b3d9:0">We can instruct the SED to read the contents of a file and display them when a specific condition matches. The command is represented by the alphabet </span>**r**<span offset-key="43be8f23a25247718e569ba9a963b3d9:2">. Given below is the syntax of the read command.</span></span>

1

<span key="6914f2e11e29424883e5668b8a906ada"><span offset-key="6914f2e11e29424883e5668b8a906ada:0">\[address\]r file</span></span>

<img src="data:image/svg+xml;base64," class="r-h7gdob r-10ptun7 r-1vzi8xi" />

Copied!

<span key="f9ef7920901245ff81d71c2ee74ff84e"><span offset-key="f9ef7920901245ff81d71c2ee74ff84e:0">Note that there must be exactly one space between the </span>**r**<span offset-key="f9ef7920901245ff81d71c2ee74ff84e:2"> command and the file name.</span></span>

<span key="6784cd362b9b4d3f8ff863b0f8f9c4ca"><span offset-key="6784cd362b9b4d3f8ff863b0f8f9c4ca:0">Let us understand it with a simple example. Create a sample file called </span>**junk.txt**<span offset-key="6784cd362b9b4d3f8ff863b0f8f9c4ca:2">.</span></span>

1

<span key="c7486facf7854539b7eecee031183101"><span offset-key="c7486facf7854539b7eecee031183101:0">\[jerry\]$ echo "This is junk text." &gt; junk.txt</span></span>

<img src="data:image/svg+xml;base64," class="r-h7gdob r-10ptun7 r-1vzi8xi" />

Copied!

<span key="df1bd30fe71341f3a0a409393b3577bd"><span offset-key="df1bd30fe71341f3a0a409393b3577bd:0">The following command instructs the SED to read the contents of </span>**junk.txt**<span offset-key="df1bd30fe71341f3a0a409393b3577bd:2"> and insert them after the third line.</span></span>

1

<span key="d2f3b4954ce644e9be635e30ba49cec8"><span offset-key="d2f3b4954ce644e9be635e30ba49cec8:0">\[jerry\]$ sed '3 r junk.txt' books.txt</span></span>

<img src="data:image/svg+xml;base64," class="r-h7gdob r-10ptun7 r-1vzi8xi" />

Copied!

<span key="607d696113274daf8595f40ced524943"><span offset-key="607d696113274daf8595f40ced524943:0">On executing the above code, you get the following result:</span></span>

1

<span key="50f20116a439400c97eff30fdb8fad21"><span offset-key="50f20116a439400c97eff30fdb8fad21:0">1) A Storm of Swords, George R. R. Martin, 1216</span></span>

2

<span key="9d7bc7df5cc843ddabc52a9e1f50699d"><span offset-key="9d7bc7df5cc843ddabc52a9e1f50699d:0">2) The Two Towers, J. R. R. Tolkien, 352</span></span>

3

<span key="26ba7fa739dc4100801acfcbc1cd6e16"><span offset-key="26ba7fa739dc4100801acfcbc1cd6e16:0">3) The Alchemist, Paulo Coelho, 197</span></span>

4

<span key="d4fa3b64ce91480491d3632949e0f19a"><span offset-key="d4fa3b64ce91480491d3632949e0f19a:0">This is junk text.</span></span>

5

<span key="08890eca88d84690916e7b7dce563280"><span offset-key="08890eca88d84690916e7b7dce563280:0">4) The Fellowship of the Ring, J. R. R. Tolkien, 432</span></span>

6

<span key="5a86d32c4abd488cbd88cdd1d623dd68"><span offset-key="5a86d32c4abd488cbd88cdd1d623dd68:0">5) The Pilgrimage, Paulo Coelho, 288</span></span>

7

<span key="a15561378a734d37b327913583ce1092"><span offset-key="a15561378a734d37b327913583ce1092:0">6) A Game of Thrones, George R. R. Martin, 864</span></span>

<img src="data:image/svg+xml;base64," class="r-h7gdob r-10ptun7 r-1vzi8xi" />

Copied!

<span key="c8324eebc8e345bda3bcd0b5dc186160"><span offset-key="c8324eebc8e345bda3bcd0b5dc186160:0">In the above example, 3 implies the line address, </span>**r**<span offset-key="c8324eebc8e345bda3bcd0b5dc186160:2"> is the command name, and </span>**junk.txt**<span offset-key="c8324eebc8e345bda3bcd0b5dc186160:4"> is the file name the contents of which are to be displayed. Additionally, the GNU SED also accepts a range of addresses. For instance, the following command inserts the contents of </span>**junk.txt**<span offset-key="c8324eebc8e345bda3bcd0b5dc186160:6"> after the third, fourth, and fifth lines.</span></span>

1

<span key="f5d138b32b5f4d6d88ce68d6c7d9e0d9"><span offset-key="f5d138b32b5f4d6d88ce68d6c7d9e0d9:0">\[jerry\]$ sed '3, 5 r junk.txt' books.txt</span></span>

<img src="data:image/svg+xml;base64," class="r-h7gdob r-10ptun7 r-1vzi8xi" />

Copied!

<span key="a1fcd6ab4ff640cfac798826a8436ba7"><span offset-key="a1fcd6ab4ff640cfac798826a8436ba7:0">On executing the above code, you get the following result:</span></span>

1

<span key="ec034a18f00845dd9a2892a3d920066f"><span offset-key="ec034a18f00845dd9a2892a3d920066f:0">1) A Storm of Swords, George R. R. Martin, 1216</span></span>

2

<span key="73e0e89777fe408382cc8d35e263c4d2"><span offset-key="73e0e89777fe408382cc8d35e263c4d2:0">2) The Two Towers, J. R. R. Tolkien, 352</span></span>

3

<span key="c6b25f732e2c4c56a1fdd16b6a1d56f8"><span offset-key="c6b25f732e2c4c56a1fdd16b6a1d56f8:0">3) The Alchemist, Paulo Coelho, 197</span></span>

4

<span key="57133a2241594d429f94f5958019c454"><span offset-key="57133a2241594d429f94f5958019c454:0">This is junk text.</span></span>

5

<span key="7fb3cbc689a64525baab8ff1d5332662"><span offset-key="7fb3cbc689a64525baab8ff1d5332662:0">4) The Fellowship of the Ring, J. R. R. Tolkien, 432</span></span>

6

<span key="c77d426aea614a4bb7b30edf691785f3"><span offset-key="c77d426aea614a4bb7b30edf691785f3:0">This is junk text.</span></span>

7

<span key="baefac4fdc974a709908e7675f370f87"><span offset-key="baefac4fdc974a709908e7675f370f87:0">5) The Pilgrimage, Paulo Coelho, 288</span></span>

8

<span key="aa0d33f9c38243e3b38e8ba0aebd7581"><span offset-key="aa0d33f9c38243e3b38e8ba0aebd7581:0">This is junk text.</span></span>

9

<span key="abf5099db36b4655b49c864acc06622f"><span offset-key="abf5099db36b4655b49c864acc06622f:0">6) A Game of Thrones, George R. R. Martin, 864</span></span>

<img src="data:image/svg+xml;base64," class="r-h7gdob r-10ptun7 r-1vzi8xi" />

Copied!

<span key="1f44823a33dd48338af07bfe243fa86d"><span offset-key="1f44823a33dd48338af07bfe243fa86d:0">Like other SED commands, the read command also accepts pattern as an address. For instance, the following command inserts the contents of </span>**junk.txt**<span offset-key="1f44823a33dd48338af07bfe243fa86d:2"> when the pattern match succeeds.</span></span>

1

<span key="823c3c523f934f4e84eb273689648411"><span offset-key="823c3c523f934f4e84eb273689648411:0">\[jerry\]$ sed '/Paulo/ r junk.txt' books.txt</span></span>

<img src="data:image/svg+xml;base64," class="r-h7gdob r-10ptun7 r-1vzi8xi" />

Copied!

<span key="4e972333388344f0815cf115943298b9"><span offset-key="4e972333388344f0815cf115943298b9:0">On executing the above code, you get the following result:</span></span>

1

<span key="5e1b2d833f2b43be884959aa05214b9f"><span offset-key="5e1b2d833f2b43be884959aa05214b9f:0">1) A Storm of Swords, George R. R. Martin, 1216</span></span>

2

<span key="a30f8180c53147168f59c45c99026061"><span offset-key="a30f8180c53147168f59c45c99026061:0">2) The Two Towers, J. R. R. Tolkien, 352</span></span>

3

<span key="7a1bfbd0bf624df38f13a12687f285d2"><span offset-key="7a1bfbd0bf624df38f13a12687f285d2:0">3) The Alchemist, Paulo Coelho, 197</span></span>

4

<span key="f3db03e244534db9b26698ac7240b7c3"><span offset-key="f3db03e244534db9b26698ac7240b7c3:0">This is junk text.</span></span>

5

<span key="066234c668a04c0bb916a66e48b553ea"><span offset-key="066234c668a04c0bb916a66e48b553ea:0">4) The Fellowship of the Ring, J. R. R. Tolkien, 432</span></span>

6

<span key="1414fb9642904b66a2839e4a4576d8a0"><span offset-key="1414fb9642904b66a2839e4a4576d8a0:0">5) The Pilgrimage, Paulo Coelho, 288</span></span>

7

<span key="888f8a16ae72494e9c0f3797abeea693"><span offset-key="888f8a16ae72494e9c0f3797abeea693:0">This is junk text.</span></span>

8

<span key="edcd5db36eb843e0b82622890dfe2cfc"><span offset-key="edcd5db36eb843e0b82622890dfe2cfc:0">6) A Game of Thrones, George R. R. Martin, 864</span></span>
