## 

<span key="93d7b982b7b04f8a8f5b33d66698c339"><span offset-key="93d7b982b7b04f8a8f5b33d66698c339:0">Execute Command</span></span>

<span key="7f221cb446e543f8b7cdd58b5b87ae97"><span offset-key="7f221cb446e543f8b7cdd58b5b87ae97:0">We can execute external commands from SED using the </span>**execute**<span offset-key="7f221cb446e543f8b7cdd58b5b87ae97:2"> command. It is represented by </span>**e**<span offset-key="7f221cb446e543f8b7cdd58b5b87ae97:4">. Given below is the syntax of the execute command.</span></span>

1

<span key="a156939228f046828ee2716e66c22831"><span offset-key="a156939228f046828ee2716e66c22831:0">\[address1\[,address2\]\]e \[command\]</span></span>

<img src="data:image/svg+xml;base64," class="r-h7gdob r-10ptun7 r-1vzi8xi" />

Copied!

<span key="ceece483a4d64c3aa1eba17b1b516f3d"><span offset-key="ceece483a4d64c3aa1eba17b1b516f3d:0">Let us illustrate the execute command with a simple example. The following SED command executes the UNIX </span>**date**<span offset-key="ceece483a4d64c3aa1eba17b1b516f3d:2"> command before the third line.</span></span>

1

<span key="466a911c8eea42279f40f5cd9a555acf"><span offset-key="466a911c8eea42279f40f5cd9a555acf:0">\[jerry\]$ sed '3 e date' books.txt</span></span>

<img src="data:image/svg+xml;base64," class="r-h7gdob r-10ptun7 r-1vzi8xi" />

Copied!

<span key="a05ec16d86024f918572d2941e911630"><span offset-key="a05ec16d86024f918572d2941e911630:0">On executing the above code, you get the following result:</span></span>

1

<span key="70f5da9a15db4b01b75aaca9a0c9546e"><span offset-key="70f5da9a15db4b01b75aaca9a0c9546e:0">1) A Storm of Swords, George R. R. Martin, 1216</span></span>

2

<span key="0ecdfa303eb8429b88f55f1558bbc9e9"><span offset-key="0ecdfa303eb8429b88f55f1558bbc9e9:0">2) The Two Towers, J. R. R. Tolkien, 352</span></span>

3

<span key="9336dc7ae2a54364a383ac7b80417699"><span offset-key="9336dc7ae2a54364a383ac7b80417699:0">Sun Sep 7 18:04:49 IST 2014</span></span>

4

<span key="85a2f256210f4e4da55d0fe067307b27"><span offset-key="85a2f256210f4e4da55d0fe067307b27:0">3) The Alchemist, Paulo Coelho, 197</span></span>

5

<span key="0bfb11a76a9d477fbbabc0de7341a7fb"><span offset-key="0bfb11a76a9d477fbbabc0de7341a7fb:0">4) The Fellowship of the Ring, J. R. R. Tolkien, 432</span></span>

6

<span key="a464a19e382045e2af562a44a5fa82d8"><span offset-key="a464a19e382045e2af562a44a5fa82d8:0">5) The Pilgrimage, Paulo Coelho, 288</span></span>

7

<span key="f2871253727e4acea82e5da3b70640d2"><span offset-key="f2871253727e4acea82e5da3b70640d2:0">6) A Game of Thrones, George R. R. Martin, 864</span></span>

<img src="data:image/svg+xml;base64," class="r-h7gdob r-10ptun7 r-1vzi8xi" />

Copied!

<span key="2f5e48f961c0400fba6510eec183c4f6"><span offset-key="2f5e48f961c0400fba6510eec183c4f6:0">Like other commands, it also accepts patterns as an address. For example, the following example executes </span>**date**<span offset-key="2f5e48f961c0400fba6510eec183c4f6:2"> command when a pattern match succeeds. Note that after each pattern match, first the command is executed and then the contents of the pattern buffer are displayed.</span></span>

1

<span key="a9c5fac7c4924598b215110b66353251"><span offset-key="a9c5fac7c4924598b215110b66353251:0">\[jerry\]$ sed '/Paulo/ e date' books.txt</span></span>

<img src="data:image/svg+xml;base64," class="r-h7gdob r-10ptun7 r-1vzi8xi" />

Copied!

<span key="f9e10e4f236842789955a920db2f25d2"><span offset-key="f9e10e4f236842789955a920db2f25d2:0">On executing the above code, you get the following result:</span></span>

1

<span key="4b2e4bab810b40498c583c9e17d493bc"><span offset-key="4b2e4bab810b40498c583c9e17d493bc:0">1) A Storm of Swords, George R. R. Martin, 1216</span></span>

2

<span key="92dade51a8d84d008a7a354c1ed1909e"><span offset-key="92dade51a8d84d008a7a354c1ed1909e:0">2) The Two Towers, J. R. R. Tolkien, 352</span></span>

3

<span key="5760f36a19584f6e87c2b0ed76f61ac1"><span offset-key="5760f36a19584f6e87c2b0ed76f61ac1:0">Sun Sep 7 18:06:04 IST 2014</span></span>

4

<span key="ba173a45f49d47c4947e5c6f908b727c"><span offset-key="ba173a45f49d47c4947e5c6f908b727c:0">3) The Alchemist, Paulo Coelho, 197</span></span>

5

<span key="6947e0e528ac4353a8895950e655cc8e"><span offset-key="6947e0e528ac4353a8895950e655cc8e:0">4) The Fellowship of the Ring, J. R. R. Tolkien, 432</span></span>

6

<span key="43b4ff7d56e641239d3fd1fe0aa628ad"><span offset-key="43b4ff7d56e641239d3fd1fe0aa628ad:0">Sun Sep 7 18:06:04 IST 2014</span></span>

7

<span key="181240fc80c543569d0e0bbbd5edd311"><span offset-key="181240fc80c543569d0e0bbbd5edd311:0">5) The Pilgrimage, Paulo Coelho, 288</span></span>

8

<span key="178f893c8b204bc4a6c798e519ffd8b6"><span offset-key="178f893c8b204bc4a6c798e519ffd8b6:0">6) A Game of Thrones, George R. R. Martin, 864</span></span>

<img src="data:image/svg+xml;base64," class="r-h7gdob r-10ptun7 r-1vzi8xi" />

Copied!

<span key="9a0c8dc79b9a439d9f28b0f80ea41938"><span offset-key="9a0c8dc79b9a439d9f28b0f80ea41938:0">If you observe the syntax of the </span>**e**<span offset-key="9a0c8dc79b9a439d9f28b0f80ea41938:2"> command carefully, you will notice that </span>**command**<span offset-key="9a0c8dc79b9a439d9f28b0f80ea41938:4"> is optional. When no command is provided after </span>**e,**<span offset-key="9a0c8dc79b9a439d9f28b0f80ea41938:6"> it treats the contents of the pattern buffer as an external command. To illustrate this, let us create a commands.txt file with a few simple commands.</span></span>

1

<span key="65a47a212b5d4c5189e78215f0a685aa"><span offset-key="65a47a212b5d4c5189e78215f0a685aa:0">\[jerry\]$ echo -e "date\\ncal\\nuname" &gt; commands.txt</span></span>

2

<span key="66dd6dc969e94065919b6f9726a5e34f"><span offset-key="66dd6dc969e94065919b6f9726a5e34f:0">\[jerry\]$ cat commands.txt</span></span>

<img src="data:image/svg+xml;base64," class="r-h7gdob r-10ptun7 r-1vzi8xi" />

Copied!

<span key="aecbe808a9344286920dc4bccde0ef79"><span offset-key="aecbe808a9344286920dc4bccde0ef79:0">On executing the above code, you get the following result:</span></span>

1

<span key="f961cc785add49e89390b195c3aacedc"><span offset-key="f961cc785add49e89390b195c3aacedc:0">date</span></span>

2

<span key="b0772d7d57f948b9971d4c4d55988a8d"><span offset-key="b0772d7d57f948b9971d4c4d55988a8d:0">cal</span></span>

3

<span key="bbdf0f0d12104489919b11733fc435ec"><span offset-key="bbdf0f0d12104489919b11733fc435ec:0">uname</span></span>

<img src="data:image/svg+xml;base64," class="r-h7gdob r-10ptun7 r-1vzi8xi" />

Copied!

<span key="2acb904812c24ca59a463878a8b83361"><span offset-key="2acb904812c24ca59a463878a8b83361:0">Commands from the file are self-explanatory. In the absence of </span>**command**<span offset-key="2acb904812c24ca59a463878a8b83361:2"> after </span>**e,**<span offset-key="2acb904812c24ca59a463878a8b83361:4"> SED executes all these commands one by one. The following simple example illustrates this.</span></span>

1

<span key="4d31fecb8acb437a90dd7711d4024d16"><span offset-key="4d31fecb8acb437a90dd7711d4024d16:0">\[jerry\]$ sed 'e' commands.txt</span></span>

<img src="data:image/svg+xml;base64," class="r-h7gdob r-10ptun7 r-1vzi8xi" />

Copied!

<span key="376fca94ecd3461d905bccba08dc2e96"><span offset-key="376fca94ecd3461d905bccba08dc2e96:0">On executing the above code, you get the following result:</span></span>

1

<span key="1334399a01b44da99590ce430a09c026"><span offset-key="1334399a01b44da99590ce430a09c026:0">Sun Sep 7 18:14:20 IST 2014</span></span>

2

<span key="e9bc33c3266b46088fdec7a9553013d2"><span offset-key="e9bc33c3266b46088fdec7a9553013d2:0"> September 2014</span></span>

3

<span key="dd95ef8054ce46b985f60311bdce6023"><span offset-key="dd95ef8054ce46b985f60311bdce6023:0">Su Mo Tu We Th Fr Sa</span></span>

4

<span key="11cb010e55f34cb08f32cfa58ed3e09c"><span offset-key="11cb010e55f34cb08f32cfa58ed3e09c:0"> 1 2 3 4 5 6</span></span>

5

<span key="aeb93de67a254845a825b19dd480c1fe"><span offset-key="aeb93de67a254845a825b19dd480c1fe:0"> 7 8 9 10 11 12 13</span></span>

6

<span key="f86e90c2885e488d864af064dbc878ae"><span offset-key="f86e90c2885e488d864af064dbc878ae:0">14 15 16 17 18 19 20</span></span>

7

<span key="a83ced2e75b24873b2d1726835f027a0"><span offset-key="a83ced2e75b24873b2d1726835f027a0:0">21 22 23 24 25 26 27</span></span>

8

<span key="ee02c2dd6f33459485e9759f985033c8"><span offset-key="ee02c2dd6f33459485e9759f985033c8:0">28 29 30</span></span>

9

<span key="e875c11a521046c8878dc7f805fb5725"><span offset-key="e875c11a521046c8878dc7f805fb5725:0"><span slate-zero-width="n">​</span></span></span>

10

<span key="fd8791ffae4c487db74ea2e2738cf4bc"><span offset-key="fd8791ffae4c487db74ea2e2738cf4bc:0">Linux</span></span>

<img src="data:image/svg+xml;base64," class="r-h7gdob r-10ptun7 r-1vzi8xi" />

Copied!

<span key="c0c80c1404ac4c4c914ab4d0eb5149e4"><span offset-key="c0c80c1404ac4c4c914ab4d0eb5149e4:0">Like other SED commands, the execute command also accepts all valid ranges of addresses.</span></span>

## 

<span key="f1eb6a5be4124ca99005907125f7e1b3"><span offset-key="f1eb6a5be4124ca99005907125f7e1b3:0">Miscellaneous Commands</span></span>

<span key="43791b9b34b74d9e87f7565fef0d546b"><span offset-key="43791b9b34b74d9e87f7565fef0d546b:0">By default, SED operates on single line, however it can operate on multiple lines as well. Multi-line commands are denoted by uppercase letters. For example, unlike the </span>**n**<span offset-key="43791b9b34b74d9e87f7565fef0d546b:2"> command, the </span>**N**<span offset-key="43791b9b34b74d9e87f7565fef0d546b:4"> command does not clear and print the pattern space. Instead, it adds a newline (\\n) at the end of the current pattern space and appends the next line from the input-file to the current pattern space and continues with the SED's standard flow by executing the rest of the SED commands. Given below is the syntax of the </span>**N**<span offset-key="43791b9b34b74d9e87f7565fef0d546b:6"> command.</span></span>

1

<span key="803633ca8ebb44e2932b5783c0c9a272"><span offset-key="803633ca8ebb44e2932b5783c0c9a272:0">\[address1\[,address2\]\]N</span></span>

<img src="data:image/svg+xml;base64," class="r-h7gdob r-10ptun7 r-1vzi8xi" />

Copied!

<span key="25a9b6ad984443dfbf9243b566014882"><span offset-key="25a9b6ad984443dfbf9243b566014882:0">Let us print a comma-separated list of book titles and their respective authors. The following example illustrates this.</span></span>

1

<span key="d2981308968c489d8da96e3b7eb38d73"><span offset-key="d2981308968c489d8da96e3b7eb38d73:0">\[jerry\]$ sed 'N; s/\\n/, /g' books.txt</span></span>

<img src="data:image/svg+xml;base64," class="r-h7gdob r-10ptun7 r-1vzi8xi" />

Copied!

<span key="cf10a5fce3a9446a9a6a9d33d829c9cd"><span offset-key="cf10a5fce3a9446a9a6a9d33d829c9cd:0">On executing the above code, you get the following result:</span></span>

1

<span key="3d4f31b8a61744d6832323bc31877c62"><span offset-key="3d4f31b8a61744d6832323bc31877c62:0">A Storm of Swords, George R. R. Martin</span></span>

2

<span key="cda60b9fbef0469690cf7296562e6be7"><span offset-key="cda60b9fbef0469690cf7296562e6be7:0">The Two Towers, J. R. R. Tolkien</span></span>

3

<span key="e31f5b6751d0402087fe3a7fd4c2f6a1"><span offset-key="e31f5b6751d0402087fe3a7fd4c2f6a1:0">The Alchemist, Paulo Coelho</span></span>

4

<span key="cb880d25c6ae4da3bd453e4573a537a0"><span offset-key="cb880d25c6ae4da3bd453e4573a537a0:0">The Fellowship of the Ring, J. R. R. Tolkien</span></span>

5

<span key="f82232a0c5c844ce805f544cdc102d8a"><span offset-key="f82232a0c5c844ce805f544cdc102d8a:0">The Pilgrimage, Paulo Coelho</span></span>

6

<span key="71354646fc26447fadb42dc9744f473b"><span offset-key="71354646fc26447fadb42dc9744f473b:0">A Game of Thrones, George R. R. Martin</span></span>

<img src="data:image/svg+xml;base64," class="r-h7gdob r-10ptun7 r-1vzi8xi" />

Copied!

<span key="a1c56234507743049b854aa2e59f312f"><span offset-key="a1c56234507743049b854aa2e59f312f:0">Let us understand how the above example works. The </span>**N**<span offset-key="a1c56234507743049b854aa2e59f312f:2"> command reads the first line, i.e.,A Storm of Swords into the pattern buffer and appends \\n followed by the next line. The pattern space now contains A Storm of Swords\*\*\\n\*\*George R. R. Martin. In the next step, we are replacing the newline with a comma.</span></span>

<span key="f04adb6a8c5b4b21a07e7e4da282744b"><span offset-key="f04adb6a8c5b4b21a07e7e4da282744b:0">Like </span>**p**<span offset-key="f04adb6a8c5b4b21a07e7e4da282744b:2"> command, we have a </span>**P**<span offset-key="f04adb6a8c5b4b21a07e7e4da282744b:4"> command to print the first part (up to embedded newline) of the multi-line pattern space created by the </span>**N**<span offset-key="f04adb6a8c5b4b21a07e7e4da282744b:6"> command. Given below is the syntax of the </span>**P**<span offset-key="f04adb6a8c5b4b21a07e7e4da282744b:8"> command which is similar to the </span>**p**<span offset-key="f04adb6a8c5b4b21a07e7e4da282744b:10"> command.</span></span>

1

<span key="40534832092d4db3a97647509ff702fa"><span offset-key="40534832092d4db3a97647509ff702fa:0">\[address1\[,address2\]\]P</span></span>

<img src="data:image/svg+xml;base64," class="r-h7gdob r-10ptun7 r-1vzi8xi" />

Copied!

<span key="fcafb9803a86468cae8e0ba35c7e5077"><span offset-key="fcafb9803a86468cae8e0ba35c7e5077:0">In the previous example, we saw that the </span>**N**<span offset-key="fcafb9803a86468cae8e0ba35c7e5077:2"> command creates a newline- separated list of book titles and their authors. Let us print only the first part of it, i.e., only the titles of the book. The following command illustrates this.</span></span>

1

<span key="5e03bd09174147b9b856a47a4e80a18e"><span offset-key="5e03bd09174147b9b856a47a4e80a18e:0">\[jerry\]$ sed -n 'N;P' books.txt</span></span>

<img src="data:image/svg+xml;base64," class="r-h7gdob r-10ptun7 r-1vzi8xi" />

Copied!

<span key="579e97976cfc48db913dd9226403a97b"><span offset-key="579e97976cfc48db913dd9226403a97b:0">On executing the above code, you get the following result:</span></span>

1

<span key="d5bacc66171447bda65f005422e2d54a"><span offset-key="d5bacc66171447bda65f005422e2d54a:0">A Storm of Swords</span></span>

2

<span key="7243140c09e74441be07e97612b2d832"><span offset-key="7243140c09e74441be07e97612b2d832:0">The Two Towers</span></span>

3

<span key="575c7419f37644e996fda48dc54a38fa"><span offset-key="575c7419f37644e996fda48dc54a38fa:0">The Alchemist</span></span>

4

<span key="7f5e454d7eb74bf7a3ffa1f7dabcdd60"><span offset-key="7f5e454d7eb74bf7a3ffa1f7dabcdd60:0">The Fellowship of the Ring</span></span>

5

<span key="552c7ab8665246ad8c29c97eed2c5b55"><span offset-key="552c7ab8665246ad8c29c97eed2c5b55:0">The Pilgrimage</span></span>

6

<span key="7763a055771e46eaab7af04a606d63b1"><span offset-key="7763a055771e46eaab7af04a606d63b1:0">A Game of Thrones</span></span>

<img src="data:image/svg+xml;base64," class="r-h7gdob r-10ptun7 r-1vzi8xi" />

Copied!

<span key="a654f90b9ec447c2b4a1b807d0fb6089"><span offset-key="a654f90b9ec447c2b4a1b807d0fb6089:0">Note that in the absence of </span>**N**<span offset-key="a654f90b9ec447c2b4a1b807d0fb6089:2">, it behaves same as the </span>**p**<span offset-key="a654f90b9ec447c2b4a1b807d0fb6089:4"> command. The following simple command illustrates this scenario.</span></span>

1

<span key="7d1428a20110477fbbcfb9b55df480d5"><span offset-key="7d1428a20110477fbbcfb9b55df480d5:0">\[jerry\]$ sed -n 'P' books.txt</span></span>

<img src="data:image/svg+xml;base64," class="r-h7gdob r-10ptun7 r-1vzi8xi" />

Copied!

<span key="403fa2fa5e1443128ea150833b04d10a"><span offset-key="403fa2fa5e1443128ea150833b04d10a:0">On executing the above code, you get the following result:</span></span>

1

<span key="2d7d0334f9704ea298bd223927eebc0c"><span offset-key="2d7d0334f9704ea298bd223927eebc0c:0">A Storm of Swords</span></span>

2

<span key="4fe97a1acccf41918d84635007b7d898"><span offset-key="4fe97a1acccf41918d84635007b7d898:0">George R. R. Martin</span></span>

3

<span key="dbf986bb513b4ef0b4ae29e88ba9f6fb"><span offset-key="dbf986bb513b4ef0b4ae29e88ba9f6fb:0">The Two Towers</span></span>

4

<span key="c3cb019aeeb84c57bfd3550c7d7d978f"><span offset-key="c3cb019aeeb84c57bfd3550c7d7d978f:0">J. R. R. Tolkien</span></span>

5

<span key="e61cd27e51c34ba9a6dc2e84235abf2a"><span offset-key="e61cd27e51c34ba9a6dc2e84235abf2a:0">The Alchemist</span></span>

6

<span key="03c093eb14d8413f9b5cdc390d6cf361"><span offset-key="03c093eb14d8413f9b5cdc390d6cf361:0">Paulo Coelho</span></span>

7

<span key="d708e134a8f44b8793718c196c9d5326"><span offset-key="d708e134a8f44b8793718c196c9d5326:0">The Fellowship of the Ring</span></span>

8

<span key="8dab67ff38b94df0a0e657e47e2d651e"><span offset-key="8dab67ff38b94df0a0e657e47e2d651e:0">J. R. R. Tolkien</span></span>

9

<span key="fc779c78c1404d2f89f25c01240568b5"><span offset-key="fc779c78c1404d2f89f25c01240568b5:0">The Pilgrimage</span></span>

10

<span key="0144dfe8e4f249829b11a7af8f886d6e"><span offset-key="0144dfe8e4f249829b11a7af8f886d6e:0">Paulo Coelho</span></span>

11

<span key="2549277fc7a34561bde33e9015cd4f33"><span offset-key="2549277fc7a34561bde33e9015cd4f33:0">A Game of Thrones</span></span>

12

<span key="2e82c1f1dbfd400a82fe06250632c216"><span offset-key="2e82c1f1dbfd400a82fe06250632c216:0">George R. R. Martin</span></span>

<img src="data:image/svg+xml;base64," class="r-h7gdob r-10ptun7 r-1vzi8xi" />

Copied!

<span key="8921dbd6b316408ba92bba1da361c39e"><span offset-key="8921dbd6b316408ba92bba1da361c39e:0">In addition to this, SED also provides a </span>**v**<span offset-key="8921dbd6b316408ba92bba1da361c39e:2"> command which checks for version. If the provided version is greater than the installed SED version, then the command execution fails. Note that this option is GNU specific and may not work with other variants of SED. Given below is the syntax of the </span>**v**<span offset-key="8921dbd6b316408ba92bba1da361c39e:4"> command.</span></span>

1

<span key="cc66d58043c342018452e078ba53c110"><span offset-key="cc66d58043c342018452e078ba53c110:0">\[address1\[,address2\]\]v \[version\]</span></span>

<img src="data:image/svg+xml;base64," class="r-h7gdob r-10ptun7 r-1vzi8xi" />

Copied!

<span key="79afa28c63df42db92ee6d43283f076c"><span offset-key="79afa28c63df42db92ee6d43283f076c:0">First, find out the current version of SED.</span></span>

1

<span key="69592ca47630496f841701acf1ed2244"><span offset-key="69592ca47630496f841701acf1ed2244:0">\[jerry\]$ sed --version</span></span>

<img src="data:image/svg+xml;base64," class="r-h7gdob r-10ptun7 r-1vzi8xi" />

Copied!

<span key="88b8db1f807d4f08aa6c17416ceb183d"><span offset-key="88b8db1f807d4f08aa6c17416ceb183d:0">On executing the above code, you get the following result:</span></span>

1

<span key="cd4a0fb2210d497e8ea6a17d6e8573b8"><span offset-key="cd4a0fb2210d497e8ea6a17d6e8573b8:0">sed (GNU sed) 4.2.2</span></span>

<img src="data:image/svg+xml;base64," class="r-h7gdob r-10ptun7 r-1vzi8xi" />

Copied!

<span key="b6c02e7a135e4e40a580a9a28956ead8"><span offset-key="b6c02e7a135e4e40a580a9a28956ead8:0">In the following example, the SED version is greater than version 4.2.2, hence the SED command aborts its execution.</span></span>

1

<span key="8c0497a9047e40969605ae63b73f7be3"><span offset-key="8c0497a9047e40969605ae63b73f7be3:0">\[jerry\]$ sed 'v 4.2.3' books.txt</span></span>

<img src="data:image/svg+xml;base64," class="r-h7gdob r-10ptun7 r-1vzi8xi" />

Copied!

<span key="e7d61cb9a7734865ac7625a274f61327"><span offset-key="e7d61cb9a7734865ac7625a274f61327:0">On executing the above code, you get the following result:</span></span>

1

<span key="94b0b06378d749b587c1d43a4caa172b"><span offset-key="94b0b06378d749b587c1d43a4caa172b:0">sed: -e expression #1, char 7: expected newer version of sed</span></span>

<img src="data:image/svg+xml;base64," class="r-h7gdob r-10ptun7 r-1vzi8xi" />

Copied!

<span key="41b3a8931b6244318ef43161647eec6a"><span offset-key="41b3a8931b6244318ef43161647eec6a:0">But if the provided version is lesser than or equal to version 4.2.2, then the command works as expected.</span></span>

1

<span key="b19bcf37ae6e4d66a9542f818405d2cb"><span offset-key="b19bcf37ae6e4d66a9542f818405d2cb:0">\[jerry\]$ sed 'v 4.2.2' books.txt</span></span>

<img src="data:image/svg+xml;base64," class="r-h7gdob r-10ptun7 r-1vzi8xi" />

Copied!

<span key="f9b6d17fcb9541e7ba2e299d42d248ba"><span offset-key="f9b6d17fcb9541e7ba2e299d42d248ba:0">On executing the above code, you get the following result:</span></span>

1

<span key="64f3c42070b0496bbc8cca2da074c5d4"><span offset-key="64f3c42070b0496bbc8cca2da074c5d4:0">A Storm of Swords</span></span>

2

<span key="1e498c88a39448d98de4a88efe07f4ae"><span offset-key="1e498c88a39448d98de4a88efe07f4ae:0">George R. R. Martin</span></span>

3

<span key="0d5a8dbc63424f2e9aa080b03f521956"><span offset-key="0d5a8dbc63424f2e9aa080b03f521956:0">The Two Towers</span></span>

4

<span key="bb037b6ba1f6460d91569b151b580f47"><span offset-key="bb037b6ba1f6460d91569b151b580f47:0">J. R. R. Tolkien</span></span>

5

<span key="7dcf01d5f39b4b318d7fa05a122b59cb"><span offset-key="7dcf01d5f39b4b318d7fa05a122b59cb:0">The Alchemist</span></span>

6

<span key="da4e98010d1f49d9aba33e619ea2cf53"><span offset-key="da4e98010d1f49d9aba33e619ea2cf53:0">Paulo Coelho</span></span>

7

<span key="85d4ff3800564afca2e4943996195a11"><span offset-key="85d4ff3800564afca2e4943996195a11:0">The Fellowship of the Ring</span></span>

8

<span key="c65c751358cd4237a152785b18fdb708"><span offset-key="c65c751358cd4237a152785b18fdb708:0">J. R. R. Tolkien</span></span>

9

<span key="533a912665e04fd0bc9ad660e202b777"><span offset-key="533a912665e04fd0bc9ad660e202b777:0">The Pilgrimage</span></span>

10

<span key="1921bd3cf1914fe7875c7d14d7c0705f"><span offset-key="1921bd3cf1914fe7875c7d14d7c0705f:0">Paulo Coelho</span></span>

11

<span key="fd7887d71490477594bf785bf235212e"><span offset-key="fd7887d71490477594bf785bf235212e:0">A Game of Thrones George R. R. Martin</span></span>
