# 

<span key="81f3cda00f46488a8a1da52fd8024a19"><span offset-key="81f3cda00f46488a8a1da52fd8024a19:0">Stream Editor - Special Characters</span></span>

<span key="21969166c993414fa08ed98f4d8bac99"><span offset-key="21969166c993414fa08ed98f4d8bac99:0">SED provides two special characters which are treated as commands. This chapter illustrates the usage of these two special characters.</span></span>

## 

<span key="6ac24762c3df489fad4f916bac038ea0"><span offset-key="6ac24762c3df489fad4f916bac038ea0:0">= Command</span></span>

<span key="0fcb84c3298c455bbe8a1355df16cbed"><span offset-key="0fcb84c3298c455bbe8a1355df16cbed:0">The "=" command deals with line numbers. Given below is the syntax of the "=" command:</span></span>

1

<span key="2e53911029cc4060b1da87e1f00f6082"><span offset-key="2e53911029cc4060b1da87e1f00f6082:0">\[/pattern/\]=</span></span>

2

<span key="51cda950222b4163a5b8b74113e83821"><span offset-key="51cda950222b4163a5b8b74113e83821:0">\[address1\[,address2\]\]=</span></span>

<img src="data:image/svg+xml;base64," class="r-h7gdob r-10ptun7 r-1vzi8xi" />

Copied!

<span key="3e4892767c1543b3aad8eb4f3096e3e9"><span offset-key="3e4892767c1543b3aad8eb4f3096e3e9:0">The = command writes the line number followed by its contents on the standard output stream. The following example illustrates this.</span></span>

1

<span key="ff93547b57cb4f478095c3c2841d74ac"><span offset-key="ff93547b57cb4f478095c3c2841d74ac:0">\[jerry\]$ sed '=' books.txt</span></span>

<img src="data:image/svg+xml;base64," class="r-h7gdob r-10ptun7 r-1vzi8xi" />

Copied!

<span key="507050c641b74b52b812539677b6fac1"><span offset-key="507050c641b74b52b812539677b6fac1:0">On executing the above code, you get the following result:</span></span>

1

<span key="097d4d3091a64de98443ffd50e0b6cc9"><span offset-key="097d4d3091a64de98443ffd50e0b6cc9:0">1</span></span>

2

<span key="4794dbdaebba45cfb18c5f868e3d708c"><span offset-key="4794dbdaebba45cfb18c5f868e3d708c:0">1) A Storm of Swords, George R. R. Martin, 1216</span></span>

3

<span key="e736e7c2251c40f4a41e10bad3ab4ef3"><span offset-key="e736e7c2251c40f4a41e10bad3ab4ef3:0">2</span></span>

4

<span key="b6626edb8023461c9f6d40b0af8fd1bb"><span offset-key="b6626edb8023461c9f6d40b0af8fd1bb:0">2) The Two Towers, J. R. R. Tolkien, 352</span></span>

5

<span key="606631502a384987b8bbe5503fbccfbb"><span offset-key="606631502a384987b8bbe5503fbccfbb:0">3</span></span>

6

<span key="4c5fc9bc5c0e433f92ee2fb64500c688"><span offset-key="4c5fc9bc5c0e433f92ee2fb64500c688:0">3) The Alchemist, Paulo Coelho, 197</span></span>

7

<span key="b3ac89d12b81424da15595002e09787a"><span offset-key="b3ac89d12b81424da15595002e09787a:0">4</span></span>

8

<span key="8f808b1fccdb48f89f2e602666a0b2ce"><span offset-key="8f808b1fccdb48f89f2e602666a0b2ce:0">4) The Fellowship of the Ring, J. R. R. Tolkien, 432</span></span>

9

<span key="9f632181372546149209f7c5732808ff"><span offset-key="9f632181372546149209f7c5732808ff:0">5</span></span>

10

<span key="130024de3891451a842a5266fc4404f4"><span offset-key="130024de3891451a842a5266fc4404f4:0">5) The Pilgrimage, Paulo Coelho, 288</span></span>

11

<span key="50c1b8fd20904ce3ac4894adbff1de9f"><span offset-key="50c1b8fd20904ce3ac4894adbff1de9f:0">6</span></span>

12

<span key="077f86ea775e49f992a184f8db75c1a6"><span offset-key="077f86ea775e49f992a184f8db75c1a6:0">6) A Game of Thrones, George R. R. Martin, 864</span></span>

<img src="data:image/svg+xml;base64," class="r-h7gdob r-10ptun7 r-1vzi8xi" />

Copied!

<span key="6abaa89d98e047bd87670c09250d503c"><span offset-key="6abaa89d98e047bd87670c09250d503c:0">Let us print the line numbers and the contents of the first four lines. The following command prints the first four lines with line numbers and the remaining without line numbers.</span></span>

1

<span key="41eeadd2e5d64d7d9591e2c70f5697dc"><span offset-key="41eeadd2e5d64d7d9591e2c70f5697dc:0">\[jerry\]$ sed '1, 4=' books.txt</span></span>

<img src="data:image/svg+xml;base64," class="r-h7gdob r-10ptun7 r-1vzi8xi" />

Copied!

<span key="a275e750bab14541bd4a60b8cc860de3"><span offset-key="a275e750bab14541bd4a60b8cc860de3:0">On executing the above code, you get the following result:</span></span>

1

<span key="513f9f30558e4e8b84f5c2a33a983df3"><span offset-key="513f9f30558e4e8b84f5c2a33a983df3:0">1</span></span>

2

<span key="2261c13dbe2a4366bf67cdb40f22d0fb"><span offset-key="2261c13dbe2a4366bf67cdb40f22d0fb:0">1) A Storm of Swords, George R. R. Martin, 1216</span></span>

3

<span key="c2f06c7b09b849389d8d2d6eac8aa2d9"><span offset-key="c2f06c7b09b849389d8d2d6eac8aa2d9:0">2</span></span>

4

<span key="4cc5c979851142aba06204f3f21a76e8"><span offset-key="4cc5c979851142aba06204f3f21a76e8:0">2) The Two Towers, J. R. R. Tolkien, 352</span></span>

5

<span key="c485f93649ce46a3af354fc4fca3a1e3"><span offset-key="c485f93649ce46a3af354fc4fca3a1e3:0">3</span></span>

6

<span key="59906b4be4aa40428846584b2f00ae08"><span offset-key="59906b4be4aa40428846584b2f00ae08:0">3) The Alchemist, Paulo Coelho, 197</span></span>

7

<span key="128a8a6326e544df9ba7f9a721b8d93c"><span offset-key="128a8a6326e544df9ba7f9a721b8d93c:0">4</span></span>

8

<span key="e2b25a7df2bd4035bbfcd92cfa83a94d"><span offset-key="e2b25a7df2bd4035bbfcd92cfa83a94d:0">4) The Fellowship of the Ring, J. R. R. Tolkien, 432</span></span>

9

<span key="5a1e4a70f3a840948c7f4f91bea4cc41"><span offset-key="5a1e4a70f3a840948c7f4f91bea4cc41:0">5) The Pilgrimage, Paulo Coelho, 288</span></span>

10

<span key="2dd3411a27ea46e1ad7b2db0080e6bcb"><span offset-key="2dd3411a27ea46e1ad7b2db0080e6bcb:0">6) A Game of Thrones, George R. R. Martin, 864</span></span>

<img src="data:image/svg+xml;base64," class="r-h7gdob r-10ptun7 r-1vzi8xi" />

Copied!

<span key="2aba742040fa49d0ba2dd8678d79f264"><span offset-key="2aba742040fa49d0ba2dd8678d79f264:0">Additionally, we can instruct the SED to print line numbers when a pattern match succeeds. The following example prints the line number that contains the pattern "Paulo".</span></span>

1

<span key="578bcee9089e462c92a5567cba1c17e0"><span offset-key="578bcee9089e462c92a5567cba1c17e0:0">\[jerry\]$ sed '/Paulo/ =' books.txt</span></span>

<img src="data:image/svg+xml;base64," class="r-h7gdob r-10ptun7 r-1vzi8xi" />

Copied!

<span key="65c7e8e3c1bf45e9910fecc3d6fad2d7"><span offset-key="65c7e8e3c1bf45e9910fecc3d6fad2d7:0">On executing the above code, you get the following result:</span></span>

1

<span key="57ee4b685fb54c25acaeeeadc874bf34"><span offset-key="57ee4b685fb54c25acaeeeadc874bf34:0">1) A Storm of Swords, George R. R. Martin, 1216</span></span>

2

<span key="e6a24523111b4d2e873088a0a5209eac"><span offset-key="e6a24523111b4d2e873088a0a5209eac:0">2) The Two Towers, J. R. R. Tolkien, 352</span></span>

3

<span key="f8e9a41baf4c4d0d84142ac0754e21bd"><span offset-key="f8e9a41baf4c4d0d84142ac0754e21bd:0">3</span></span>

4

<span key="baf8f5ce10c141019561f04e1e89d369"><span offset-key="baf8f5ce10c141019561f04e1e89d369:0">3) The Alchemist, Paulo Coelho, 197</span></span>

5

<span key="55e1a7c3c8d14cf78b036e177b543196"><span offset-key="55e1a7c3c8d14cf78b036e177b543196:0">4) The Fellowship of the Ring, J. R. R. Tolkien, 432</span></span>

6

<span key="88aabaa0676c45a4b83156919edc3074"><span offset-key="88aabaa0676c45a4b83156919edc3074:0">5</span></span>

7

<span key="07d097e163384593a6d8007c44618b8c"><span offset-key="07d097e163384593a6d8007c44618b8c:0">5) The Pilgrimage, Paulo Coelho, 288</span></span>

8

<span key="07b251ae1ae945e5a64065bdef497c20"><span offset-key="07b251ae1ae945e5a64065bdef497c20:0">6) A Game of Thrones, George R. R. Martin, 864</span></span>

<img src="data:image/svg+xml;base64," class="r-h7gdob r-10ptun7 r-1vzi8xi" />

Copied!

<span key="9f4e8616869347838ce33f89a56925f4"><span offset-key="9f4e8616869347838ce33f89a56925f4:0">Can you guess what the following SED command does?</span></span>

1

<span key="c61d1336e1864131ac8b89d0ad51c590"><span offset-key="c61d1336e1864131ac8b89d0ad51c590:0">\[jerry\]$ sed -n '$ =' books.txt</span></span>

<img src="data:image/svg+xml;base64," class="r-h7gdob r-10ptun7 r-1vzi8xi" />

Copied!

<span key="95e7ba46597741bfbc82ea8f0194df40"><span offset-key="95e7ba46597741bfbc82ea8f0194df40:0">On executing the above code, you get the following result:</span></span>

1

<span key="9013132270e84e82bf7bef14a03b3713"><span offset-key="9013132270e84e82bf7bef14a03b3713:0">6</span></span>

<img src="data:image/svg+xml;base64," class="r-h7gdob r-10ptun7 r-1vzi8xi" />

Copied!

<span key="5387dc9593bd470ea1ff908df149c225"><span offset-key="5387dc9593bd470ea1ff908df149c225:0">Yes, you are right. It counts the total number of lines present in the file. Let us demystify the code. In the command section, we used "$ =" which prints the line number of the last line followed by its contents. But we also provided the \*\*-n \*\*flag which suppresses the default printing of the pattern buffer. Hence, only the last line number is displayed.</span></span>

## 

<span key="f4becd31d9a743d680509a20fbbe69f2"><span offset-key="f4becd31d9a743d680509a20fbbe69f2:0">& Command</span></span>

<span key="f111412ebb654e209959f6103a0f7a76"><span offset-key="f111412ebb654e209959f6103a0f7a76:0">SED supports the special character &. Whenever a pattern match succeeds, this special character stores the matched pattern. It is often used with the substitution command. Let us see how we can leverage this efficient feature.</span></span>

<span key="269313d82df644cf8f6de94a03b212f9"><span offset-key="269313d82df644cf8f6de94a03b212f9:0">Each line in the book.txt file is numbered. Let us add the words </span>**Book number**<span offset-key="269313d82df644cf8f6de94a03b212f9:2"> at the beginning of each line. The following example illustrates this.</span></span>

1

<span key="bea328b1c785487795a1ce090fe1cfef"><span offset-key="bea328b1c785487795a1ce090fe1cfef:0">\[jerry\]$ sed 's/\[\[:digit:\]\]/Book number &/' books.txt</span></span>

<img src="data:image/svg+xml;base64," class="r-h7gdob r-10ptun7 r-1vzi8xi" />

Copied!

<span key="ac09722527bb4af8898fdc4ce8ac730c"><span offset-key="ac09722527bb4af8898fdc4ce8ac730c:0">On executing the above code, you get the following result:</span></span>

1

<span key="1bc84164d857473f9aa31a3d005aa73c"><span offset-key="1bc84164d857473f9aa31a3d005aa73c:0">Book number 1) A Storm of Swords, George R. R. Martin, 1216</span></span>

2

<span key="f84e9496c7764b1c88f968cfac1bfccf"><span offset-key="f84e9496c7764b1c88f968cfac1bfccf:0">Book number 2) The Two Towers, J. R. R. Tolkien, 352</span></span>

3

<span key="dbb3af189d244a58936612f3ee801e19"><span offset-key="dbb3af189d244a58936612f3ee801e19:0">Book number 3) The Alchemist, Paulo Coelho, 197</span></span>

4

<span key="190009125dc4482385fd4427ebed12fa"><span offset-key="190009125dc4482385fd4427ebed12fa:0">Book number 4) The Fellowship of the Ring, J. R. R. Tolkien, 432</span></span>

5

<span key="5510eb87f73849d98eff31f664a03127"><span offset-key="5510eb87f73849d98eff31f664a03127:0">Book number 5) The Pilgrimage, Paulo Coelho, 288</span></span>

6

<span key="c607fbf351404f33b92b26097e82926d"><span offset-key="c607fbf351404f33b92b26097e82926d:0">Book number 6) A Game of Thrones, George R. R. Martin, 864</span></span>

<img src="data:image/svg+xml;base64," class="r-h7gdob r-10ptun7 r-1vzi8xi" />

Copied!

<span key="225e1f871cf849d4a73bce55d216da3c"><span offset-key="225e1f871cf849d4a73bce55d216da3c:0">This example is very simple. First, we search for the first occurrence of a digit, which is the line number (that is why we used \[\[:digit:\]\]) and the SED automatically stores the matched pattern in the special character &. In the second step, we insert the words </span>**Book number**<span offset-key="225e1f871cf849d4a73bce55d216da3c:2"> before each matched pattern, i.e., before every line.</span></span>

<span key="14fb0b19829d4245a57a008644d59745"><span offset-key="14fb0b19829d4245a57a008644d59745:0">Let us take another example. In the book.txt file, the last digit implies the number of pages of the book. Let us add "Pages =" before that. To do this, find the last occurrence of the digit and replace it with "Pages = &". Here, & stores the matched pattern, i.e., the number of pages</span></span>

1

<span key="61e40935dafb4477bd1fe46b5fcf1366"><span offset-key="61e40935dafb4477bd1fe46b5fcf1366:0">\[jerry\]$ sed 's/\[\[:digit:\]\]\*$/Pages = &/' books.txt</span></span>

<img src="data:image/svg+xml;base64," class="r-h7gdob r-10ptun7 r-1vzi8xi" />

Copied!

<span key="93fc46774cb04984be5628f21daba7c4"><span offset-key="93fc46774cb04984be5628f21daba7c4:0">On executing the above syntax, you get the following result:</span></span>

1

<span key="6ec51ce2ce4a42c8b027d97439047a5c"><span offset-key="6ec51ce2ce4a42c8b027d97439047a5c:0">1) A Storm of Swords, George R. R. Martin, Pages = 1216</span></span>

2

<span key="0eb3e5ae87a2400298e0b452b6d68348"><span offset-key="0eb3e5ae87a2400298e0b452b6d68348:0">2) The Two Towers, J. R. R. Tolkien, Pages = 352</span></span>

3

<span key="035a63b5ede34cf1aec7730be4026c2f"><span offset-key="035a63b5ede34cf1aec7730be4026c2f:0">3) The Alchemist, Paulo Coelho, Pages = 197</span></span>

4

<span key="5677b4baf27743edb9091f3d5497cf2e"><span offset-key="5677b4baf27743edb9091f3d5497cf2e:0">4) The Fellowship of the Ring, J. R. R. Tolkien, Pages = 432</span></span>

5

<span key="49823d0d3e1e4cc99181ca40f2af76ba"><span offset-key="49823d0d3e1e4cc99181ca40f2af76ba:0">5) The Pilgrimage, Paulo Coelho,Pages = 288</span></span>

6

<span key="b3debfe96edf44cd94d2618cd6d467a0"><span offset-key="b3debfe96edf44cd94d2618cd6d467a0:0">6) A Game of Thrones, George R. R. Martin, Pages = 864</span></span>

<img src="data:image/svg+xml;base64," class="r-h7gdob r-10ptun7 r-1vzi8xi" />

Copied!

<span key="c70c48b812c14b04bc439cd0abf9910a"><span offset-key="c70c48b812c14b04bc439cd0abf9910a:0">For the time being, just remember that </span>**\[\[:digit:\]\]\*$**<span offset-key="c70c48b812c14b04bc439cd0abf9910a:2"> finds the last occurrence of the digit. In the chapter "Regular Expressions, we will explore more about regular expressions.</span></span>

# 

<span key="6583911df84e468aaec2a0e21e2ab860"><span offset-key="6583911df84e468aaec2a0e21e2ab860:0">Stream Editor - Strings</span></span>

## 

<span key="c7bf881f0d064b289f31bd56ce5ba735"><span offset-key="c7bf881f0d064b289f31bd56ce5ba735:0">Substitute Command</span></span>

<span key="7ebc3fd96de24bf388c2916cdd0accca"><span offset-key="7ebc3fd96de24bf388c2916cdd0accca:0">Text substitution operations like "find and replace" are common in any text editor. In this section, we illustrate how SED performs text substitution. Given below is the syntax of the substitution command.</span></span>

1

<span key="457d07276c2d4673837c66b20ee108d3"><span offset-key="457d07276c2d4673837c66b20ee108d3:0">\[address1\[,address2\]\]s/pattern/replacement/\[flags\]</span></span>

<img src="data:image/svg+xml;base64," class="r-h7gdob r-10ptun7 r-1vzi8xi" />

Copied!

<span key="b01ac97fd6dd455d8db5388f04cd32ed"><span offset-key="b01ac97fd6dd455d8db5388f04cd32ed:0">Here, </span>**address1**<span offset-key="b01ac97fd6dd455d8db5388f04cd32ed:2"> and </span>**address2**<span offset-key="b01ac97fd6dd455d8db5388f04cd32ed:4"> are the starting and ending addresses respectively, which can be either line numbers or pattern strings. Both these addresses are optional parameters. The pattern is the text which we want to replace with the replacement string. Additionally, we can specify optional flags with the SED.</span></span>

<span key="6364821e171142ccbe09df9025843499"><span offset-key="6364821e171142ccbe09df9025843499:0">In the books.txt file, we have used comma(,) to separate each column. Let us use vertical bar(|) to separate each column. To do this, replace comma(,) with vertical bar(|).</span></span>

1

<span key="52f98b88052042d598cf7534bb3770d7"><span offset-key="52f98b88052042d598cf7534bb3770d7:0">\[jerry\]$ sed 's/,/ | /' books.txt</span></span>

<img src="data:image/svg+xml;base64," class="r-h7gdob r-10ptun7 r-1vzi8xi" />

Copied!

<span key="cc438d9e382541dabbda76133de2c6f9"><span offset-key="cc438d9e382541dabbda76133de2c6f9:0">On executing the above code, you get the following result:</span></span>

1

<span key="34b141ff9f804843bc794c1b1e57177c"><span offset-key="34b141ff9f804843bc794c1b1e57177c:0">1) A Storm of Swords | George R. R. Martin, 1216</span></span>

2

<span key="267de6878b1249048c141b707b3bef80"><span offset-key="267de6878b1249048c141b707b3bef80:0">2) The Two Towers | J. R. R. Tolkien, 352</span></span>

3

<span key="8b1f054e94f442fa9263b4fe78ccaba9"><span offset-key="8b1f054e94f442fa9263b4fe78ccaba9:0">3) The Alchemist | Paulo Coelho, 197</span></span>

4

<span key="6b49fe5384bd406087f1462d2856a010"><span offset-key="6b49fe5384bd406087f1462d2856a010:0">4) The Fellowship of the Ring | J. R. R. Tolkien, 432</span></span>

5

<span key="867e6ef09d674fbab8798d9ed3a9fe96"><span offset-key="867e6ef09d674fbab8798d9ed3a9fe96:0">5) The Pilgrimage | Paulo Coelho, 288</span></span>

6

<span key="a32df83015d649a29cd651212dbce782"><span offset-key="a32df83015d649a29cd651212dbce782:0">6) A Game of Thrones | George R. R. Martin, 864</span></span>

<img src="data:image/svg+xml;base64," class="r-h7gdob r-10ptun7 r-1vzi8xi" />

Copied!

<span key="d73336e038384ae2845271a715a4595c"><span offset-key="d73336e038384ae2845271a715a4595c:0">If you observe carefully, only the first comma is replaced and the second remains as it is. Why? As soon as the pattern matches, SED replaces it with the replacement string and moves to the next line. By default, it replaces only the first occurrence. To replace all occurrences, use the global flag (g) with SED as follows:</span></span>

1

<span key="64d556e225974391a599b12b7def170d"><span offset-key="64d556e225974391a599b12b7def170d:0">\[jerry\]$ sed 's/,/ | /g' books.txt</span></span>

<img src="data:image/svg+xml;base64," class="r-h7gdob r-10ptun7 r-1vzi8xi" />

Copied!

<span key="028b9c4293504da58b709a258b8a7712"><span offset-key="028b9c4293504da58b709a258b8a7712:0">On executing the above code, you get the following result:</span></span>

1

<span key="da84df7bdd4f4ad3b5b8ae2d984dd72d"><span offset-key="da84df7bdd4f4ad3b5b8ae2d984dd72d:0">1) A Storm of Swords | George R. R. Martin | 1216</span></span>

2

<span key="9a6ce57ccce24e0caed86cab2aae43e7"><span offset-key="9a6ce57ccce24e0caed86cab2aae43e7:0">2) The Two Towers | J. R. R. Tolkien | 352</span></span>

3

<span key="ab5ad71212a94c8ea01ad292a3b03458"><span offset-key="ab5ad71212a94c8ea01ad292a3b03458:0">3) The Alchemist | Paulo Coelho | 197</span></span>

4

<span key="a623b1d4922d46efbf7d2413025b3cb8"><span offset-key="a623b1d4922d46efbf7d2413025b3cb8:0">4) The Fellowship of the Ring | J. R. R. Tolkien | 432</span></span>

5

<span key="8d09a69258da436794c782feb41c26bc"><span offset-key="8d09a69258da436794c782feb41c26bc:0">5) The Pilgrimage | Paulo Coelho | 288</span></span>

6

<span key="3dda0b922bc04aa584d5782b10a43209"><span offset-key="3dda0b922bc04aa584d5782b10a43209:0">6) A Game of Thrones | George R. R. Martin | 864</span></span>

<img src="data:image/svg+xml;base64," class="r-h7gdob r-10ptun7 r-1vzi8xi" />

Copied!

<span key="6cbae245389a48d696e26fc16ba4d480"><span offset-key="6cbae245389a48d696e26fc16ba4d480:0">Now all occurrences of commas(,) are replaced with vertical bar(|).</span></span>

<span key="af2e4b8755734ab4ab29ad1fee724b9d"><span offset-key="af2e4b8755734ab4ab29ad1fee724b9d:0">We can instruct the SED to perform text substitution only when a pattern match succeeds. The following example replaces comma(,) with vertical bar(|) only when a line contains the pattern The Pilgrimage.</span></span>

1

<span key="88bec821e001457d87e9bc277802747c"><span offset-key="88bec821e001457d87e9bc277802747c:0">\[jerry\]$ sed '/The Pilgrimage/ s/,/ | /g' books.txt</span></span>

<img src="data:image/svg+xml;base64," class="r-h7gdob r-10ptun7 r-1vzi8xi" />

Copied!

<span key="4995f6ea2d1e44bda3297ca6b279dacf"><span offset-key="4995f6ea2d1e44bda3297ca6b279dacf:0">On executing the above code, you get the following result:</span></span>

1

<span key="28652c8f44184cc4be697452c58a0ce6"><span offset-key="28652c8f44184cc4be697452c58a0ce6:0">1) A Storm of Swords, George R. R. Martin, 1216</span></span>

2

<span key="786408d5962e4f67b6d95b08ccd6e327"><span offset-key="786408d5962e4f67b6d95b08ccd6e327:0">2) The Two Towers, J. R. R. Tolkien, 352</span></span>

3

<span key="e54601774d464652a597d0970674af4a"><span offset-key="e54601774d464652a597d0970674af4a:0">3) The Alchemist, Paulo Coelho, 197</span></span>

4

<span key="ce34739bda79414b859a04eb0bb1c203"><span offset-key="ce34739bda79414b859a04eb0bb1c203:0">4) The Fellowship of the Ring, J. R. R. Tolkien, 432</span></span>

5

<span key="d05ff02fc31c48e793d2b662f6bab0f4"><span offset-key="d05ff02fc31c48e793d2b662f6bab0f4:0">5) The Pilgrimage | Paulo Coelho | 288</span></span>

6

<span key="a13f534b40dc4002af08e98e2976eb47"><span offset-key="a13f534b40dc4002af08e98e2976eb47:0">6) A Game of Thrones, George R. R. Martin, 864</span></span>

<img src="data:image/svg+xml;base64," class="r-h7gdob r-10ptun7 r-1vzi8xi" />

Copied!

<span key="4f0cf0c4210f437e8c2d90a7c37a11ed"><span offset-key="4f0cf0c4210f437e8c2d90a7c37a11ed:0">In addition to this, SED can replace a specific occurrence of the pattern. Let us replace only the second instance of comma(,) with vertical bar(|).</span></span>

1

<span key="f2d771d0318c48b99ce329e12595f57a"><span offset-key="f2d771d0318c48b99ce329e12595f57a:0">\[jerry\]$ sed 's/,/ | /2' books.txt</span></span>

<img src="data:image/svg+xml;base64," class="r-h7gdob r-10ptun7 r-1vzi8xi" />

Copied!

<span key="d5a9ed6a0f064d049af9d13ee31522c1"><span offset-key="d5a9ed6a0f064d049af9d13ee31522c1:0">On executing the above code, you get the following result:</span></span>

1

<span key="60e004d8edea4751830adb31785c88d6"><span offset-key="60e004d8edea4751830adb31785c88d6:0">1) A Storm of Swords, George R. R. Martin | 1216</span></span>

2

<span key="c4632522ac0d4b06815b04567298bf5e"><span offset-key="c4632522ac0d4b06815b04567298bf5e:0">2) The Two Towers, J. R. R. Tolkien | 352</span></span>

3

<span key="f2b86de62aee4028918b3952d3b04c47"><span offset-key="f2b86de62aee4028918b3952d3b04c47:0">3) The Alchemist, Paulo Coelho | 197</span></span>

4

<span key="aa6f97acc0f143a78f5b19778b49467d"><span offset-key="aa6f97acc0f143a78f5b19778b49467d:0">4) The Fellowship of the Ring, J. R. R. Tolkien | 432</span></span>

5

<span key="29c3f47d9d89463fb22ed09566a8eb26"><span offset-key="29c3f47d9d89463fb22ed09566a8eb26:0">5) The Pilgrimage,Paulo Coelho | 288</span></span>

6

<span key="c1413f7aedf1459096af828738532fad"><span offset-key="c1413f7aedf1459096af828738532fad:0">6) A Game of Thrones, George R. R. Martin | 864</span></span>

<img src="data:image/svg+xml;base64," class="r-h7gdob r-10ptun7 r-1vzi8xi" />

Copied!

<span key="4e08a5ed1c864cfd9c852b7e19f30d60"><span offset-key="4e08a5ed1c864cfd9c852b7e19f30d60:0">In the above example, the number at the end of the SED command (or at the place of flag) implies the 2nd occurrence.</span></span>

<span key="255981f0ba754e96bfa41f9fe5303023"><span offset-key="255981f0ba754e96bfa41f9fe5303023:0">SED provides an interesting feature. After performing substitution, SED provides an option to show only the changed lines. For this purpose, SED uses the </span>**p**<span offset-key="255981f0ba754e96bfa41f9fe5303023:2"> flag which refers to print. The following example lists only changed lines.</span></span>

1

<span key="f779fcfda2bd4aec99904f4df0ba31cc"><span offset-key="f779fcfda2bd4aec99904f4df0ba31cc:0">\[jerry\]$ sed -n 's/Paulo Coelho/PAULO COELHO/p' books.txt</span></span>

<img src="data:image/svg+xml;base64," class="r-h7gdob r-10ptun7 r-1vzi8xi" />

Copied!

<span key="e358b1f1ae3e450eadc66220b7c77735"><span offset-key="e358b1f1ae3e450eadc66220b7c77735:0">On executing the above code, you get the following result:</span></span>

1

<span key="79c53301d3c74347a3e41126849c2355"><span offset-key="79c53301d3c74347a3e41126849c2355:0">3) The Alchemist, PAULO COELHO, 197</span></span>

2

<span key="28281da3eef94cad9213f72c16dcb789"><span offset-key="28281da3eef94cad9213f72c16dcb789:0">5) The Pilgrimage, PAULO COELHO, 288</span></span>

<img src="data:image/svg+xml;base64," class="r-h7gdob r-10ptun7 r-1vzi8xi" />

Copied!

<span key="fd859cdbc6774c4fa8dff65d7ec0424d"><span offset-key="fd859cdbc6774c4fa8dff65d7ec0424d:0">We can store changed lines in another file as well. To achieve this result, use the </span>**w**<span offset-key="fd859cdbc6774c4fa8dff65d7ec0424d:2"> flag. The following example shows how to do it.</span></span>

1

<span key="a7ccd1c53b6847b794ccceeb8478400a"><span offset-key="a7ccd1c53b6847b794ccceeb8478400a:0">\[jerry\]$ sed -n 's/Paulo Coelho/PAULO COELHO/w junk.txt' books.txt</span></span>

<img src="data:image/svg+xml;base64," class="r-h7gdob r-10ptun7 r-1vzi8xi" />

Copied!

<span key="93b83fa8773740e683702196c45005d9"><span offset-key="93b83fa8773740e683702196c45005d9:0">We used the same SED command. Let us verify the contents of the </span>**junk.txt**<span offset-key="93b83fa8773740e683702196c45005d9:2"> file.</span></span>

1

<span key="c658b2475a654262be2c05394243b47f"><span offset-key="c658b2475a654262be2c05394243b47f:0">\[jerry\]$ cat junk.txt</span></span>

<img src="data:image/svg+xml;base64," class="r-h7gdob r-10ptun7 r-1vzi8xi" />

Copied!

<span key="9e007812514244229e9b5ffb17318865"><span offset-key="9e007812514244229e9b5ffb17318865:0">On executing the above code, you get the following result:</span></span>

1

<span key="fbc9c80d37e0487db8e70a12a51e5e18"><span offset-key="fbc9c80d37e0487db8e70a12a51e5e18:0">3) The Alchemist, PAULO COELHO, 197</span></span>

2

<span key="a9c28efde8ec4b039c5f867edefe58c7"><span offset-key="a9c28efde8ec4b039c5f867edefe58c7:0">5) The Pilgrimage, PAULO COELHO, 288</span></span>

<img src="data:image/svg+xml;base64," class="r-h7gdob r-10ptun7 r-1vzi8xi" />

Copied!

<span key="4e03d21b1bbe49228e36590cdeac8026"><span offset-key="4e03d21b1bbe49228e36590cdeac8026:0">To perform case-insensitive substitution, use the i flag which implies ignore case. The following example performs case-insensitive substitution.</span></span>

1

<span key="61e2041e590c4f9fb5d02db9441cc248"><span offset-key="61e2041e590c4f9fb5d02db9441cc248:0">\[jerry\]$ sed -n 's/pAuLo CoElHo/PAULO COELHO/pi' books.txt</span></span>

<img src="data:image/svg+xml;base64," class="r-h7gdob r-10ptun7 r-1vzi8xi" />

Copied!

<span key="89fe922081db4a009db87f0bb046075f"><span offset-key="89fe922081db4a009db87f0bb046075f:0">On executing the above code, you get the following result:</span></span>

1

<span key="9ae36172765548678619f8fc0412ebaa"><span offset-key="9ae36172765548678619f8fc0412ebaa:0">3) The Alchemist, PAULO COELHO, 197</span></span>

2

<span key="be543934533f4a42b7f4a6d4bd6807d5"><span offset-key="be543934533f4a42b7f4a6d4bd6807d5:0">5) The Pilgrimage, PAULO COELHO, 288</span></span>

<img src="data:image/svg+xml;base64," class="r-h7gdob r-10ptun7 r-1vzi8xi" />

Copied!

<span key="d0891064caf34b6bbdf8fd86f67a7448"><span offset-key="d0891064caf34b6bbdf8fd86f67a7448:0">So far, we have used only the foreslash(/) character as a delimiter, but we can also use vertical bar(|), at sign(@), caret(^), exclamation mark(!) as a delimiter. The following example shows how to use other characters as a delimiter.</span></span>

<span key="972960e0bfcd46df93392a5435c48d07"><span offset-key="972960e0bfcd46df93392a5435c48d07:0">Let us assume you need to replace the path </span>**/bin/sed**<span offset-key="972960e0bfcd46df93392a5435c48d07:2"> with </span>**/home/jerry/src/sed/sed-4.2.2/sed.**<span offset-key="972960e0bfcd46df93392a5435c48d07:4"> Hence, your SED command looks like this:</span></span>

1

<span key="77da41ec9a454fc08bcddf64023221f4"><span offset-key="77da41ec9a454fc08bcddf64023221f4:0">\[jerry\]$ echo "/bin/sed" | sed 's/\\/bin\\/sed/\\/home\\/jerry\\/src\\/sed\\/sed-4.2.2\\/sed/'</span></span>

<img src="data:image/svg+xml;base64," class="r-h7gdob r-10ptun7 r-1vzi8xi" />

Copied!

<span key="cc78879e6c3b405e960f3468952514b2"><span offset-key="cc78879e6c3b405e960f3468952514b2:0">On executing the above code, you get the following result:</span></span>

1

<span key="e023a48f4a524f4ba79f341d9d2c88e6"><span offset-key="e023a48f4a524f4ba79f341d9d2c88e6:0">/home/jerry/src/sed/sed-4.2.2/sed</span></span>

<img src="data:image/svg+xml;base64," class="r-h7gdob r-10ptun7 r-1vzi8xi" />

Copied!

<span key="457b2729e4384e9b9549d96eb53d72f1"><span offset-key="457b2729e4384e9b9549d96eb53d72f1:0">We can make this command more readable and easy to understand. Let us use vertical bar(|) as delimiter and see the result.</span></span>

1

<span key="934a4b56fe454e988d75256df6b59406"><span offset-key="934a4b56fe454e988d75256df6b59406:0">\[jerry\]$ echo "/bin/sed" | sed 's|/bin/sed|/home/jerry/src/sed/sed-4.2.2/sed|'</span></span>

<img src="data:image/svg+xml;base64," class="r-h7gdob r-10ptun7 r-1vzi8xi" />

Copied!

<span key="ea36edb882e240b6ae4d7e92dc880213"><span offset-key="ea36edb882e240b6ae4d7e92dc880213:0">On executing the above code, you get the following result:</span></span>

1

<span key="0f7072e79ea248a49ff813a47e4845e8"><span offset-key="0f7072e79ea248a49ff813a47e4845e8:0">/home/jerry/src/sed/sed-4.2.2/sed</span></span>

<img src="data:image/svg+xml;base64," class="r-h7gdob r-10ptun7 r-1vzi8xi" />

Copied!

<span key="7ae26bb7c3ed482aa63a6ab99f7ff84e"><span offset-key="7ae26bb7c3ed482aa63a6ab99f7ff84e:0">Indeed! We got the same result and the syntax is more readable. Similarly, we can use the "at" sign (@) as a delimiter as follows:</span></span>

1

<span key="4f69e9c6738f465fb3795b7cf6672cd9"><span offset-key="4f69e9c6738f465fb3795b7cf6672cd9:0">\[jerry\]$ echo "/bin/sed" | sed '<a href="../../../../cdn-cgi/l/email-protection.html" class="__cf_email__">[email protected]</a>/bin/<a href="../../../../cdn-cgi/l/email-protection.html" class="__cf_email__">[email protected]</a>/home/jerry/src/sed/sed-4.2.2/<a href="../../../../cdn-cgi/l/email-protection.html" class="__cf_email__">[email protected]</a>'</span></span>

<img src="data:image/svg+xml;base64," class="r-h7gdob r-10ptun7 r-1vzi8xi" />

Copied!

<span key="dd72e4865af04e189392308e999aa9fd"><span offset-key="dd72e4865af04e189392308e999aa9fd:0">On executing the above code, you get the following result:</span></span>

1

<span key="86576280a98540b59ca9a8eaaa130bbe"><span offset-key="86576280a98540b59ca9a8eaaa130bbe:0">/home/jerry/src/sed/sed-4.2.2/sed</span></span>

<img src="data:image/svg+xml;base64," class="r-h7gdob r-10ptun7 r-1vzi8xi" />

Copied!

<span key="d22c2718ad7d4bfea8f86a2463b4329b"><span offset-key="d22c2718ad7d4bfea8f86a2463b4329b:0">In addition to this, we can use caret(^) as a delimiter.</span></span>

1

<span key="e582db688bc7452fbadf8a760b322db5"><span offset-key="e582db688bc7452fbadf8a760b322db5:0">\[jerry\]$ echo "/bin/sed" | sed 's^/bin/sed^/home/jerry/src/sed/sed-4.2.2/sed^'</span></span>

<img src="data:image/svg+xml;base64," class="r-h7gdob r-10ptun7 r-1vzi8xi" />

Copied!

<span key="22fd6df4e4984646b6c8bea7ab6370d4"><span offset-key="22fd6df4e4984646b6c8bea7ab6370d4:0">On executing the above code, you get the following result:</span></span>

1

<span key="d8b8d8155c3346928675366ff4459a9e"><span offset-key="d8b8d8155c3346928675366ff4459a9e:0">/home/jerry/src/sed/sed-4.2.2/sed</span></span>

<img src="data:image/svg+xml;base64," class="r-h7gdob r-10ptun7 r-1vzi8xi" />

Copied!

<span key="769c71618d66431e874819308fb18da4"><span offset-key="769c71618d66431e874819308fb18da4:0">We can also use exclamation mark (!) as a delimiter as follows:</span></span>

1

<span key="5473bfef52734b4f8d0f04d71a22f603"><span offset-key="5473bfef52734b4f8d0f04d71a22f603:0">\[jerry\]$ echo "/bin/sed" | sed 's!/bin/sed!/home/jerry/src/sed/sed-4.2.2/sed!'</span></span>

<img src="data:image/svg+xml;base64," class="r-h7gdob r-10ptun7 r-1vzi8xi" />

Copied!

<span key="6ae9d160d69b472ebc5cb5fd2ee742bb"><span offset-key="6ae9d160d69b472ebc5cb5fd2ee742bb:0">On executing the above code, you get the following result:</span></span>

1

<span key="200cc53559734e8c8184bc9511ec9f09"><span offset-key="200cc53559734e8c8184bc9511ec9f09:0">/home/jerry/src/sed/sed-4.2.2/sed</span></span>

<img src="data:image/svg+xml;base64," class="r-h7gdob r-10ptun7 r-1vzi8xi" />

Copied!

<span key="8a1c0ba3a1904156aea7be12c5d36af9"><span offset-key="8a1c0ba3a1904156aea7be12c5d36af9:0">Generally, backslash(/) is used as a delimiter but sometimes it is more convenient to use other supported delimiters with SED.</span></span>

## 

<span key="07c733c967ae41e581c8d0ec6e4e9be7"><span offset-key="07c733c967ae41e581c8d0ec6e4e9be7:0">Creating a Substring</span></span>

<span key="bee74591d0b64a8da2996fbef1e205db"><span offset-key="bee74591d0b64a8da2996fbef1e205db:0">We learnt the powerful substitute command. Let us see if we can find a substring from a matched text. Let us understand how to do it with the help of an example.</span></span>

<span key="32acbd8e326643d2b9216eb7ca1e7b35"><span offset-key="32acbd8e326643d2b9216eb7ca1e7b35:0">Let us consider the following text:</span></span>

1

<span key="29c8f207962f4e0a96bf295f165ec7c9"><span offset-key="29c8f207962f4e0a96bf295f165ec7c9:0">\[jerry\]$ echo "Three One Two"</span></span>

<img src="data:image/svg+xml;base64," class="r-h7gdob r-10ptun7 r-1vzi8xi" />

Copied!

<span key="30ea5b45f17d47ec83d38c7149c83a96"><span offset-key="30ea5b45f17d47ec83d38c7149c83a96:0">Suppose we have to arrange it into a sequence. Means, it should print One first, then Two, and finally Three. The following one-liner does the needful.</span></span>

1

<span key="b076f9b6a8f84e9289d1f0ad63c9f732"><span offset-key="b076f9b6a8f84e9289d1f0ad63c9f732:0">echo "Three One Two" | sed 's|\\(\\w\\+\\) \\(\\w\\+\\) \\(\\w\\+\\)|\\2 \\3 \\1|'</span></span>

<img src="data:image/svg+xml;base64," class="r-h7gdob r-10ptun7 r-1vzi8xi" />

Copied!

<span key="3c9b080b7e2440fabb655f5da4222c95"><span offset-key="3c9b080b7e2440fabb655f5da4222c95:0">Note that in the above example, vertical bar (|) is used as a delimiter.</span></span>

<span key="eef87a49f5824ed4be20c737c885ec1d"><span offset-key="eef87a49f5824ed4be20c737c885ec1d:0">In SED, substrings can be specified by using a grouping operator and it must be prefixed with an escape character, i.e., </span>**\\(**<span offset-key="eef87a49f5824ed4be20c737c885ec1d:2"> and </span>**\\)**<span offset-key="eef87a49f5824ed4be20c737c885ec1d:4">.</span></span>

<span key="d8dbfbaa708d4f3a9a2a9539b067d66c">**\\w**<span offset-key="d8dbfbaa708d4f3a9a2a9539b067d66c:1"> is a regular expression that matches any letter, digit, or underscore and "+" is used to match more than one characters. In other words, the regular expression </span>**\\(\\w\\+\\)**<span offset-key="d8dbfbaa708d4f3a9a2a9539b067d66c:3"> matches the single word from the input string.</span></span>

<span key="270f1d8aaa1b4892befd8325fe3a631d"><span offset-key="270f1d8aaa1b4892befd8325fe3a631d:0">In the input string, there are three words separated by space, hence there are </span>**three**<span offset-key="270f1d8aaa1b4892befd8325fe3a631d:2"> regular expressions separated by space. The first regular expression stores the first word, i.e.,Three, the second stores the word </span>**One**<span offset-key="270f1d8aaa1b4892befd8325fe3a631d:4">, and the third stores the word </span>**Two**</span>

<span key="ba6daca39d4942678aa756adc32bd847"><span offset-key="ba6daca39d4942678aa756adc32bd847:0">These substrings are referred by </span>**\\N,**<span offset-key="ba6daca39d4942678aa756adc32bd847:2"> where N is the substring number. Hence, </span>**\\2**<span offset-key="ba6daca39d4942678aa756adc32bd847:4"> prints the second substring, i.e., </span>**One; \\3**<span offset-key="ba6daca39d4942678aa756adc32bd847:6"> prints the third substring, i.e., </span>**Two;**<span offset-key="ba6daca39d4942678aa756adc32bd847:8"> and </span>**\\1**<span offset-key="ba6daca39d4942678aa756adc32bd847:10"> prints the first substring, i.e., </span>**Three**</span>

<span key="f0ab32eaf1ea45c695a6acf3fb0c8b01"><span offset-key="f0ab32eaf1ea45c695a6acf3fb0c8b01:0">Let us separate these words by commas(,) and modify the regular expression accordingly.</span></span>

1

<span key="f058ee56790b4f36a5452f28dad2ea2f"><span offset-key="f058ee56790b4f36a5452f28dad2ea2f:0">\[jerry\]$ echo "Three,One,Two" | sed 's|\\(\\w\\+\\),\\(\\w\\+\\),\\(\\w\\+\\)|\\2,\\3,\\1|'</span></span>

<img src="data:image/svg+xml;base64," class="r-h7gdob r-10ptun7 r-1vzi8xi" />

Copied!

<span key="b6e4867425e245d89631c294a326418c"><span offset-key="b6e4867425e245d89631c294a326418c:0">On executing the above code, you get the following result:</span></span>

1

<span key="b87e5186958d4254abafbf63527aa628"><span offset-key="b87e5186958d4254abafbf63527aa628:0">One,Two,Three</span></span>

<img src="data:image/svg+xml;base64," class="r-h7gdob r-10ptun7 r-1vzi8xi" />

Copied!

<span key="b171caa5c27a4dc8a366fa9b3e821925"><span offset-key="b171caa5c27a4dc8a366fa9b3e821925:0">Note that now there is comma(,) instead of space in the regular expression.</span></span>

## 

<span key="be8285415f09496d85cc612fbb2d78b3"><span offset-key="be8285415f09496d85cc612fbb2d78b3:0">String Replacement Flags (GNU SED only)</span></span>

<span key="14f07f63b0d04c4397c05b174d9ca540"><span offset-key="14f07f63b0d04c4397c05b174d9ca540:0">In the previous section, we saw some examples of the substitution command. The GNU SED provides some special escape sequences which can be used in the replacement string. Note that these string replacement flags are GNU specific and may not work with other variants of SED. Here we will discuss string replacement flags.</span></span>

-   <img src="data:image/svg+xml;base64," class="r-1nf4jbm r-1vzi8xi" />

    <span key="0a5e5c20a24b4606bd4f4d49ba8b1065"><span offset-key="0a5e5c20a24b4606bd4f4d49ba8b1065:0">\\L: When \\L is specified in the replacement string, it treats all the remaining characters of the the word after \\L as lowercase characters. For example, the characters "ULO" are treated as lowercase characters.</span></span>

1

<span key="5f85b7e56a894903862b538be994be91"><span offset-key="5f85b7e56a894903862b538be994be91:0">\[jerry\]$ sed -n 's/Paulo/PA\\LULO/p' books.txt</span></span>

<img src="data:image/svg+xml;base64," class="r-h7gdob r-10ptun7 r-1vzi8xi" />

Copied!

<span key="ea02b85058c54c62aac9d4cf312964f2"><span offset-key="ea02b85058c54c62aac9d4cf312964f2:0">On executing the above code, you get the following result:</span></span>

1

<span key="c12e1050eed2433e856324979eb24521"><span offset-key="c12e1050eed2433e856324979eb24521:0">3) The Alchemist, PAulo Coelho, 197</span></span>

2

<span key="382464ee81234c738281f181d31253b9"><span offset-key="382464ee81234c738281f181d31253b9:0">5) The Pilgrimage, PAulo Coelho, 288</span></span>

<img src="data:image/svg+xml;base64," class="r-h7gdob r-10ptun7 r-1vzi8xi" />

Copied!

-   <img src="data:image/svg+xml;base64," class="r-1nf4jbm r-1vzi8xi" />

    <span key="9a5cbc1734144ccc9700996520e97f6e"><span offset-key="9a5cbc1734144ccc9700996520e97f6e:0">\\u: When \\u is specified in the replacement string, it treats the immediate character after \\u as an uppercase character. In the following example, \\u is used before the characters 'a' and 'o'. Hence SED treats these characters as uppercase letters.</span></span>

1

<span key="a3a846a7ba9e4920883e77c063ed709b"><span offset-key="a3a846a7ba9e4920883e77c063ed709b:0">\[jerry\]$ sed -n 's/Paulo/p\\uaul\\uo/p' books.txt</span></span>

<img src="data:image/svg+xml;base64," class="r-h7gdob r-10ptun7 r-1vzi8xi" />

Copied!

<span key="de9b65977b3f4ec89f9d7d98c7e463d5"><span offset-key="de9b65977b3f4ec89f9d7d98c7e463d5:0">On executing the above code, you get the following result:</span></span>

1

<span key="0c9111daab2d48a8836b610451d832c1"><span offset-key="0c9111daab2d48a8836b610451d832c1:0">3) The Alchemist, pAulO Coelho, 197</span></span>

2

<span key="a0a429368b6e427c888eec4008eef0a7"><span offset-key="a0a429368b6e427c888eec4008eef0a7:0">5) The Pilgrimage, pAulO Coelho, 288</span></span>

<img src="data:image/svg+xml;base64," class="r-h7gdob r-10ptun7 r-1vzi8xi" />

Copied!

-   <img src="data:image/svg+xml;base64," class="r-1nf4jbm r-1vzi8xi" />

    <span key="3394e478cec94e32bfe71d3e7b1e3aa2"><span offset-key="3394e478cec94e32bfe71d3e7b1e3aa2:0">\\U: When \\U is specified in the replacement string, it treats all the remaining characters of the the word after \\U as uppercase characters.</span></span>

1

<span key="19fc01e31c214266a3070b59077a0901"><span offset-key="19fc01e31c214266a3070b59077a0901:0">\[jerry\]$ sed -n 's/Paulo/\\Upaulo/p' books.txt</span></span>

<img src="data:image/svg+xml;base64," class="r-h7gdob r-10ptun7 r-1vzi8xi" />

Copied!

<span key="015e3d0956bb47b6bc74e839fde6cc49"><span offset-key="015e3d0956bb47b6bc74e839fde6cc49:0">On executing the above code, you get the following result:</span></span>

1

<span key="7bea9d5b95c8477aa986a004f9cbaa23"><span offset-key="7bea9d5b95c8477aa986a004f9cbaa23:0">3) The Alchemist, PAULO Coelho, 197</span></span>

2

<span key="87156ca7e2034ff08e0adb0406f89adf"><span offset-key="87156ca7e2034ff08e0adb0406f89adf:0">5) The Pilgrimage, PAULO Coelho, 288</span></span>

<img src="data:image/svg+xml;base64," class="r-h7gdob r-10ptun7 r-1vzi8xi" />

Copied!

-   <img src="data:image/svg+xml;base64," class="r-1nf4jbm r-1vzi8xi" />

    <span key="25989b8bf9604c30ad6182f701dfa0d1"><span offset-key="25989b8bf9604c30ad6182f701dfa0d1:0">\\E: This flag should be used with \\L or \\U. It stops the conversion initiated by the flag \\L or \\U. In the following example, only the first word is replaced with uppercase letters.</span></span>

1

<span key="5fbd4e31e6674e999d4f7bebedb78607"><span offset-key="5fbd4e31e6674e999d4f7bebedb78607:0">\[jerry\]$ sed -n 's/Paulo Coelho/\\Upaulo \\Ecoelho/p' books.txt</span></span>

<img src="data:image/svg+xml;base64," class="r-h7gdob r-10ptun7 r-1vzi8xi" />

Copied!

<span key="eaff93262e5c42ce846779fff981b81a"><span offset-key="eaff93262e5c42ce846779fff981b81a:0">On executing the above code, you get the following result:</span></span>

1

<span key="9de68423c56e4bd59af3a62a71ecc611"><span offset-key="9de68423c56e4bd59af3a62a71ecc611:0">3) The Alchemist, PAULO coelho, 197</span></span>

2

<span key="07e93086e92847e794e3cfbcf4a362fd"><span offset-key="07e93086e92847e794e3cfbcf4a362fd:0">5) The Pilgrimage, PAULO coelho, 288</span></span>

<img src="data:image/svg+xml;base64," class="r-h7gdob r-10ptun7 r-1vzi8xi" />

Copied!

# 

<span key="afe8a8664f5c41d99f4a1e5617d17484"><span offset-key="afe8a8664f5c41d99f4a1e5617d17484:0">Stream Editor - Managing Patterns</span></span>

<span key="71a3650293ea4ef897169e82acf17196"><span offset-key="71a3650293ea4ef897169e82acf17196:0">We have already discussed the use of pattern and hold buffer. In this chapter, we are going to explore more about their usage. Let us discuss the </span>**n**<span offset-key="71a3650293ea4ef897169e82acf17196:2"> command which prints the pattern space. It will be used in conjunction with other commands. Given below is the syntax of then command.</span></span>

1

<span key="3c8d02b5c8864db086b9c0929eff3a73"><span offset-key="3c8d02b5c8864db086b9c0929eff3a73:0">\[address1\[,address2\]\]n</span></span>

<img src="data:image/svg+xml;base64," class="r-h7gdob r-10ptun7 r-1vzi8xi" />

Copied!

<span key="e7e5b118957f4c73bfc2a59ae3600cc3"><span offset-key="e7e5b118957f4c73bfc2a59ae3600cc3:0">Let us take an example.</span></span>

1

<span key="85baba0635e54d97925de56925ed7948"><span offset-key="85baba0635e54d97925de56925ed7948:0">\[jerry\]$ sed 'n' books.txt</span></span>

<img src="data:image/svg+xml;base64," class="r-h7gdob r-10ptun7 r-1vzi8xi" />

Copied!

<span key="900a483e2b3249939086d55fb9c5d697"><span offset-key="900a483e2b3249939086d55fb9c5d697:0">When the above code is executed, it will produce the following result:</span></span>

1

<span key="478e428dea5c4a23b67bf921424cef47"><span offset-key="478e428dea5c4a23b67bf921424cef47:0">1) A Storm of Swords, George R. R. Martin, 1216</span></span>

2

<span key="61e094b5bcb2475b94eda70017458428"><span offset-key="61e094b5bcb2475b94eda70017458428:0">2) The Two Towers, J. R. R. Tolkien, 352</span></span>

3

<span key="01e7520553c84f5790ec5430790f100a"><span offset-key="01e7520553c84f5790ec5430790f100a:0">3) The Alchemist, Paulo Coelho, 197</span></span>

4

<span key="74e46e778e734c1ea1014e379e3984e6"><span offset-key="74e46e778e734c1ea1014e379e3984e6:0">4) The Fellowship of the Ring, J. R. R. Tolkien, 432</span></span>

5

<span key="0c2b0d0c2a464554ae882509ef55884c"><span offset-key="0c2b0d0c2a464554ae882509ef55884c:0">5) The Pilgrimage, Paulo Coelho, 288</span></span>

6

<span key="84590c7d84864501a4503899ba2ca021"><span offset-key="84590c7d84864501a4503899ba2ca021:0">6) A Game of Thrones, George R. R. Martin, 864</span></span>

<img src="data:image/svg+xml;base64," class="r-h7gdob r-10ptun7 r-1vzi8xi" />

Copied!

<span key="8d586efb93724ac1a3c3ee7f10f8afb1"><span offset-key="8d586efb93724ac1a3c3ee7f10f8afb1:0">The </span>**n**<span offset-key="8d586efb93724ac1a3c3ee7f10f8afb1:2"> command prints the contents of the pattern buffer, clears the pattern buffer, fetches the next line into the pattern buffer, and applies commands on it.</span></span>

<span key="d1db148296ab46f98ba5b59663f769ad"><span offset-key="d1db148296ab46f98ba5b59663f769ad:0">Let us consider there are three SED commands before </span>**n**<span offset-key="d1db148296ab46f98ba5b59663f769ad:2"> and two SED commands after </span>**n**<span offset-key="d1db148296ab46f98ba5b59663f769ad:4"> as follows:</span></span>

1

<span key="46b033b6e6d542478a8e82646f2d2859"><span offset-key="46b033b6e6d542478a8e82646f2d2859:0">Sed command #1</span></span>

2

<span key="bd9f41d16d1640a2aeb9b1454cf50392"><span offset-key="bd9f41d16d1640a2aeb9b1454cf50392:0">Sed command #2</span></span>

3

<span key="84206ab5464441db88d39d6118a7488d"><span offset-key="84206ab5464441db88d39d6118a7488d:0">Sed command #3</span></span>

4

<span key="4dee047c7b4642279f0b07a66b8af50c"><span offset-key="4dee047c7b4642279f0b07a66b8af50c:0">n command</span></span>

5

<span key="d51b9a410d5d43a7898460ef570401bc"><span offset-key="d51b9a410d5d43a7898460ef570401bc:0">Sed command #4</span></span>

6

<span key="bdc1e200967c48e89acabb4d021bc57d"><span offset-key="bdc1e200967c48e89acabb4d021bc57d:0">Sed command #5</span></span>

<img src="data:image/svg+xml;base64," class="r-h7gdob r-10ptun7 r-1vzi8xi" />

Copied!

<span key="14354e2e078a4c53bfc25e10d089a340"><span offset-key="14354e2e078a4c53bfc25e10d089a340:0">In this case, SED applies the first three commands on the pattern buffer, clears the pattern buffer, fetches the next line into the pattern buffer, and thereafter applies the fourth and fifth commands on it. This is a very important concept. Do not go ahead without having a clear understanding of this.</span></span>

<span key="a05c66cf4c644924aaa343c9d34c069f"><span offset-key="a05c66cf4c644924aaa343c9d34c069f:0">The hold buffer holds data, but SED commands cannot be applied directly on the hold buffer. Hence, we need to bring the hold buffer data into the pattern buffer. SED provides the </span>**x**<span offset-key="a05c66cf4c644924aaa343c9d34c069f:2"> command to exchange the contents of pattern and hold buffers. The following commands illustrate the </span>**x**<span offset-key="a05c66cf4c644924aaa343c9d34c069f:4"> command.</span></span>

<span key="177c2a1737d14665995e616f25cf9e9d"><span offset-key="177c2a1737d14665995e616f25cf9e9d:0">Let us slightly modify the books.txt file. Say, the file contains book titles followed by their author names. After modification, the file should look like this:</span></span>

1

<span key="3cc8dced32a94b6495e863d193da7708"><span offset-key="3cc8dced32a94b6495e863d193da7708:0">\[jerry\]$ cat books.txt</span></span>

<img src="data:image/svg+xml;base64," class="r-h7gdob r-10ptun7 r-1vzi8xi" />

Copied!

<span key="618844551dc6466792026d848f881f66"><span offset-key="618844551dc6466792026d848f881f66:0">On executing the above code, you get the following result:</span></span>

1

<span key="74353b9612d6424faf4ce88f96f3df58"><span offset-key="74353b9612d6424faf4ce88f96f3df58:0">A Storm of Swords</span></span>

2

<span key="99510d4b95c14e6cb56f30f6982730b8"><span offset-key="99510d4b95c14e6cb56f30f6982730b8:0">George R. R. Martin</span></span>

3

<span key="df595ca85901433a9ff8311335b501bb"><span offset-key="df595ca85901433a9ff8311335b501bb:0">The Two Towers</span></span>

4

<span key="62f1fa5fc1554078b8ee79d7e72e5209"><span offset-key="62f1fa5fc1554078b8ee79d7e72e5209:0">J. R. R. Tolkien</span></span>

5

<span key="90cd7e2ac1d3489e8656065b879260c3"><span offset-key="90cd7e2ac1d3489e8656065b879260c3:0">The Alchemist</span></span>

6

<span key="81efa2a07be24125a351df049420ac78"><span offset-key="81efa2a07be24125a351df049420ac78:0">Paulo Coelho</span></span>

7

<span key="630f9356d29f4e2d8f5fb26dce3cc295"><span offset-key="630f9356d29f4e2d8f5fb26dce3cc295:0">The Fellowship of the Ring</span></span>

8

<span key="a55149709d664ff2810f8e2ebbb05c27"><span offset-key="a55149709d664ff2810f8e2ebbb05c27:0">J. R. R. Tolkien</span></span>

9

<span key="a8cda4e93be54bc3918f6e29e35818ef"><span offset-key="a8cda4e93be54bc3918f6e29e35818ef:0">The Pilgrimage</span></span>

10

<span key="5b3c4b59d7564abeb0e1aff0035db579"><span offset-key="5b3c4b59d7564abeb0e1aff0035db579:0">Paulo Coelho</span></span>

11

<span key="61d3b2f0efbb4c7fbd24b94721df8e3a"><span offset-key="61d3b2f0efbb4c7fbd24b94721df8e3a:0">A Game of Thrones</span></span>

12

<span key="9a88c6f2de684cabb1b3788e4af5d94c"><span offset-key="9a88c6f2de684cabb1b3788e4af5d94c:0">George R. R. Martin</span></span>

<img src="data:image/svg+xml;base64," class="r-h7gdob r-10ptun7 r-1vzi8xi" />

Copied!

<span key="b8cd7b1d3c5c438fac4596bd9cdbd829"><span offset-key="b8cd7b1d3c5c438fac4596bd9cdbd829:0">Let us exchange the contents of the two buffers. For instance, the following example prints only the names of authors.</span></span>

1

<span key="35d2e391a45c498f82342e4746cce3c2"><span offset-key="35d2e391a45c498f82342e4746cce3c2:0">\[jerry\]$ sed -n 'x;n;p' books.txt</span></span>

<img src="data:image/svg+xml;base64," class="r-h7gdob r-10ptun7 r-1vzi8xi" />

Copied!

<span key="0adcab0ca79c494ebc7c8dcd8d5f6866"><span offset-key="0adcab0ca79c494ebc7c8dcd8d5f6866:0">On executing the above code, you get the following result:</span></span>

1

<span key="46f2b109b2154302945775818b473908"><span offset-key="46f2b109b2154302945775818b473908:0">George R. R. Martin</span></span>

2

<span key="ffacce1607374d1fa6886392b36b85bb"><span offset-key="ffacce1607374d1fa6886392b36b85bb:0">J. R. R. Tolkien</span></span>

3

<span key="036bf9b5c0454110ac95819fc165e4fe"><span offset-key="036bf9b5c0454110ac95819fc165e4fe:0">Paulo Coelho</span></span>

4

<span key="afc4c740a3c8487085d4f2e1201dd554"><span offset-key="afc4c740a3c8487085d4f2e1201dd554:0">J. R. R. Tolkien</span></span>

5

<span key="fab09a07989d4884abac1a3315befedf"><span offset-key="fab09a07989d4884abac1a3315befedf:0">Paulo Coelho</span></span>

6

<span key="3e9fd42542ac45cba1fcd3082e1ecdc2"><span offset-key="3e9fd42542ac45cba1fcd3082e1ecdc2:0">George R. R. Martin</span></span>

<img src="data:image/svg+xml;base64," class="r-h7gdob r-10ptun7 r-1vzi8xi" />

Copied!

<span key="a353f2c5ec7d4e6a855895203c06d98d"><span offset-key="a353f2c5ec7d4e6a855895203c06d98d:0">Let us understand how this command works.</span></span>

-   <img src="data:image/svg+xml;base64," class="r-1nf4jbm r-1vzi8xi" />

    <span key="990a016e0b7643c89b96dd020cb41adc"><span offset-key="990a016e0b7643c89b96dd020cb41adc:0">Initially, SED reads the first line, i.e., A Storm of Swords into the pattern buffer.</span></span>

-   <img src="data:image/svg+xml;base64," class="r-1nf4jbm r-1vzi8xi" />

    <span key="0aa3265bb2434c30a5769f9ac1dc479c">**x**<span offset-key="0aa3265bb2434c30a5769f9ac1dc479c:1"> command moves this line to the hold buffer.</span></span>

-   <img src="data:image/svg+xml;base64," class="r-1nf4jbm r-1vzi8xi" />

    <span key="640d8db271514a2297c6c3b62d45678d">**n**<span offset-key="640d8db271514a2297c6c3b62d45678d:1"> fetches the next line, i.e., George R. R. Martin into the pattern buffer.</span></span>

-   <img src="data:image/svg+xml;base64," class="r-1nf4jbm r-1vzi8xi" />

    <span key="3b89335bb15a4e999274cc83165d1c6e"><span offset-key="3b89335bb15a4e999274cc83165d1c6e:0">The control passes to the command followed by n which prints the contents of the pattern buffer.</span></span>

-   <img src="data:image/svg+xml;base64," class="r-1nf4jbm r-1vzi8xi" />

    <span key="53d954401ac5456d8f64f0ac1c7424d0"><span offset-key="53d954401ac5456d8f64f0ac1c7424d0:0">The process repeats until the file is exhausted.</span></span>

<span key="ddd3fa46e85c448d8b4bb560a570e321"><span offset-key="ddd3fa46e85c448d8b4bb560a570e321:0">Now let us exchange the contents of the buffers before printing. Guess, what happens? Yes, it prints the titles of books.</span></span>

1

<span key="25edcb347af64980ae5f1d764d01865c"><span offset-key="25edcb347af64980ae5f1d764d01865c:0">\[jerry\]$ sed -n 'x;n;x;p' books.txt</span></span>

<img src="data:image/svg+xml;base64," class="r-h7gdob r-10ptun7 r-1vzi8xi" />

Copied!

<span key="a69c32001f844417859457b80a50b9a7"><span offset-key="a69c32001f844417859457b80a50b9a7:0">On executing the above code, you get the following result:</span></span>

1

<span key="9e36fd5e7940413b928c21eccccb57b1"><span offset-key="9e36fd5e7940413b928c21eccccb57b1:0">A Storm of Swords</span></span>

2

<span key="ce90b487ab1d4d3c8d2195843dd73870"><span offset-key="ce90b487ab1d4d3c8d2195843dd73870:0">The Two Towers</span></span>

3

<span key="7e56b6b326334dbfb76722fe9d48d42f"><span offset-key="7e56b6b326334dbfb76722fe9d48d42f:0">The Alchemist</span></span>

4

<span key="01dc2e92e6684be4bdf5f42b08be4738"><span offset-key="01dc2e92e6684be4bdf5f42b08be4738:0">The Fellowship of the Ring</span></span>

5

<span key="37832bc97e3349b4b046cd02a601c947"><span offset-key="37832bc97e3349b4b046cd02a601c947:0">The Pilgrimage</span></span>

6

<span key="c19c1d9c1d3344a58148458935b23ced"><span offset-key="c19c1d9c1d3344a58148458935b23ced:0">A Game of Thrones</span></span>

<img src="data:image/svg+xml;base64," class="r-h7gdob r-10ptun7 r-1vzi8xi" />

Copied!

<span key="755e682e3aea4496a075b1d3f041c9d2"><span offset-key="755e682e3aea4496a075b1d3f041c9d2:0">The </span>**h**<span offset-key="755e682e3aea4496a075b1d3f041c9d2:2"> command deals with the hold buffer. It copies data from the pattern buffer to the hold buffer. Existing data from the hold buffer gets overwritten. Note that the </span>**h**<span offset-key="755e682e3aea4496a075b1d3f041c9d2:4"> command does not move data, it only copies data. Hence, the copied data remains as it is in the pattern buffer. Given below is the syntax of the </span>**h**<span offset-key="755e682e3aea4496a075b1d3f041c9d2:6"> command.</span></span>

1

<span key="f46e3e8826034d94a602ac0650f3fc90"><span offset-key="f46e3e8826034d94a602ac0650f3fc90:0">\[address1\[,address2\]\]h</span></span>

<img src="data:image/svg+xml;base64," class="r-h7gdob r-10ptun7 r-1vzi8xi" />

Copied!

<span key="9a74af7fb09f4440a97939902705e44c"><span offset-key="9a74af7fb09f4440a97939902705e44c:0">The following command prints only the titles of the author Paulo Coelho.</span></span>

1

<span key="a33a18fbe0854efab265cc792befcd7e"><span offset-key="a33a18fbe0854efab265cc792befcd7e:0">\[jerry\]$ sed -n '/Paulo/!h; /Paulo/{x;p}' books.txt</span></span>

<img src="data:image/svg+xml;base64," class="r-h7gdob r-10ptun7 r-1vzi8xi" />

Copied!

<span key="65b1b77dd90b4c5c9e2faa0af7e20a90"><span offset-key="65b1b77dd90b4c5c9e2faa0af7e20a90:0">On executing the above code, you get the following result:</span></span>

1

<span key="20579be11cc8429190a46b40db2acfba"><span offset-key="20579be11cc8429190a46b40db2acfba:0">The Alchemist</span></span>

2

<span key="26e902bed0214240a08342ff9f967c72"><span offset-key="26e902bed0214240a08342ff9f967c72:0">The Pilgrimage</span></span>

<img src="data:image/svg+xml;base64," class="r-h7gdob r-10ptun7 r-1vzi8xi" />

Copied!

<span key="9254c32c83a1458fb8bd6a0b974e7ed5"><span offset-key="9254c32c83a1458fb8bd6a0b974e7ed5:0">Let us understand how the above command works. The contents of books.txt follow a specific format. The first line is the book title followed by the author of the book. In the above command, "!" is used to reverse the condition, i.e., line is copied to the hold buffer only when a pattern match does not succeed. And curly braces {} are used to group multiple SED commands</span></span>

<span key="1d15b6c981cf48a1a3d48e4601342496"><span offset-key="1d15b6c981cf48a1a3d48e4601342496:0">In the first pass of the command, SED reads the first line, i.e., A Storm of Swords into the pattern buffer and checks whether it contains the pattern Paulo or not. As the pattern match does not succeed, it copies this line to the hold buffer. Now both the pattern buffer and the hold buffer contain the same line i.e., A Storm of Swords. In the second step, it checks whether the line contains the pattern Paulo or not. As the pattern does not match, it does not do anything.</span></span>

<span key="1e2de383cd4e4d14932ab75ba78f9b2a"><span offset-key="1e2de383cd4e4d14932ab75ba78f9b2a:0">In second pass, it reads the next line George R. R. Martin into the pattern buffer and applies the same steps. For the next three lines, it does the same thing. At the end of the fifth pass, both the buffers contain The Alchemist. At the start of the sixth pass, it reads the line Paulo Coelho and as the pattern matches, it does not copy this line into the hold buffer. Hence, the pattern buffer contains Paulo Coelho, and the hold buffer contains The Alchemist.</span></span>

<span key="2ead8fd0f4be4ce583b61297d0043113"><span offset-key="2ead8fd0f4be4ce583b61297d0043113:0">Thereafter, it checks whether the pattern buffer contains the pattern Paulo. As the pattern match succeeds, it exchanges the contents of the pattern buffer with the hold buffer. Now the pattern buffer contains The Alchemist and the hold buffer contains Paulo Coelho. Finally, it prints the contents of the pattern buffer. The same steps are applied to the pattern The Pilgrimage.</span></span>

<span key="b92f034120cd41e28ca1af70014a24e7"><span offset-key="b92f034120cd41e28ca1af70014a24e7:0">The </span>**h**<span offset-key="b92f034120cd41e28ca1af70014a24e7:2"> command destroys the previous contents of the hold buffer. This is not always acceptable, as sometimes we need to preserve the contents. For this purpose, SED provides the </span>**H**<span offset-key="b92f034120cd41e28ca1af70014a24e7:4"> command which appends the contents to the hold buffer by adding a new line at the end. The only difference between </span>**h**<span offset-key="b92f034120cd41e28ca1af70014a24e7:6"> and </span>**H**<span offset-key="b92f034120cd41e28ca1af70014a24e7:8"> command is, the former overwrites data from the hold buffer, while the later appends data to the hold buffer. Its syntax is similar to the </span>**h**<span offset-key="b92f034120cd41e28ca1af70014a24e7:10"> command.</span></span>

1

<span key="00e1b2a8081c4b2c85a02916a79d9ee5"><span offset-key="00e1b2a8081c4b2c85a02916a79d9ee5:0">\[address1\[,address2\]\]H</span></span>

<img src="data:image/svg+xml;base64," class="r-h7gdob r-10ptun7 r-1vzi8xi" />

Copied!

<span key="45091578a8e34d1d87e3c5b9bef9f49b"><span offset-key="45091578a8e34d1d87e3c5b9bef9f49b:0">Let us take another example. This time, instead of printing only book titles, print the names of their authors too. The following example prints the book titles followed by their author names.</span></span>

1

<span key="5d7e7da0360d4fed8caa609cf6ec909b"><span offset-key="5d7e7da0360d4fed8caa609cf6ec909b:0">\[jerry\]$ sed -n '/Paulo/!h; /Paulo/{H;x;p}' books.txt</span></span>

<img src="data:image/svg+xml;base64," class="r-h7gdob r-10ptun7 r-1vzi8xi" />

Copied!

<span key="e5e1d1f80d60452591a87d913bceb21c"><span offset-key="e5e1d1f80d60452591a87d913bceb21c:0">On executing the above code, you get the following result:</span></span>

1

<span key="47ff1e56b1fb4577b78d2baaeca3d33d"><span offset-key="47ff1e56b1fb4577b78d2baaeca3d33d:0">The Alchemist</span></span>

2

<span key="dcf559e6dba84796960eb4c4de5b782b"><span offset-key="dcf559e6dba84796960eb4c4de5b782b:0">Paulo Coelho</span></span>

3

<span key="3372013e7bc94ff6aaf36d04141b2533"><span offset-key="3372013e7bc94ff6aaf36d04141b2533:0">The Pilgrimage</span></span>

4

<span key="4bafd648dac24bb2adfc7459ee5fab52"><span offset-key="4bafd648dac24bb2adfc7459ee5fab52:0">Paulo Coelho</span></span>

<img src="data:image/svg+xml;base64," class="r-h7gdob r-10ptun7 r-1vzi8xi" />

Copied!

<span key="504c36549d8e43748e492c4ae5f3a095"><span offset-key="504c36549d8e43748e492c4ae5f3a095:0">We learnt how to copy/append the contents of pattern buffer to hold buffer. Can we perform the reverse function as well? Yes certainly! For this purpose, SED provides the </span>**g**<span offset-key="504c36549d8e43748e492c4ae5f3a095:2"> command which copies data from the hold buffer to the pattern buffer. While copying, existing data from the pattern space gets overwritten. Given below is the syntax of the </span>**g**<span offset-key="504c36549d8e43748e492c4ae5f3a095:4"> command.</span></span>

1

<span key="87e389b4fb57463c93cb81034cc78b61"><span offset-key="87e389b4fb57463c93cb81034cc78b61:0">\[address1\[,address2\]\]g</span></span>

<img src="data:image/svg+xml;base64," class="r-h7gdob r-10ptun7 r-1vzi8xi" />

Copied!

<span key="2635610463d1467790889f40dfe1640b"><span offset-key="2635610463d1467790889f40dfe1640b:0">Let us consider the same example - printing book titles and their authors. This time, we will first print the name of the author and on the next line, the corresponding book title. The following command prints the name of the author Paulo Coelho, followed by its book title.</span></span>

1

<span key="87240d95be144802b787f46abcc0821b"><span offset-key="87240d95be144802b787f46abcc0821b:0">\[jerry\]$ sed -n '/Paulo/!h; /Paulo/{p;g;p}' books.txt</span></span>

<img src="data:image/svg+xml;base64," class="r-h7gdob r-10ptun7 r-1vzi8xi" />

Copied!

<span key="83fe82de07614ecd94b95fcac1758855"><span offset-key="83fe82de07614ecd94b95fcac1758855:0">On executing the above code, you get the following result:</span></span>

1

<span key="9fa2507c93db4d09989b6922381422d4"><span offset-key="9fa2507c93db4d09989b6922381422d4:0">Paulo Coelho</span></span>

2

<span key="c5fae19f36a0437b83f13a2f8e04459c"><span offset-key="c5fae19f36a0437b83f13a2f8e04459c:0">The Alchemist</span></span>

3

<span key="178769d4080b4c1c817fc0bc8f359f8b"><span offset-key="178769d4080b4c1c817fc0bc8f359f8b:0">Paulo Coelho</span></span>

4

<span key="df9b0627d1fb43199829b2db50ce6fb1"><span offset-key="df9b0627d1fb43199829b2db50ce6fb1:0">The Pilgrimage</span></span>

<img src="data:image/svg+xml;base64," class="r-h7gdob r-10ptun7 r-1vzi8xi" />

Copied!

<span key="32ff46ca53174b30896e79509b668bfd"><span offset-key="32ff46ca53174b30896e79509b668bfd:0">The first command is kept as it is. At the end of fifth pass, both the buffers contain The Alchemist. At the start of the sixth pass, it reads the line Paulo Coelho and as the pattern matches, it does not copy this line into the hold buffer. Hence, the pattern space containsPaulo Coelho and the hold space contains The Alchemist.</span></span>

<span key="409f436ca504420bbf200225cd36ef64"><span offset-key="409f436ca504420bbf200225cd36ef64:0">Thereafter, it checks whether the pattern space contains the pattern Paulo. As the pattern match succeeds, it first prints the contents of the pattern space, i.e., Paulo Coelho, then it copies the hold buffer to the pattern buffer. Hence, both the pattern and hold buffers contain The Alchemist. Finally, it prints the contents of the pattern buffer. The same steps are applied to the pattern The Pilgrimage.</span></span>

<span key="e5a418eca26e4489b4a645ec4a46d5f8"><span offset-key="e5a418eca26e4489b4a645ec4a46d5f8:0">Similarly, we can append the contents of the hold buffer to the pattern buffer. SED provides the </span>**G**<span offset-key="e5a418eca26e4489b4a645ec4a46d5f8:2"> command which appends the contents to the pattern buffer by adding a new line at the end.</span></span>

1

<span key="9db65632d02d492689fc992be26079ac"><span offset-key="9db65632d02d492689fc992be26079ac:0">\[address1\[,address2\]\]G</span></span>

<img src="data:image/svg+xml;base64," class="r-h7gdob r-10ptun7 r-1vzi8xi" />

Copied!

<span key="66b347786d6d4601a5409a3ef42cb003"><span offset-key="66b347786d6d4601a5409a3ef42cb003:0">Now let us take the previous example which prints the name of author Paulo Coelhofollowed by its book title. To achieve the same result, execute the following SED command.</span></span>

1

<span key="e9e7c5d52f3046df8dc56abd0d28d22b"><span offset-key="e9e7c5d52f3046df8dc56abd0d28d22b:0">\[jerry\]$ sed -n '/Paulo/!h; /Paulo/{G;p}' books.txt</span></span>

<img src="data:image/svg+xml;base64," class="r-h7gdob r-10ptun7 r-1vzi8xi" />

Copied!

<span key="d1a864d7343e41a38fc5d1e58407e5ff"><span offset-key="d1a864d7343e41a38fc5d1e58407e5ff:0">On executing the above code, you get the following result:</span></span>

1

<span key="95c3792f2a004722a6abc1a3b48a4631"><span offset-key="95c3792f2a004722a6abc1a3b48a4631:0">Paulo Coelho</span></span>

2

<span key="d9353fa134124686ab0b690e009de039"><span offset-key="d9353fa134124686ab0b690e009de039:0">The Alchemist</span></span>

3

<span key="edb2584af18d48b3885a1469e082eba5"><span offset-key="edb2584af18d48b3885a1469e082eba5:0">Paulo Coelho</span></span>

4

<span key="30c81403c8eb44ee9b6e93670bd4eb13"><span offset-key="30c81403c8eb44ee9b6e93670bd4eb13:0">The Pilgrimage</span></span>

<img src="data:image/svg+xml;base64," class="r-h7gdob r-10ptun7 r-1vzi8xi" />

Copied!

<span key="becd9c2d694543c2a5c37250aa38e749"><span offset-key="becd9c2d694543c2a5c37250aa38e749:0">Can you modify the above example to display the book titles followed by their authors? Simple, just exchange the buffer contents before the </span>**G**<span offset-key="becd9c2d694543c2a5c37250aa38e749:2"> command.</span></span>

1

<span key="9302b27c5d4046268b7c518751ce2526"><span offset-key="9302b27c5d4046268b7c518751ce2526:0">\[jerry\]$ sed -n '/Paulo/!h; /Paulo/{x;G;p}' books.txt</span></span>

<img src="data:image/svg+xml;base64," class="r-h7gdob r-10ptun7 r-1vzi8xi" />

Copied!

<span key="59f9d3e879674ca9bcecbdb8782d1935"><span offset-key="59f9d3e879674ca9bcecbdb8782d1935:0">On executing the above code, you get the following result:</span></span>

1

<span key="7dcec96426434056b3dbe7186b0a3c31"><span offset-key="7dcec96426434056b3dbe7186b0a3c31:0">The Alchemist</span></span>

2

<span key="859ba3cf227446809e4e4862529fe0ba"><span offset-key="859ba3cf227446809e4e4862529fe0ba:0">Paulo Coelho</span></span>

3

<span key="95a6429a5660454aa63f1cc4d7138d70"><span offset-key="95a6429a5660454aa63f1cc4d7138d70:0">The Pilgrimage</span></span>

4

<span key="4c1d8e89c0324fa9a9a2863d2ca6af46"><span offset-key="4c1d8e89c0324fa9a9a2863d2ca6af46:0">Paulo Coelho</span></span>

<img src="data:image/svg+xml;base64," class="r-h7gdob r-10ptun7 r-1vzi8xi" />

Copied!

# 

<span key="ca578907b8e942d3b9b649d01a752f6b"><span offset-key="ca578907b8e942d3b9b649d01a752f6b:0">Stream Editor - Regular Expressions</span></span>

<span key="536bacbe169f41de98e105304ec31e81"><span offset-key="536bacbe169f41de98e105304ec31e81:0">It is the regular expressions that make SED powerful and efficient. A number of complex tasks can be solved with regular expressions. Any command-line expert knows the power of regular expressions.</span></span>

<span key="f424a0750da0405780a9993cf3f60e42"><span offset-key="f424a0750da0405780a9993cf3f60e42:0">Like many other GNU/Linux utilities, SED too supports regular expressions, which are often referred to as as </span>**regex**<span offset-key="f424a0750da0405780a9993cf3f60e42:2">. This chapter describes regular expressions in detail. The chapter is divided into three sections: Standard regular expressions, POSIX classes of regular expressions, and Meta characters.</span></span>

## 

<span key="36de582e06cd44609794c36e9cbcc4c9"><span offset-key="36de582e06cd44609794c36e9cbcc4c9:0">Standard Regular Expressions</span></span>

### 

<span key="7e1e01e7d6af40ac9c5d98dfbd42c873"><span offset-key="7e1e01e7d6af40ac9c5d98dfbd42c873:0">Start of line (^)</span></span>

<span key="78ca7bbf33614cc39ff893f170fa2d2d"><span offset-key="78ca7bbf33614cc39ff893f170fa2d2d:0">In regular expressions terminology, the caret(^) symbol matches the start of a line. The following example prints all the lines that start with the pattern "The".</span></span>

1

<span key="fde99e771b2d446fb02e5fb989703bb3"><span offset-key="fde99e771b2d446fb02e5fb989703bb3:0">\[jerry\]$ sed -n '/^The/ p' books.txt</span></span>

<img src="data:image/svg+xml;base64," class="r-h7gdob r-10ptun7 r-1vzi8xi" />

Copied!

<span key="188cabfdf46445538066a43a7d0b8be7"><span offset-key="188cabfdf46445538066a43a7d0b8be7:0">On executing the above code, you get the following result:</span></span>

1

<span key="8d2a204e385747a4b90b7214b38b493c"><span offset-key="8d2a204e385747a4b90b7214b38b493c:0">The Two Towers, J. R. R. Tolkien</span></span>

2

<span key="a8e77b5106184c37bb606133a78a8742"><span offset-key="a8e77b5106184c37bb606133a78a8742:0">The Alchemist, Paulo Coelho</span></span>

3

<span key="e18ab154477f4fd2b893a247a07b18a9"><span offset-key="e18ab154477f4fd2b893a247a07b18a9:0">The Fellowship of the Ring, J. R. R. Tolkien</span></span>

4

<span key="5410ef56396e45e3bc559cd5f9f96da7"><span offset-key="5410ef56396e45e3bc559cd5f9f96da7:0">The Pilgrimage, Paulo Coelho</span></span>

<img src="data:image/svg+xml;base64," class="r-h7gdob r-10ptun7 r-1vzi8xi" />

Copied!

### 

<span key="4d7d18ea6ea5421aaffbae722c57b133"><span offset-key="4d7d18ea6ea5421aaffbae722c57b133:0">End of Line ($)</span></span>

<span key="a798f8f7dd4a4bb2a9370eedafa66206"><span offset-key="a798f8f7dd4a4bb2a9370eedafa66206:0">End of line is represented by the dollar($) symbol. The following example prints the lines that end with "Coelho".</span></span>

1

<span key="bf818b17e2d34ecc874e9656476e7494"><span offset-key="bf818b17e2d34ecc874e9656476e7494:0">\[jerry\]$ sed -n '/Coelho$/ p' books.txt</span></span>

<img src="data:image/svg+xml;base64," class="r-h7gdob r-10ptun7 r-1vzi8xi" />

Copied!

<span key="0fbb0eb36a5043db9845270c14786a20"><span offset-key="0fbb0eb36a5043db9845270c14786a20:0">On executing the above code, you get the following result:</span></span>

1

<span key="8579bebdeaa6439ba712c1cfacf46fb6"><span offset-key="8579bebdeaa6439ba712c1cfacf46fb6:0">The Alchemist, Paulo Coelho</span></span>

2

<span key="8808a5b6c25947c784ebf82e08ccda14"><span offset-key="8808a5b6c25947c784ebf82e08ccda14:0">The Pilgrimage, Paulo Coelho</span></span>

<img src="data:image/svg+xml;base64," class="r-h7gdob r-10ptun7 r-1vzi8xi" />

Copied!

### 

<span key="e9d89368b8814f72a1df325dd98a83ed"><span offset-key="e9d89368b8814f72a1df325dd98a83ed:0">Single Character (.)</span></span>

<span key="e361ff78e6854a1a880ddcca653a9692"><span offset-key="e361ff78e6854a1a880ddcca653a9692:0">The Dot(.) matches any single character except the end of line character. The following example prints all three letter words that end with the character "t".</span></span>

1

<span key="1e51860ff55f4535923bd9b5e37b79c4"><span offset-key="1e51860ff55f4535923bd9b5e37b79c4:0">\[jerry\]$ echo -e "cat\\nbat\\nrat\\nmat\\nbatting\\nrats\\nmats" | sed -n '/^..t$/p'</span></span>

<img src="data:image/svg+xml;base64," class="r-h7gdob r-10ptun7 r-1vzi8xi" />

Copied!

<span key="c9c2070232bd46d6987c329492e9adc5"><span offset-key="c9c2070232bd46d6987c329492e9adc5:0">On executing the above code, you get the following result:</span></span>

1

<span key="d7baaae0171340fbb38a6c9a75d24342"><span offset-key="d7baaae0171340fbb38a6c9a75d24342:0">cat</span></span>

<span key="1724c1bfd0534199b60e2cc9f52be620"><span offset-key="1724c1bfd0534199b60e2cc9f52be620:0">bat</span></span>

Copied!

### 

<span key="87de3232ce1a45b59a75b07633b17dbf"><span offset-key="87de3232ce1a45b59a75b07633b17dbf:0">Match Character Set (\[\])</span></span>

<span key="65cb359bb9954c2e996c0c50e4c93c0b"><span offset-key="65cb359bb9954c2e996c0c50e4c93c0b:0">In regular expression terminology, a character set is represented by square brackets (\[\]). It is used to match only one out of several characters. The following example matches the patterns "Call" and "Tall" but not "Ball".</span></span>

1

<span key="b428414d7b234755b01ea36194799f33"><span offset-key="b428414d7b234755b01ea36194799f33:0">\[jerry\]$ echo -e "Call\\nTall\\nBall" | sed -n '/\[CT\]all/ p'</span></span>

<img src="data:image/svg+xml;base64," class="r-h7gdob r-10ptun7 r-1vzi8xi" />

Copied!

<span key="77c6443ee1ba4f50b593e1b84396e57c"><span offset-key="77c6443ee1ba4f50b593e1b84396e57c:0">On executing the above code, you get the following result:</span></span>

1

<span key="1b656a989d494423bd7d607d0d8bc3f1"><span offset-key="1b656a989d494423bd7d607d0d8bc3f1:0">Call</span></span>

2

<span key="39a2b1829ba043549a5713a0f00535c5"><span offset-key="39a2b1829ba043549a5713a0f00535c5:0">Tall</span></span>

<img src="data:image/svg+xml;base64," class="r-h7gdob r-10ptun7 r-1vzi8xi" />

Copied!

### 

<span key="2f3245624e23498a9b9b5a18b6ac422f"><span offset-key="2f3245624e23498a9b9b5a18b6ac422f:0">Exclusive Set (\[^\])</span></span>

<span key="9a0ed6a095754fa0a253ecca2905ddda"><span offset-key="9a0ed6a095754fa0a253ecca2905ddda:0">In exclusive set, the caret negates the set of characters in the square brackets. The following example prints only "Ball".</span></span>

1

<span key="83581d73988145f38d30f69f394cb671"><span offset-key="83581d73988145f38d30f69f394cb671:0">\[jerry\]$ echo -e "Call\\nTall\\nBall" | sed -n '/\[^CT\]all/ p'</span></span>

<img src="data:image/svg+xml;base64," class="r-h7gdob r-10ptun7 r-1vzi8xi" />

Copied!

<span key="9e730907b1784c5db96645bc4fa13e59"><span offset-key="9e730907b1784c5db96645bc4fa13e59:0">On executing the above code, you get the following result:</span></span>

1

<span key="fb53c6b48e7f4fbebbc2451eb8425ed3"><span offset-key="fb53c6b48e7f4fbebbc2451eb8425ed3:0">Ball</span></span>

<img src="data:image/svg+xml;base64," class="r-h7gdob r-10ptun7 r-1vzi8xi" />

Copied!

### 

<span key="102d61ec2c3d46409085e896d61db501"><span offset-key="102d61ec2c3d46409085e896d61db501:0">Character Range (\[-\])</span></span>

<span key="d0a3550b37174b9a9f5f8220d1b5b878"><span offset-key="d0a3550b37174b9a9f5f8220d1b5b878:0">When a character range is provided, the regular expression matches any character within the range specified in square brackets. The following example matches "Call" and "Tall" but not "Ball".</span></span>

1

<span key="926078a60fc24e2c8a5ad1fbd890add3"><span offset-key="926078a60fc24e2c8a5ad1fbd890add3:0">\[jerry\]$ echo -e "Call\\nTall\\nBall" | sed -n '/\[C-Z\]all/ p'</span></span>

<img src="data:image/svg+xml;base64," class="r-h7gdob r-10ptun7 r-1vzi8xi" />

Copied!

<span key="5f93dbbd0fd64fa7a88c666687f70259"><span offset-key="5f93dbbd0fd64fa7a88c666687f70259:0">On executing the above code, you get the following result:</span></span>

1

<span key="ec58cc5d2548422c8b2c6007da09d78a"><span offset-key="ec58cc5d2548422c8b2c6007da09d78a:0">Call</span></span>

2

<span key="9e9cfaa1681e4f6ba64598379448ec3b"><span offset-key="9e9cfaa1681e4f6ba64598379448ec3b:0">Tall</span></span>

<img src="data:image/svg+xml;base64," class="r-h7gdob r-10ptun7 r-1vzi8xi" />

Copied!

<span key="841094fbc4b84e7e8df1230c981471e7"><span offset-key="841094fbc4b84e7e8df1230c981471e7:0">Now let us modify the range to "A-P" and observe the result.</span></span>

1

<span key="66bff01dda83480aa118047bbb1b3331"><span offset-key="66bff01dda83480aa118047bbb1b3331:0">\[jerry\]$ echo -e "Call\\nTall\\nBall" | sed -n '/\[A-P\]all/ p'</span></span>

<span key="3116ce32748f492ea246f91abafd883a"><span offset-key="3116ce32748f492ea246f91abafd883a:0">Call</span></span>
