### 

<span key="7d9db47e5d07411c90d7b10acc6289c8"><span offset-key="7d9db47e5d07411c90d7b10acc6289c8:0">Zero on One Occurrence (\\?)</span></span>

<span key="761a87627a924f498e1064c61444fb20"><span offset-key="761a87627a924f498e1064c61444fb20:0">In SED, the question mark (\\?) matches zero or one occurrence of the preceding character. The following example matches "Behaviour" as well as "Behavior". Here, we made "u" as an optional character by using "\\?".</span></span>

1

<span key="8a096c697906458783309f25f5d3f646"><span offset-key="8a096c697906458783309f25f5d3f646:0">\[jerry\]$ echo -e "Behaviour\\nBehavior" | sed -n '/Behaviou\\?r/ p'</span></span>

<img src="data:image/svg+xml;base64," class="r-h7gdob r-10ptun7 r-1vzi8xi" />

Copied!

<span key="72d3a3b3a22b4f8b848cb13f78938b1d"><span offset-key="72d3a3b3a22b4f8b848cb13f78938b1d:0">On executing the above code, you get the following result:</span></span>

1

<span key="aac3c452f35b42dab4f135ac33d61242"><span offset-key="aac3c452f35b42dab4f135ac33d61242:0">Behaviour</span></span>

2

<span key="0d9b50fc440a4f63a4aa0281d3f04f44"><span offset-key="0d9b50fc440a4f63a4aa0281d3f04f44:0">Behavior</span></span>

<img src="data:image/svg+xml;base64," class="r-h7gdob r-10ptun7 r-1vzi8xi" />

Copied!

### 

<span key="b1f8a3c7bd974afd9e25b856c1e271c2"><span offset-key="b1f8a3c7bd974afd9e25b856c1e271c2:0">One or More Occurrence (\\+)</span></span>

<span key="76f91d8c130546c38d67e8047a4b2703"><span offset-key="76f91d8c130546c38d67e8047a4b2703:0">In SED, the plus symbol(\\+) matches one or more occurrences of the preceding character. The following example matches one or more occurrences of "2".</span></span>

1

<span key="252c207f46784ef0962a4fa09159ce99"><span offset-key="252c207f46784ef0962a4fa09159ce99:0">\[jerry\]$ echo -e "111\\n22\\n123\\n234\\n456\\n222" | sed -n '/2\\+/ p'</span></span>

<img src="data:image/svg+xml;base64," class="r-h7gdob r-10ptun7 r-1vzi8xi" />

Copied!

<span key="074ce724303546638bbb7a0eaa9b45e5"><span offset-key="074ce724303546638bbb7a0eaa9b45e5:0">On executing the above code, you get the following result:</span></span>

1

<span key="7a8fc597d7b8477ab30023548c614552"><span offset-key="7a8fc597d7b8477ab30023548c614552:0">22</span></span>

2

<span key="458c9d3609c54f5bb0e2b3a1e40ac568"><span offset-key="458c9d3609c54f5bb0e2b3a1e40ac568:0">123</span></span>

3

<span key="4ad658ff73c74218a477d0d4d9541cde"><span offset-key="4ad658ff73c74218a477d0d4d9541cde:0">234</span></span>

4

<span key="4a00b62f47e84ec9924b6c90fd7be65f"><span offset-key="4a00b62f47e84ec9924b6c90fd7be65f:0">222</span></span>

<img src="data:image/svg+xml;base64," class="r-h7gdob r-10ptun7 r-1vzi8xi" />

Copied!

### 

<span key="985c43ab9a8a4799bd77d2b89fc7b16e"><span offset-key="985c43ab9a8a4799bd77d2b89fc7b16e:0">Zero or More Occurrence (\*)</span></span>

<span key="778aaaf90c8d40fbb3cd7f46e7e03452"><span offset-key="778aaaf90c8d40fbb3cd7f46e7e03452:0">Asterisks (\*) matches the zero or more occurrence of the preceding character. The following example matches "ca", "cat", "catt", and so on.</span></span>

1

<span key="929a11b4ce074a4a89bccb802232e84b"><span offset-key="929a11b4ce074a4a89bccb802232e84b:0">\[jerry\]$ echo -e "ca\\ncat" | sed -n '/cat\*/ p'</span></span>

<img src="data:image/svg+xml;base64," class="r-h7gdob r-10ptun7 r-1vzi8xi" />

Copied!

<span key="774a4c1c9d07468b8e4457b19b5a0dfd"><span offset-key="774a4c1c9d07468b8e4457b19b5a0dfd:0">On executing the above code, you get the following result:</span></span>

1

<span key="e9b3b6fe05534485b2d2ce81a9e38db9"><span offset-key="e9b3b6fe05534485b2d2ce81a9e38db9:0">ca</span></span>

2

<span key="9e34481f7f2148c89781b5d58c517088"><span offset-key="9e34481f7f2148c89781b5d58c517088:0">cat</span></span>

### 

<span key="b0146eb20bad4b109298ddb786e90691"><span offset-key="b0146eb20bad4b109298ddb786e90691:0">Exactly N Occurrences {n}</span></span>

<span key="87f9b04e1f2942f8bed518764bd19d1a"><span offset-key="87f9b04e1f2942f8bed518764bd19d1a:0">{n} matches exactly "n" occurrences of the preceding character. The following example prints only three digit numbers. But before that, you need to create the following file which contains only numbers.</span></span>

1

<span key="9fd1c9ef19784c2f99ae231e0e277dfa"><span offset-key="9fd1c9ef19784c2f99ae231e0e277dfa:0">\[jerry\]$ cat numbers.txt</span></span>

<img src="data:image/svg+xml;base64," class="r-h7gdob r-10ptun7 r-1vzi8xi" />

Copied!

<span key="e5a737380d074688be22562134d89f78"><span offset-key="e5a737380d074688be22562134d89f78:0">On executing the above code, you get the following result:</span></span>

1

<span key="1113232ea4324341b06e5b0aba7e093b"><span offset-key="1113232ea4324341b06e5b0aba7e093b:0">1</span></span>

2

<span key="7ca11ddd599f4ae591773094f1c17a44"><span offset-key="7ca11ddd599f4ae591773094f1c17a44:0">10</span></span>

3

<span key="fdcdd1b045544dc5bbf96c6406b096d1"><span offset-key="fdcdd1b045544dc5bbf96c6406b096d1:0">100</span></span>

4

<span key="2a281209d6e04d58a06e73f83a1f2400"><span offset-key="2a281209d6e04d58a06e73f83a1f2400:0">1000</span></span>

<span key="881b1609839c43aa8ea03f0f8c99e993"><span offset-key="881b1609839c43aa8ea03f0f8c99e993:0">100000000</span></span>

10

<span key="56f3fa90d88d4ec9903f81b7b2b7cf63"><span offset-key="56f3fa90d88d4ec9903f81b7b2b7cf63:0">1000000000</span></span>

<img src="data:image/svg+xml;base64," class="r-h7gdob r-10ptun7 r-1vzi8xi" />

Copied!

<span key="dd39c65fb7704d3a9fbca56f4bb3746a"><span offset-key="dd39c65fb7704d3a9fbca56f4bb3746a:0">Let us write the SED expression.</span></span>

1

<span key="2810c791f4d74e1c9db7bb0555a731ea"><span offset-key="2810c791f4d74e1c9db7bb0555a731ea:0">\[jerry\]$ sed -n '/^\[0-9\]\\{3\\}$/ p' numbers.txt</span></span>

1

<span key="08af180498284f419cd6b0a4678bb8e0"><span offset-key="08af180498284f419cd6b0a4678bb8e0:0">100</span></span>

### 

<span key="1e99bba974db4d38a3d23491b77c79e1"><span offset-key="1e99bba974db4d38a3d23491b77c79e1:0">At least n Occurrences {n,}</span></span>

<span key="45b83585fa7b48c2aa4a9f07b1e4d00b"><span offset-key="45b83585fa7b48c2aa4a9f07b1e4d00b:0">{n,} matches at least "n" occurrences of the preceding character. The following example prints all the numbers greater than or equal to five digits.</span></span>

1

<span key="fddb5ba8685d48dcad019d03d8734525"><span offset-key="fddb5ba8685d48dcad019d03d8734525:0">\[jerry\]$ sed -n '/^\[0-9\]\\{5,\\}$/ p' numbers.txt</span></span>

<img src="data:image/svg+xml;base64," class="r-h7gdob r-10ptun7 r-1vzi8xi" />

Copied!

<span key="9f3ee7b1ebcc4735ac20cc7c3e00d354"><span offset-key="9f3ee7b1ebcc4735ac20cc7c3e00d354:0">On executing the above code, you get the following result:</span></span>

1

<span key="d5ad965c74e841319883bd75241ba194"><span offset-key="d5ad965c74e841319883bd75241ba194:0">10000</span></span>

2

<span key="b31c1a0ee8464a339d24976e8e8d08cc"><span offset-key="b31c1a0ee8464a339d24976e8e8d08cc:0">100000</span></span>

3

<span key="e4a42bd0bc6d4c809e9952b821b483dc"><span offset-key="e4a42bd0bc6d4c809e9952b821b483dc:0">1000000</span></span>

5

<span key="6e46ac0f7b434d2a912af57c40837768"><span offset-key="6e46ac0f7b434d2a912af57c40837768:0">100000000</span></span>

<span key="0432f6e93eb8416cb07cd0ff4b246fc9"><span offset-key="0432f6e93eb8416cb07cd0ff4b246fc9:0">1000000000</span></span>

### 

<span key="d9071f4c8bb7421fb9a22e6f132245ba"><span offset-key="d9071f4c8bb7421fb9a22e6f132245ba:0">M to N Occurrence {m, n}</span></span>

<span key="a7374d164a0b4134ad22ea6a7c09dab1"><span offset-key="a7374d164a0b4134ad22ea6a7c09dab1:0">{m, n} matches at least "m" and at most "n" occurrences of the preceding character. The following example prints all the numbers having at least five digits but not more than eight digits.</span></span>

1

<span key="038103a5b8cf490f9ccc7360175a48b7"><span offset-key="038103a5b8cf490f9ccc7360175a48b7:0">\[jerry\]$ sed -n '/^\[0-9\]\\{5,8\\}$/ p' numbers.txt</span></span>

<img src="data:image/svg+xml;base64," class="r-h7gdob r-10ptun7 r-1vzi8xi" />

Copied!

<span key="0a39b573044045289cae156d9012b466"><span offset-key="0a39b573044045289cae156d9012b466:0">On executing the above code, you get the following result:</span></span>

1

<span key="7b36a025f22e4afbae90b29dce8b7814"><span offset-key="7b36a025f22e4afbae90b29dce8b7814:0">10000</span></span>

2

<span key="3745c94a46654beebd53d76f9490fd69"><span offset-key="3745c94a46654beebd53d76f9490fd69:0">100000</span></span>

3

<span key="d0365b5ab1a54644b61cb6745591ef4a"><span offset-key="d0365b5ab1a54644b61cb6745591ef4a:0">1000000</span></span>

4

<span key="698969e63c054ee3858d37e5aa581fa8"><span offset-key="698969e63c054ee3858d37e5aa581fa8:0">10000000</span></span>

<img src="data:image/svg+xml;base64," class="r-h7gdob r-10ptun7 r-1vzi8xi" />

Copied!

### 

<span key="6e7be1b86be94efebb1d0ab9420424bf"><span offset-key="6e7be1b86be94efebb1d0ab9420424bf:0">Pipe (|)</span></span>

<span key="e975b17d0f1a4061a28ae7b4f8ce1ef9"><span offset-key="e975b17d0f1a4061a28ae7b4f8ce1ef9:0">In SED, the pipe character behaves like logical OR operation. It matches items from either side of the pipe. The following example either matches "str1" or "str3".</span></span>

1

<span key="de0bec7192a54c179814d66b6d304a81"><span offset-key="de0bec7192a54c179814d66b6d304a81:0">\[jerry\]$ echo -e "str1\\nstr2\\nstr3\\nstr4" | sed -n '/str\\(1\\|3\\)/ p'</span></span>

<img src="data:image/svg+xml;base64," class="r-h7gdob r-10ptun7 r-1vzi8xi" />

Copied!

<span key="0751c630e946467182fe20202a1de85f"><span offset-key="0751c630e946467182fe20202a1de85f:0">On executing the above code, you get the following result:</span></span>

1

<span key="75cd657e89684af9a68b3993b6b403db"><span offset-key="75cd657e89684af9a68b3993b6b403db:0">str1</span></span>

2

<span key="fb4cd5fcf9454d60aa32d04183bf6115"><span offset-key="fb4cd5fcf9454d60aa32d04183bf6115:0">str3</span></span>

<img src="data:image/svg+xml;base64," class="r-h7gdob r-10ptun7 r-1vzi8xi" />

Copied!

<span key="ff7cba6b5d0a49bfaa0046cb63dd03b7"><span offset-key="ff7cba6b5d0a49bfaa0046cb63dd03b7:0">Note that the pair of the parenthesis and pipe (|) is escaped by the "\\" character.</span></span>

## 

<span key="0a9c0b0ceb114c0dbffa4aecd1c5ca32"><span offset-key="0a9c0b0ceb114c0dbffa4aecd1c5ca32:0">Escaping Characters</span></span>

<span key="fffec6dc95a04ad79851baf900d81d10"><span offset-key="fffec6dc95a04ad79851baf900d81d10:0">There are certain special characters. For example, newline is represented by "\\n", carriage return is represented by "\\r", and so on. To use these characters into regular ASCII context, we have to escape them using the backward slash(\\) character. This chapter illustrates escaping of special characters.</span></span>

### 

<span key="28ecf5881d5d49ecba7f6bffd8a2b25e"><span offset-key="28ecf5881d5d49ecba7f6bffd8a2b25e:0">Escaping "\\"</span></span>

<span key="2710e520a73f4017816cab605bef8cad"><span offset-key="2710e520a73f4017816cab605bef8cad:0">The following example matches the pattern "\\".</span></span>

1

<span key="d0590447c88148d18a7233dd903aba23"><span offset-key="d0590447c88148d18a7233dd903aba23:0">\[jerry\]$ echo 'str1\\str2' | sed -n '/\\\\/ p'</span></span>

<img src="data:image/svg+xml;base64," class="r-h7gdob r-10ptun7 r-1vzi8xi" />

Copied!

<span key="b0aeb9f6087e4056be9c13346588cdc4"><span offset-key="b0aeb9f6087e4056be9c13346588cdc4:0">On executing the above code, you get the following result:</span></span>

1

<span key="b606d34e00194575a43d3d4cc4977ec2"><span offset-key="b606d34e00194575a43d3d4cc4977ec2:0">str1\\str2</span></span>

<img src="data:image/svg+xml;base64," class="r-h7gdob r-10ptun7 r-1vzi8xi" />

Copied!

### 

<span key="75cf0c75aed84b5fbfa63151701e840b"><span offset-key="75cf0c75aed84b5fbfa63151701e840b:0">Escaping "\\n"</span></span>

<span key="52a6c473fd854be78929a11ecf1a5c11"><span offset-key="52a6c473fd854be78929a11ecf1a5c11:0">The following example matches the new line character.</span></span>

1

<span key="a8b6507a0b2a40b1bfff0783ae2eab79"><span offset-key="a8b6507a0b2a40b1bfff0783ae2eab79:0">\[jerry\]$ echo 'str1\\nstr2' | sed -n '/\\\\n/ p'</span></span>

<img src="data:image/svg+xml;base64," class="r-h7gdob r-10ptun7 r-1vzi8xi" />

Copied!

<span key="20f52d6c1db244929290e2ff2d2fbfde"><span offset-key="20f52d6c1db244929290e2ff2d2fbfde:0">On executing the above code, you get the following result:</span></span>

1

<span key="8a6df5deaade4a2f84866c6127bbaef5"><span offset-key="8a6df5deaade4a2f84866c6127bbaef5:0">str1\\nstr2</span></span>

<img src="data:image/svg+xml;base64," class="r-h7gdob r-10ptun7 r-1vzi8xi" />

Copied!

### 

<span key="c5fb9d2a576d40a3ac8502469b7ad979"><span offset-key="c5fb9d2a576d40a3ac8502469b7ad979:0">Escaping "\\r"</span></span>

<span key="9c7f6174299d491ca76f2d66b32f1501"><span offset-key="9c7f6174299d491ca76f2d66b32f1501:0">The following example matches the carriage return.</span></span>

1

<span key="7404b915d0e74d009e3cce0d030f1da8"><span offset-key="7404b915d0e74d009e3cce0d030f1da8:0">\[jerry\]$ echo 'str1\\rstr2' | sed -n '/\\\\r/ p'</span></span>

<img src="data:image/svg+xml;base64," class="r-h7gdob r-10ptun7 r-1vzi8xi" />

Copied!

<span key="2c816b664ace44f0922ecbcf7a0f72fb"><span offset-key="2c816b664ace44f0922ecbcf7a0f72fb:0">On executing the above code, you get the following result:</span></span>

1

<span key="c68e3e30c8f947fea88d2a58478cc03c"><span offset-key="c68e3e30c8f947fea88d2a58478cc03c:0">str1\\rstr2</span></span>

<img src="data:image/svg+xml;base64," class="r-h7gdob r-10ptun7 r-1vzi8xi" />

Copied!

### 

<span key="880bc49b566040efac5cc90e42f06ab8"><span offset-key="880bc49b566040efac5cc90e42f06ab8:0">Escaping "\\dnnn"</span></span>

<span key="771f2cfaac1b4a5ab388e369e6860e44"><span offset-key="771f2cfaac1b4a5ab388e369e6860e44:0">This matches a character whose decimal ASCII value is "nnn". The following example matches only the character "a".</span></span>

1

<span key="f807eafca0e04beaabd106d0011c773c"><span offset-key="f807eafca0e04beaabd106d0011c773c:0">\[jerry\]$ echo -e "a\\nb\\nc" | sed -n '/\\d97/ p'</span></span>

<img src="data:image/svg+xml;base64," class="r-h7gdob r-10ptun7 r-1vzi8xi" />

Copied!

<span key="cfa8a7a3772146b386cc90c3e96c1de1"><span offset-key="cfa8a7a3772146b386cc90c3e96c1de1:0">On executing the above code, you get the following result:</span></span>

1

<span key="08401329b80c43fabae496f8d9497a96"><span offset-key="08401329b80c43fabae496f8d9497a96:0">a</span></span>

<img src="data:image/svg+xml;base64," class="r-h7gdob r-10ptun7 r-1vzi8xi" />

Copied!

### 

<span key="a628d870ddf0468b82767735ddeaec15"><span offset-key="a628d870ddf0468b82767735ddeaec15:0">Escaping "\\onnn"</span></span>

<span key="01028f9cec0749ccb30e3914be39286f"><span offset-key="01028f9cec0749ccb30e3914be39286f:0">This matches a character whose octal ASCII value is "nnn". The following example matches only the character "b".</span></span>

1

<span key="50c6bf17916747aa85edf70f6e9ad1d0"><span offset-key="50c6bf17916747aa85edf70f6e9ad1d0:0">\[jerry\]$ echo -e "a\\nb\\nc" | sed -n '/\\o142/ p'</span></span>

<img src="data:image/svg+xml;base64," class="r-h7gdob r-10ptun7 r-1vzi8xi" />

Copied!

<span key="982002d7c6cd4fbea06903c41aace60a"><span offset-key="982002d7c6cd4fbea06903c41aace60a:0">On executing the above code, you get the following result:</span></span>

1

<span key="20974a87b06140539a01d53a4213479e"><span offset-key="20974a87b06140539a01d53a4213479e:0">b</span></span>

<img src="data:image/svg+xml;base64," class="r-h7gdob r-10ptun7 r-1vzi8xi" />

Copied!

<span key="8ce5621bb92d4e8c8b5a232433331255"><span offset-key="8ce5621bb92d4e8c8b5a232433331255:0">This matches a character whose hexadecimal ASCII value is "nnn". The following example matches only the character "c".</span></span>

1

<span key="7fe91a2e0b3342ada5dd28c1ec15e2e8"><span offset-key="7fe91a2e0b3342ada5dd28c1ec15e2e8:0">\[jerry\]$ echo -e "a\\nb\\nc" | sed -n '/\\x63/ p'</span></span>

<img src="data:image/svg+xml;base64," class="r-h7gdob r-10ptun7 r-1vzi8xi" />

Copied!

<span key="66250fb34e914159be6e17642460e5a0"><span offset-key="66250fb34e914159be6e17642460e5a0:0">On executing the above code, you get the following result:</span></span>

1

<span key="ced5c325707f469682cde52095885992"><span offset-key="ced5c325707f469682cde52095885992:0">c</span></span>

<img src="data:image/svg+xml;base64," class="r-h7gdob r-10ptun7 r-1vzi8xi" />

Copied!

## 

<span key="93a3e7399e374613ba5ee46b60bbbdce"><span offset-key="93a3e7399e374613ba5ee46b60bbbdce:0">POSIX Classes of Regular Expressions</span></span>

<span key="0ed14c5b129c4487a2db465204f5dde7"><span offset-key="0ed14c5b129c4487a2db465204f5dde7:0">There are certain reserved words which have special meaning. These reserved words are referred to as POSIX classes of regular expression. This section describes the POSIX classes supported by SED.</span></span>

### 

<span key="f35d22a8bea14dd18915a8573e806e25"><span offset-key="f35d22a8bea14dd18915a8573e806e25:0">\[:alnum:\]</span></span>

<span key="c1ed04c052c645158968b351955eaba0"><span offset-key="c1ed04c052c645158968b351955eaba0:0">It implies alphabetical and numeric characters. The following example matches only "One" and "123", but does not match the tab character.</span></span>

1

<span key="f21a2de30d854de4a7a4317c983ebd25"><span offset-key="f21a2de30d854de4a7a4317c983ebd25:0">\[jerry\]$ echo -e "One\\n123\\n\\t" | sed -n '/\[\[:alnum:\]\]/ p'</span></span>

<img src="data:image/svg+xml;base64," class="r-h7gdob r-10ptun7 r-1vzi8xi" />

Copied!

<span key="45a4ff03777c4fd39e68ccca991728aa"><span offset-key="45a4ff03777c4fd39e68ccca991728aa:0">On executing the above code, you get the following result:</span></span>

1

<span key="10ad37705f2b4250a2ad40f5a83ae5e1"><span offset-key="10ad37705f2b4250a2ad40f5a83ae5e1:0">One</span></span>

2

<span key="4d1395683fbf405598734460364efc43"><span offset-key="4d1395683fbf405598734460364efc43:0">123</span></span>

<img src="data:image/svg+xml;base64," class="r-h7gdob r-10ptun7 r-1vzi8xi" />

Copied!

### 

<span key="af7a952a80d04f408b7f7c5dce3fe794"><span offset-key="af7a952a80d04f408b7f7c5dce3fe794:0">\[:alpha:\]</span></span>

<span key="e76e461975b64f36b2e5d31f4e5a7bb5"><span offset-key="e76e461975b64f36b2e5d31f4e5a7bb5:0">It implies alphabetical characters only. The following example matches only the word "One".</span></span>

1

<span key="673a3f1f6fe24d799fd10ce68c4bc738"><span offset-key="673a3f1f6fe24d799fd10ce68c4bc738:0">\[jerry\]$ echo -e "One\\n123\\n\\t" | sed -n '/\[\[:alpha:\]\]/ p'</span></span>

<img src="data:image/svg+xml;base64," class="r-h7gdob r-10ptun7 r-1vzi8xi" />

Copied!

<span key="f1dfb094ea36468fb178ce531c520054"><span offset-key="f1dfb094ea36468fb178ce531c520054:0">On executing the above code, you get the following result:</span></span>

1

<span key="272538d7e58a46b185e383d98beb6b81"><span offset-key="272538d7e58a46b185e383d98beb6b81:0">One</span></span>

<img src="data:image/svg+xml;base64," class="r-h7gdob r-10ptun7 r-1vzi8xi" />

Copied!

### 

<span key="b58e25fe75cc4e9ba41d947bf9e6fd3f"><span offset-key="b58e25fe75cc4e9ba41d947bf9e6fd3f:0">\[:blank:\]</span></span>

<span key="6a25b31e902b4074bc8880273ade31be"><span offset-key="6a25b31e902b4074bc8880273ade31be:0">It implies blank character which can be either space or tab. The following example matches only the tab character.</span></span>

1

<span key="7ebf17cc844e4a09b15253c4adfdb764"><span offset-key="7ebf17cc844e4a09b15253c4adfdb764:0">\[jerry\]$ echo -e "One\\n123\\n\\t" | sed -n '/\[\[:space:\]\]/ p' | cat -vte</span></span>

<img src="data:image/svg+xml;base64," class="r-h7gdob r-10ptun7 r-1vzi8xi" />

Copied!

<span key="c8e6d79c29604beb887922fa40d799ae"><span offset-key="c8e6d79c29604beb887922fa40d799ae:0">On executing the above code, you get the following result:</span></span>

1

<span key="366183f860644cec81f0394054fcbedb"><span offset-key="366183f860644cec81f0394054fcbedb:0">^I$</span></span>

<img src="data:image/svg+xml;base64," class="r-h7gdob r-10ptun7 r-1vzi8xi" />

Copied!

<span key="6962c47d95044d8ab58b2663fccd2640"><span offset-key="6962c47d95044d8ab58b2663fccd2640:0">Note that the command "cat -vte" is used to show tab characters (^I).</span></span>

### 

<span key="5d51306f6b144c2992db104c583241b9"><span offset-key="5d51306f6b144c2992db104c583241b9:0">\[:digit:\]</span></span>

<span key="5a14cdc64f6a4301bd56e803837bf7c4"><span offset-key="5a14cdc64f6a4301bd56e803837bf7c4:0">It implies decimal numbers only. The following example matches only digit "123".</span></span>

1

<span key="2910c4b1fb8b4ef4a5e53899d08f5abe"><span offset-key="2910c4b1fb8b4ef4a5e53899d08f5abe:0">\[jerry\]$ echo -e "abc\\n123\\n\\t" | sed -n '/\[\[:digit:\]\]/ p'</span></span>

<img src="data:image/svg+xml;base64," class="r-h7gdob r-10ptun7 r-1vzi8xi" />

Copied!

<span key="b74a95c9ec8b467f94afc7da97e02884"><span offset-key="b74a95c9ec8b467f94afc7da97e02884:0">On executing the above code, you get the following result:</span></span>

1

<span key="d4509765e5764978bc94abcae8b6d1c6"><span offset-key="d4509765e5764978bc94abcae8b6d1c6:0">123</span></span>

<img src="data:image/svg+xml;base64," class="r-h7gdob r-10ptun7 r-1vzi8xi" />

Copied!

### 

<span key="f025724347374e3e8b3e0aac301e48b3"><span offset-key="f025724347374e3e8b3e0aac301e48b3:0">\[:lower:\]</span></span>

<span key="3e416bf6bdaa47ff954af7f7be6c7da2"><span offset-key="3e416bf6bdaa47ff954af7f7be6c7da2:0">It implies lowercase letters only. The following example matches only "one".</span></span>

1

<span key="5ebf26212bc747fb8f1eabf4f7ea02d0"><span offset-key="5ebf26212bc747fb8f1eabf4f7ea02d0:0">\[jerry\]$ echo -e "one\\nTWO\\n\\t" | sed -n '/\[\[:lower:\]\]/ p'</span></span>

<img src="data:image/svg+xml;base64," class="r-h7gdob r-10ptun7 r-1vzi8xi" />

Copied!

<span key="b87da3707e3c43dcb89dc75a132acf8f"><span offset-key="b87da3707e3c43dcb89dc75a132acf8f:0">On executing the above code, you get the following result:</span></span>

1

<span key="c7504443630d4a7bb3cfc7beae4ddc66"><span offset-key="c7504443630d4a7bb3cfc7beae4ddc66:0">one</span></span>

<img src="data:image/svg+xml;base64," class="r-h7gdob r-10ptun7 r-1vzi8xi" />

Copied!

### 

<span key="895e61f3b73b4adb9749f83e291cacc4"><span offset-key="895e61f3b73b4adb9749f83e291cacc4:0">\[:upper:\]</span></span>

<span key="91f22289557743a9ad42511f72fd8d0d"><span offset-key="91f22289557743a9ad42511f72fd8d0d:0">It implies uppercase letters only. The following example matches only "TWO".</span></span>

1

<span key="74ebd06dbfbb4ee1bd3512a90fa72b75"><span offset-key="74ebd06dbfbb4ee1bd3512a90fa72b75:0">\[jerry\]$ echo -e "one\\nTWO\\n\\t" | sed -n '/\[\[:upper:\]\]/ p'</span></span>

<img src="data:image/svg+xml;base64," class="r-h7gdob r-10ptun7 r-1vzi8xi" />

Copied!

<span key="273ec2c766db47c185693b7e77fa9a3a"><span offset-key="273ec2c766db47c185693b7e77fa9a3a:0">On executing the above code, you get the following result:</span></span>

1

<span key="16e90b634c9144b5bdb16db543ed7bee"><span offset-key="16e90b634c9144b5bdb16db543ed7bee:0">TWO</span></span>

<img src="data:image/svg+xml;base64," class="r-h7gdob r-10ptun7 r-1vzi8xi" />

Copied!

### 

<span key="2413946e83d04f9482d11db5d826dd69"><span offset-key="2413946e83d04f9482d11db5d826dd69:0">\[:punct:\]</span></span>

<span key="81cf7210bc9e4810bae171fcbf2ac518"><span offset-key="81cf7210bc9e4810bae171fcbf2ac518:0">It implies punctuation marks which include non-space or alphanumeric characters</span></span>

1

<span key="1331875ac51d403f803ad53175b14189"><span offset-key="1331875ac51d403f803ad53175b14189:0">\[jerry\]$ echo -e "One,Two\\nThree\\nFour" | sed -n '/\[\[:punct:\]\]/ p'</span></span>

<img src="data:image/svg+xml;base64," class="r-h7gdob r-10ptun7 r-1vzi8xi" />

Copied!

<span key="9601d4bc0a8f4963a8ecc031717b9c73"><span offset-key="9601d4bc0a8f4963a8ecc031717b9c73:0">On executing the above code, you get the following result:</span></span>

1

<span key="3772e6eb54fd4f52abf0cf285f677967"><span offset-key="3772e6eb54fd4f52abf0cf285f677967:0">One,Two</span></span>

<img src="data:image/svg+xml;base64," class="r-h7gdob r-10ptun7 r-1vzi8xi" />

Copied!

### 

<span key="f4dbecec2f1e424a942c13380ec71803"><span offset-key="f4dbecec2f1e424a942c13380ec71803:0">\[:space:\]</span></span>

<span key="74e7b791a35f4fe29e8be48d07942f79"><span offset-key="74e7b791a35f4fe29e8be48d07942f79:0">It implies whitespace characters. The following example illustrates this.</span></span>

1

<span key="4fa4becc0d2744ebbe5a7751f5e7ffa5"><span offset-key="4fa4becc0d2744ebbe5a7751f5e7ffa5:0">\[jerry\]$ echo -e "One\\n123\\f\\t" | sed -n '/\[\[:space:\]\]/ p' | cat -vte</span></span>

<img src="data:image/svg+xml;base64," class="r-h7gdob r-10ptun7 r-1vzi8xi" />

Copied!

<span key="0dedac554b6f459787a43f937f8bb981"><span offset-key="0dedac554b6f459787a43f937f8bb981:0">On executing the above code, you get the following result:</span></span>

1

<span key="18bde6ed7e4b4a3486e1464b787767ef"><span offset-key="18bde6ed7e4b4a3486e1464b787767ef:0">123^L^I$</span></span>

<img src="data:image/svg+xml;base64," class="r-h7gdob r-10ptun7 r-1vzi8xi" />

Copied!

## 

<span key="0109287bdc6e4d94a8192434598aa125"><span offset-key="0109287bdc6e4d94a8192434598aa125:0">Metacharacters</span></span>

<span key="d7f17aff4a844bcb9d1f3caa471f3a88"><span offset-key="d7f17aff4a844bcb9d1f3caa471f3a88:0">Like traditional regular expressions, SED also supports metacharacters. These are Perl style regular expressions. Note that metacharacter support is GNU SED specific and may not work with other variants of SED. Let us discuss metacharacters in detail.</span></span>

## 

<span key="fcec15c981b34f49ad4bac015dac2ae5"><span offset-key="fcec15c981b34f49ad4bac015dac2ae5:0">Word Boundary (\\b)</span></span>

<span key="112d354a127d4f90b617e9877c4496b8"><span offset-key="112d354a127d4f90b617e9877c4496b8:0">In regular expression terminology, "\\b" matches the word boundary. For example, "\\bthe\\b" matches "the" but not "these", "there", "they", "then", and so on. The following example illustrates this.</span></span>

1

<span key="87f5b7eb70484b84bfc981db60ccfaab"><span offset-key="87f5b7eb70484b84bfc981db60ccfaab:0">\[jerry\]$ echo -e "these\\nthe\\nthey\\nthen" | sed -n '/\\bthe\\b/ p'</span></span>

<img src="data:image/svg+xml;base64," class="r-h7gdob r-10ptun7 r-1vzi8xi" />

Copied!

<span key="0e7a11f6a2ef49bb9c30f1c820f99fd2"><span offset-key="0e7a11f6a2ef49bb9c30f1c820f99fd2:0">On executing the above code, you get the following result:</span></span>

1

<span key="ce0b9822086d449680f97c9875383526"><span offset-key="ce0b9822086d449680f97c9875383526:0">the</span></span>

<img src="data:image/svg+xml;base64," class="r-h7gdob r-10ptun7 r-1vzi8xi" />

Copied!

## 

<span key="f0d913ffec3a4cff8a546685cbabd542"><span offset-key="f0d913ffec3a4cff8a546685cbabd542:0">Non-Word Boundary (\\B)</span></span>

<span key="d5379436319242f992fb38a2a800c8c4"><span offset-key="d5379436319242f992fb38a2a800c8c4:0">In regular expression terminology, "\\B" matches non-word boundary. For example, "the\\B" matches "these" and "they" but not "the". The following example illustrates this.</span></span>

1

<span key="7b039a5b1be34cd9a96ae761886adc94"><span offset-key="7b039a5b1be34cd9a96ae761886adc94:0">\[jerry\]$ echo -e "these\\nthe\\nthey" | sed -n '/the\\B/ p'</span></span>

<img src="data:image/svg+xml;base64," class="r-h7gdob r-10ptun7 r-1vzi8xi" />

Copied!

<span key="e782d1316f1f492b821baf948df52929"><span offset-key="e782d1316f1f492b821baf948df52929:0">On executing the above code, you get the following result:</span></span>

1

<span key="6b0a33a5f0544649803131c44d39c998"><span offset-key="6b0a33a5f0544649803131c44d39c998:0">these</span></span>

2

<span key="c45a77543c744bb3a8a59afc9b63817f"><span offset-key="c45a77543c744bb3a8a59afc9b63817f:0">they</span></span>

<img src="data:image/svg+xml;base64," class="r-h7gdob r-10ptun7 r-1vzi8xi" />

Copied!

## 

<span key="018dffa568db4d2b9502f4272ec41ed0"><span offset-key="018dffa568db4d2b9502f4272ec41ed0:0">Single Whitespace (\\s)</span></span>

<span key="400a9ba99fe5411e8a900d7d481d0ae2"><span offset-key="400a9ba99fe5411e8a900d7d481d0ae2:0">In SED, "\\s" implies single whitespace character. The following example matches "Line\\t1" but does not match "Line1".</span></span>

1

<span key="617f1a0792364e7895e37a9bc8c240b6"><span offset-key="617f1a0792364e7895e37a9bc8c240b6:0">\[jerry\]$ echo -e "Line\\t1\\nLine2" | sed -n '/Line\\s/ p'</span></span>

<img src="data:image/svg+xml;base64," class="r-h7gdob r-10ptun7 r-1vzi8xi" />

Copied!

<span key="2528a7c6cd414e3cb2b740fb518e3969"><span offset-key="2528a7c6cd414e3cb2b740fb518e3969:0">On executing the above code, you get the following result:</span></span>

1

<span key="4c61f1624c1c4bdabf5abb160ad6de7f"><span offset-key="4c61f1624c1c4bdabf5abb160ad6de7f:0">Line 1</span></span>

<img src="data:image/svg+xml;base64," class="r-h7gdob r-10ptun7 r-1vzi8xi" />

Copied!

## 

<span key="bedc70befaf343499693b4493cae1c26"><span offset-key="bedc70befaf343499693b4493cae1c26:0">Single Non-Whitespace (\\S)</span></span>

<span key="813dee3a034d4bcfa82c7dbdf099d606"><span offset-key="813dee3a034d4bcfa82c7dbdf099d606:0">In SED, "\\S" implies single whitespace character. The following example matches "Line2" but does not match "Line\\t1".</span></span>

1

<span key="13d09287dbee454c85831ad29794a820"><span offset-key="13d09287dbee454c85831ad29794a820:0">\[jerry\]$ echo -e "Line\\t1\\nLine2" | sed -n '/Line\\S/ p'</span></span>

<img src="data:image/svg+xml;base64," class="r-h7gdob r-10ptun7 r-1vzi8xi" />

Copied!

<span key="1361cd0d26fa4129893eb7c4c835f2f9"><span offset-key="1361cd0d26fa4129893eb7c4c835f2f9:0">On executing the above code, you get the following result:</span></span>

1

<span key="4d591f3105b0459fade5082e375c0e43"><span offset-key="4d591f3105b0459fade5082e375c0e43:0">Line2</span></span>

<img src="data:image/svg+xml;base64," class="r-h7gdob r-10ptun7 r-1vzi8xi" />

Copied!

## 

<span key="bfb0bd9988df4c9f81f92e3054bfac6c"><span offset-key="bfb0bd9988df4c9f81f92e3054bfac6c:0">Single Word Character (\\w)</span></span>

<span key="d9b0b3b316b344d288e8cfc9e5fa7dce"><span offset-key="d9b0b3b316b344d288e8cfc9e5fa7dce:0">In SED, "\\w" implies single word character, i.e., alphabetical characters, digits, and underscore (\_). The following example illustrates this.</span></span>

1

<span key="4feef5dd27a64a8ca98c88276d0b2109"><span offset-key="4feef5dd27a64a8ca98c88276d0b2109:0">\[jerry\]$ echo -e "One\\n123\\n1\_2\\n&;#" | sed -n '/\\w/ p'</span></span>

<img src="data:image/svg+xml;base64," class="r-h7gdob r-10ptun7 r-1vzi8xi" />

Copied!

<span key="3380c483c971493984a3d62e650ca86a"><span offset-key="3380c483c971493984a3d62e650ca86a:0">On executing the above code, you get the following result:</span></span>

1

<span key="f75d78622c784ea99276a4561eeac696"><span offset-key="f75d78622c784ea99276a4561eeac696:0">One</span></span>

2

<span key="0560dd62d8184b58b636d6fbee4a67a3"><span offset-key="0560dd62d8184b58b636d6fbee4a67a3:0">123</span></span>

3

<span key="0dc63b2931bd41bd945a8be5f518693f"><span offset-key="0dc63b2931bd41bd945a8be5f518693f:0">1\_2</span></span>

<img src="data:image/svg+xml;base64," class="r-h7gdob r-10ptun7 r-1vzi8xi" />

Copied!

## 

<span key="0194b9e0da5d4a77a4077635bc011b90"><span offset-key="0194b9e0da5d4a77a4077635bc011b90:0">Single Non-Word Character (\\W)</span></span>

<span key="52290c3e3571438b8a7f564f1dd702ba"><span offset-key="52290c3e3571438b8a7f564f1dd702ba:0">In SED, "\\W" implies single non-word character which is exactly opposite to "\\w". The following example illustrates this.</span></span>

1

<span key="128ea4d2797b48679ed3cc57f5bde805"><span offset-key="128ea4d2797b48679ed3cc57f5bde805:0">\[jerry\]$ echo -e "One\\n123\\n1\_2\\n&;#" | sed -n '/\\W/ p'</span></span>

<img src="data:image/svg+xml;base64," class="r-h7gdob r-10ptun7 r-1vzi8xi" />

Copied!

<span key="71854aabbe0f44b59d239b9c1694437f"><span offset-key="71854aabbe0f44b59d239b9c1694437f:0">On executing the above code, you get the following result:</span></span>

1

<span key="65728c0cff314c3eae4b8decda84f8d1"><span offset-key="65728c0cff314c3eae4b8decda84f8d1:0">&;#</span></span>

<img src="data:image/svg+xml;base64," class="r-h7gdob r-10ptun7 r-1vzi8xi" />

Copied!

## 

<span key="319db924f2b74d49b9031a9bf1f886a4"><span offset-key="319db924f2b74d49b9031a9bf1f886a4:0">Beginning of Pattern Space (\\\`)</span></span>

<span key="84e648b7ddd041aea2f1987b412a5bf3"><span offset-key="84e648b7ddd041aea2f1987b412a5bf3:0">In SED, "\\\`" implies the beginning of the pattern space. The following example matches only the word "One".</span></span>

1

<span key="edd235257c4b49eabae218525a3e9631"><span offset-key="edd235257c4b49eabae218525a3e9631:0">\[jerry\]$ echo -e "One\\nTwo One" | sed -n '/\\\`One/ p'</span></span>

<img src="data:image/svg+xml;base64," class="r-h7gdob r-10ptun7 r-1vzi8xi" />

Copied!

<span key="c286add506334349b504b4bc74041929"><span offset-key="c286add506334349b504b4bc74041929:0">On executing the above code, you get the following result:</span></span>

1

<span key="ae02f83df43e4869a4b7a758a92608cb"><span offset-key="ae02f83df43e4869a4b7a758a92608cb:0">One</span></span>

<img src="data:image/svg+xml;base64," class="r-h7gdob r-10ptun7 r-1vzi8xi" />

Copied!

# 

<span key="9e0c9c0f22e74a2ea9f4004a8821bc3f"><span offset-key="9e0c9c0f22e74a2ea9f4004a8821bc3f:0">Stream Editor - Useful Recipes</span></span>

<span key="0bece370179a412c9f65fef0c5ae8acd"><span offset-key="0bece370179a412c9f65fef0c5ae8acd:0">SED is an amazing utility that allows multiple ways to solve a problem. This is the UNIX way and SED perfectly proves that. GNU/Linux provides many useful utilities to perform day-to-day tasks. Let us simulate a few utilities using SED. Sometimes it may appear we are solving an easy problem the hard way, but the purpose is just to demonstrate the power of SED.</span></span>

## 

<span key="3576a8d52b954b02a951c9a8340172a4"><span offset-key="3576a8d52b954b02a951c9a8340172a4:0">Cat Command</span></span>

<span key="ee6c2f648be84c5a8da738397d4f512d"><span offset-key="ee6c2f648be84c5a8da738397d4f512d:0">In the following example, each line is printed as a part of the default workflow.</span></span>

1

<span key="dfe8e62d61224eefb69b4c251cc2feb2"><span offset-key="dfe8e62d61224eefb69b4c251cc2feb2:0">\[jerry\]$ sed '' books.txt</span></span>

<img src="data:image/svg+xml;base64," class="r-h7gdob r-10ptun7 r-1vzi8xi" />

Copied!

<span key="8992c8986bd7478eb04b16d046ad21e1"><span offset-key="8992c8986bd7478eb04b16d046ad21e1:0">On executing the above code, you get the following result:</span></span>

1

<span key="462ee493cb22406c80355705480d0a9c"><span offset-key="462ee493cb22406c80355705480d0a9c:0">A Storm of Swords, George R. R. Martin</span></span>

2

<span key="44faed57718045a59f787c5a3927b971"><span offset-key="44faed57718045a59f787c5a3927b971:0">The Two Towers, J. R. R. Tolkien</span></span>

3

<span key="9e32b0a547ae47e598705e21a525881a"><span offset-key="9e32b0a547ae47e598705e21a525881a:0">The Alchemist, Paulo Coelho</span></span>

4

<span key="df764fa7030d46929ef320f916a86a3a"><span offset-key="df764fa7030d46929ef320f916a86a3a:0">The Fellowship of the Ring, J. R. R. Tolkien</span></span>

5

<span key="4b50a0c5a48b4c6e876d401d02c92742"><span offset-key="4b50a0c5a48b4c6e876d401d02c92742:0">The Pilgrimage, Paulo Coelho</span></span>

6

<span key="6291ec80530043c49397644592907feb"><span offset-key="6291ec80530043c49397644592907feb:0">A Game of Thrones, George R. R. Martin</span></span>

<img src="data:image/svg+xml;base64," class="r-h7gdob r-10ptun7 r-1vzi8xi" />

Copied!

<span key="29e59e4f459e4c2b8eecdddd98cf8f51"><span offset-key="29e59e4f459e4c2b8eecdddd98cf8f51:0">The following example uses print command to display the file contents.</span></span>

1

<span key="a0a6fad3b3c446a9baad18f154ccc9ee"><span offset-key="a0a6fad3b3c446a9baad18f154ccc9ee:0">\[jerry\]$ sed -n 'p' books.txt</span></span>

Copied!

<span key="1c5a2d2aa33e4880b0022d38d870f24f"><span offset-key="1c5a2d2aa33e4880b0022d38d870f24f:0">On executing the above code, you get the following result:</span></span>

2

<span key="f872227d90ec41b281a23abff5bddc21"><span offset-key="f872227d90ec41b281a23abff5bddc21:0">The Two Towers, J. R. R. Tolkien</span></span>

3

<span key="9d090a73fca7494491f11e7a97f74fe4"><span offset-key="9d090a73fca7494491f11e7a97f74fe4:0">The Alchemist, Paulo Coelho</span></span>

<span key="82ce1f9366554637a140a7e8dd8e006e"><span offset-key="82ce1f9366554637a140a7e8dd8e006e:0">The Fellowship of the Ring, J. R. R. Tolkien</span></span>

<span key="7d223f05247c42c7a76bd1821c40344c"><span offset-key="7d223f05247c42c7a76bd1821c40344c:0">The Pilgrimage, Paulo Coelho</span></span>

## 

<span key="a8ef0cb5c51247d8ac84344a2a7b8cc8"><span offset-key="a8ef0cb5c51247d8ac84344a2a7b8cc8:0">Removing Empty Lines</span></span>

<span key="671837016fcf4b2b93ec38b2b2782d8f"><span offset-key="671837016fcf4b2b93ec38b2b2782d8f:0">In the following example, "^quot; implies empty line, and empty lines are deleted when a pattern match succeeds.</span></span>

1

<span key="552e16e9148c4be9bd5bca72c69a2cd9"><span offset-key="552e16e9148c4be9bd5bca72c69a2cd9:0">\[jerry\]$ echo -e "Line #1\\n\\n\\nLine #2" | sed '/^$/d'</span></span>

<img src="data:image/svg+xml;base64," class="r-h7gdob r-10ptun7 r-1vzi8xi" />

Copied!

<span key="02d81adaf68a44f587973903de316636"><span offset-key="02d81adaf68a44f587973903de316636:0">On executing the above code, you get the following result:</span></span>

1

<span key="b964ffc9af974fe7b6c003fc9281dbc7"><span offset-key="b964ffc9af974fe7b6c003fc9281dbc7:0">Line #1</span></span>

2

<span key="33cae581026442dd84ccf35ab10a15de"><span offset-key="33cae581026442dd84ccf35ab10a15de:0">Line #2</span></span>

<img src="data:image/svg+xml;base64," class="r-h7gdob r-10ptun7 r-1vzi8xi" />

Copied!

<span key="37bea33384a34b7aa69283813d4c8131"><span offset-key="37bea33384a34b7aa69283813d4c8131:0">Similarly, the following example prints the line only when it is non-empty.</span></span>

1

<span key="bcc450ab47a1449b9afa606c54bbbb6e"><span offset-key="bcc450ab47a1449b9afa606c54bbbb6e:0">\[jerry\]$ echo -e "Line #1\\n\\n\\nLine #2" | sed -n '/^$/!p'</span></span>

<img src="data:image/svg+xml;base64," class="r-h7gdob r-10ptun7 r-1vzi8xi" />

Copied!

<span key="3bf83b60a9a640a4a953ae8dec8d911a"><span offset-key="3bf83b60a9a640a4a953ae8dec8d911a:0">On executing the above code, you get the following result:</span></span>

1

<span key="7a01d0ba2fe04929a3ca999d6168036c"><span offset-key="7a01d0ba2fe04929a3ca999d6168036c:0">Line #1</span></span>

2

<span key="c7bb06b733634a798ff09481fe171afc"><span offset-key="c7bb06b733634a798ff09481fe171afc:0">Line #2</span></span>

<img src="data:image/svg+xml;base64," class="r-h7gdob r-10ptun7 r-1vzi8xi" />

Copied!

## 

<span key="ee87fa0d770e4dfd9b5b5bee732c801b"><span offset-key="ee87fa0d770e4dfd9b5b5bee732c801b:0">Removing Commented Lines from a C++ Program</span></span>

<span key="02a6cdfa1605410baa4a1f823b323faf"><span offset-key="02a6cdfa1605410baa4a1f823b323faf:0">Let us create a sample C++ program.</span></span>

1

<span key="7559e97a470149b0b9237a3e07dc98f1"><span offset-key="7559e97a470149b0b9237a3e07dc98f1:0">#include &lt;iostream></span></span>

2

<span key="4cea5e4135174d338b9d24efb968946b"><span offset-key="4cea5e4135174d338b9d24efb968946b:0">using namespace std;</span></span>

3

<span key="91fa7d98523d407885edeeed052f9269"><span offset-key="91fa7d98523d407885edeeed052f9269:0"><span slate-zero-width="n">​</span></span></span>

4

<span key="13f3f0aadd504d3fa63b85ac1a80ddde"><span offset-key="13f3f0aadd504d3fa63b85ac1a80ddde:0">int main(void)</span></span>

5

<span key="fda82b9387e24c21838135b8e61cddeb"><span offset-key="fda82b9387e24c21838135b8e61cddeb:0">{</span></span>

6

<span key="d0f253f78cee4bb0b8484f3590b27414"><span offset-key="d0f253f78cee4bb0b8484f3590b27414:0"> // Displays message on stdout.</span></span>

7

<span key="7150ae57e936429d8184d7b2308b8dd2"><span offset-key="7150ae57e936429d8184d7b2308b8dd2:0"> cout &gt;&gt; "Hello, World !!!" &gt;&gt; endl;</span></span>

8

<span key="a4104ca152c14cf4b09b4feeef085f18"><span offset-key="a4104ca152c14cf4b09b4feeef085f18:0"> return 0; // Return success.</span></span>

9

<span key="07a915a49c794f248e0c61c6058662f3"><span offset-key="07a915a49c794f248e0c61c6058662f3:0">}</span></span>

<img src="data:image/svg+xml;base64," class="r-h7gdob r-10ptun7 r-1vzi8xi" />

Copied!

<span key="54645f8de6134e38938b4bace6c86861"><span offset-key="54645f8de6134e38938b4bace6c86861:0">Now remove the comments using the following regular expression.</span></span>

1

<span key="d378e63f2a2a4375a1996b8cc3b26613"><span offset-key="d378e63f2a2a4375a1996b8cc3b26613:0">\[jerry\]$ sed 's|//.\*||g' hello.cpp</span></span>

<img src="data:image/svg+xml;base64," class="r-h7gdob r-10ptun7 r-1vzi8xi" />

Copied!

<span key="05260eb543a649eea81c078e66b68600"><span offset-key="05260eb543a649eea81c078e66b68600:0">On executing the above code, you get the following result:</span></span>

1

<span key="a21ecccd41f54269b4d208e09f413642"><span offset-key="a21ecccd41f54269b4d208e09f413642:0">#include &lt;iostream></span></span>

2

<span key="22adf27d6bc147999369bf180dfb1638"><span offset-key="22adf27d6bc147999369bf180dfb1638:0">using namespace std;</span></span>

3

<span key="44c7db801b074802860efbc4cb4e8f8e"><span offset-key="44c7db801b074802860efbc4cb4e8f8e:0"><span slate-zero-width="n">​</span></span></span>

4

<span key="e6196e565c114635a8aeb144068f18e8"><span offset-key="e6196e565c114635a8aeb144068f18e8:0">int main(void)</span></span>

5

<span key="0da319bd8cf344569b71d430b612e371"><span offset-key="0da319bd8cf344569b71d430b612e371:0">{</span></span>

6

<span key="8d4a3ee1e8de43c099ec67b3269f9f9c"><span offset-key="8d4a3ee1e8de43c099ec67b3269f9f9c:0"> cout &gt;&gt; "Hello, World !!!" &gt;&gt; endl;</span></span>

7

<span key="3575528ab16143529969b8caa9cb0f42"><span offset-key="3575528ab16143529969b8caa9cb0f42:0"> return 0;</span></span>

8

<span key="03a5d652929d4db5872116f5e9d5b705"><span offset-key="03a5d652929d4db5872116f5e9d5b705:0">}</span></span>

<img src="data:image/svg+xml;base64," class="r-h7gdob r-10ptun7 r-1vzi8xi" />

Copied!

## 

<span key="7e9a1d17a7524600b1175e7a0055f48f"><span offset-key="7e9a1d17a7524600b1175e7a0055f48f:0">Adding Comments Before Certain Lines</span></span>

<span key="450304dfc2894514a145b8dae2f66eb5"><span offset-key="450304dfc2894514a145b8dae2f66eb5:0">The following example adds comments before line numbers 3 to 5.</span></span>

1

<span key="0dd3d88cc6ed417cb400a12a80105767"><span offset-key="0dd3d88cc6ed417cb400a12a80105767:0">\[jerry\]$ sed '3,5 s/^/#/' hello.sh</span></span>

<img src="data:image/svg+xml;base64," class="r-h7gdob r-10ptun7 r-1vzi8xi" />

Copied!

<span key="33502a12ea2e4ec8a0776268d37d9692"><span offset-key="33502a12ea2e4ec8a0776268d37d9692:0">On executing the above code, you get the following result:</span></span>

1

<span key="255adbb710614cc2bfcba4dac38d1905"><span offset-key="255adbb710614cc2bfcba4dac38d1905:0">#!/bin/bash</span></span>

2

<span key="7cb279660892453fb88d60dc9094d126"><span offset-key="7cb279660892453fb88d60dc9094d126:0">#pwd</span></span>

3

<span key="e7cd7ec1513340ddb655bde3d5bdcc7c"><span offset-key="e7cd7ec1513340ddb655bde3d5bdcc7c:0">#hostname</span></span>

4

<span key="bd9f060827434c909681aaef3ee0f1fd"><span offset-key="bd9f060827434c909681aaef3ee0f1fd:0">#uname -a</span></span>

5

<span key="99b264ce5ecd464e956b25d862f08f8d"><span offset-key="99b264ce5ecd464e956b25d862f08f8d:0">who</span></span>

6

<span key="231325ed7f6d474f80ecc55a74ac4d8b"><span offset-key="231325ed7f6d474f80ecc55a74ac4d8b:0">who -r</span></span>

7

<span key="1772889b86bd46ab94eccd02faf4b072"><span offset-key="1772889b86bd46ab94eccd02faf4b072:0">lsb\_release -a</span></span>

<img src="data:image/svg+xml;base64," class="r-h7gdob r-10ptun7 r-1vzi8xi" />

Copied!

## 

<span key="f697bf2de16e496a803cb200ab094eab"><span offset-key="f697bf2de16e496a803cb200ab094eab:0">Wc -l command</span></span>

<span key="5a0d189af1ee49a6b0a5b9ff9ce5fa71"><span offset-key="5a0d189af1ee49a6b0a5b9ff9ce5fa71:0">The "wc -l" command counts the number of lines present in the file. The following SED expression simulates the same.</span></span>

1

<span key="4cc91f9d59924ebe928c9a35b19735bc"><span offset-key="4cc91f9d59924ebe928c9a35b19735bc:0">\[jerry\]$ sed -n '$ =' hello.sh</span></span>

<img src="data:image/svg+xml;base64," class="r-h7gdob r-10ptun7 r-1vzi8xi" />

Copied!

<span key="ce39fecadb084c4a9d3d96edae163d04"><span offset-key="ce39fecadb084c4a9d3d96edae163d04:0">On executing the above code, you get the following result:</span></span>

1

<span key="1704744c51024f2b961c596b3e73f9b3"><span offset-key="1704744c51024f2b961c596b3e73f9b3:0">8</span></span>

<img src="data:image/svg+xml;base64," class="r-h7gdob r-10ptun7 r-1vzi8xi" />

Copied!

## 

<span key="7c7e53ec2bf3412cb8e5e8471db901c7"><span offset-key="7c7e53ec2bf3412cb8e5e8471db901c7:0">Head Command</span></span>

<span key="c0f43844250847828d8daf3d6c28695a"><span offset-key="c0f43844250847828d8daf3d6c28695a:0">By default, the head command prints the first 10 lines of the file. Let us simulate the same behavior with SED.</span></span>

1

<span key="6eb4b51a3a6a4cf38cd8ecb591b5b56c"><span offset-key="6eb4b51a3a6a4cf38cd8ecb591b5b56c:0">\[jerry\]$ sed '10 q' books.txt</span></span>

## 

<span key="e82c73cee66749068e2ab455e7560edc"><span offset-key="e82c73cee66749068e2ab455e7560edc:0">Dos2unix Command</span></span>

<span key="b89d0f66782a43aaa056a122c3f1306c"><span offset-key="b89d0f66782a43aaa056a122c3f1306c:0">In DOS environment, a newline is represented by a combination of CR/LF characters. The following simulation of "dos2unix" command converts a DOS newline character to UNIX newline character. In GNU/Linux, this character is often treated as "^M" (Control M) character.</span></span>

1

<span key="cd9de0d3370e4558bd3b7f33ab3834ba"><span offset-key="cd9de0d3370e4558bd3b7f33ab3834ba:0">\[jerry\]$ echo -e "Line #1\\r\\nLine #2\\r" &gt; test.txt</span></span>

2

<span key="ef8f6f5a19dc42eda1db3cf94728ec35"><span offset-key="ef8f6f5a19dc42eda1db3cf94728ec35:0">\[jerry\]$ file test.txt</span></span>

<img src="data:image/svg+xml;base64," class="r-h7gdob r-10ptun7 r-1vzi8xi" />

Copied!

<span key="0ec9e2d3bea146179a26333034d428e0"><span offset-key="0ec9e2d3bea146179a26333034d428e0:0">On executing the above code, you get the following result:</span></span>

1

<span key="b2280368f1b044479cfcbedf18387a8f"><span offset-key="b2280368f1b044479cfcbedf18387a8f:0">test.txt: ASCII text, with CRLF line terminators</span></span>

<img src="data:image/svg+xml;base64," class="r-h7gdob r-10ptun7 r-1vzi8xi" />

Copied!

1

## 

<span key="d9d05f2001184e6db793acadcbe50f55"><span offset-key="d9d05f2001184e6db793acadcbe50f55:0">Unix2dos command</span></span>

<span key="fe4fe71b2d144eaebf92b358ca6d22f7"><span offset-key="fe4fe71b2d144eaebf92b358ca6d22f7:0">Similar to "dos2unix", there is "unix2dos" command which converts UNIX newline character to DOS newline character. The following example shows simulation of the same.</span></span>

## 

<span key="5560c0ab688f4bfe9fcae3e019bb3efe"><span offset-key="5560c0ab688f4bfe9fcae3e019bb3efe:0">Cat -E command</span></span>

<span key="340fbb4e4c9e496f90191758d0f37f3d"><span offset-key="340fbb4e4c9e496f90191758d0f37f3d:0">The "cat -E" command shows the end of line by Dollar($) character. The following SED example is simulation of the same.</span></span>

1

<span key="dc4168aa59b644eba385f2d984ac3b43"><span offset-key="dc4168aa59b644eba385f2d984ac3b43:0">\[jerry\]$ echo -e "Line #1\\nLine #2" &gt; test.txt</span></span>

2

<span key="8f5268ee5f4b4521bd6b09e17a0d529b"><span offset-key="8f5268ee5f4b4521bd6b09e17a0d529b:0">\[jerry\]$ cat -E test.txt</span></span>

<img src="data:image/svg+xml;base64," class="r-h7gdob r-10ptun7 r-1vzi8xi" />

Copied!

<span key="0d5c90999c0d4f71a412f7ce44f1b363"><span offset-key="0d5c90999c0d4f71a412f7ce44f1b363:0">On executing the above code, you get the following result:</span></span>

<span key="97c4141413ff4486931fa5b1696f188a"><span offset-key="97c4141413ff4486931fa5b1696f188a:0">Line #2$</span></span>

Copied!

<span key="c7fdfef6b6854805b7c1a25481a46443"><span offset-key="c7fdfef6b6854805b7c1a25481a46443:0">Let us simulate the command using SED.</span></span>

1

<span key="d2ece50a65f94402abb2fdb4a5165696"><span offset-key="d2ece50a65f94402abb2fdb4a5165696:0">\[jerry\]$ sed 's|$|&$|' test.txt</span></span>

## 

<span key="1a648595a68d498c8d7d0a137d148f1a"><span offset-key="1a648595a68d498c8d7d0a137d148f1a:0">Cat -ET Command</span></span>

<span key="56159ac8cc1a46be8caf2d669a7c373f"><span offset-key="56159ac8cc1a46be8caf2d669a7c373f:0">The "cat -ET" command shows the Dollar($) symbol at the end of each line and displays the TAB characters as "^I". The following example shows the simulation of "cat -ET" command using SED.</span></span>

1

<span key="e23c014de9c640b4b56b3a19123d74e3"><span offset-key="e23c014de9c640b4b56b3a19123d74e3:0">\[jerry\]$ echo -e "Line #1\\tLine #2" &gt; test.txt</span></span>

2

<span key="fefd2db2d621477ba156086ee3d9138c"><span offset-key="fefd2db2d621477ba156086ee3d9138c:0">\[jerry\]$ cat -ET test.txt</span></span>

<img src="data:image/svg+xml;base64," class="r-h7gdob r-10ptun7 r-1vzi8xi" />

Copied!

<span key="8da0defb72554be6b59363892d9d494d"><span offset-key="8da0defb72554be6b59363892d9d494d:0">On executing the above code, you get the following result:</span></span>

1

<span key="a014c1799ae74615836202d89be032da"><span offset-key="a014c1799ae74615836202d89be032da:0">Line #1^ILine #2$</span></span>

<img src="data:image/svg+xml;base64," class="r-h7gdob r-10ptun7 r-1vzi8xi" />

Copied!

<span key="80c7acde317949dbba557538333df9fd"><span offset-key="80c7acde317949dbba557538333df9fd:0">Let us simulate the command using SED.</span></span>

1

<span key="6b39a26efd42419cbf42e855d7eb4e4c"><span offset-key="6b39a26efd42419cbf42e855d7eb4e4c:0">\[jerry\]$ sed -n 'l' test.txt | sed 'y/\\\\t/^I/'</span></span>

<img src="data:image/svg+xml;base64," class="r-h7gdob r-10ptun7 r-1vzi8xi" />

Copied!

<span key="3798bbc697ac461ea6c28fc4d207215b"><span offset-key="3798bbc697ac461ea6c28fc4d207215b:0">On executing the above code, you get the following result:</span></span>

1

<span key="c9c11cdb4d634b8eb0f0592201f7c123"><span offset-key="c9c11cdb4d634b8eb0f0592201f7c123:0">Line #1^ILine #2$</span></span>

<img src="data:image/svg+xml;base64," class="r-h7gdob r-10ptun7 r-1vzi8xi" />

Copied!

## 

<span key="2e26f61a582745da9fd4fcddeefb5194"><span offset-key="2e26f61a582745da9fd4fcddeefb5194:0">nl Command</span></span>

<span key="7353d949870a4045a3e95fc2bd1d3795"><span offset-key="7353d949870a4045a3e95fc2bd1d3795:0">The "nl" command simply numbers the lines of files. The following SED script simulates this behavior.</span></span>

1

<span key="70643a8183f24a80bb730e44c7aefeca"><span offset-key="70643a8183f24a80bb730e44c7aefeca:0">\[jerry\]$ echo -e "Line #1\\nLine #2" &gt; test.txt</span></span>

2

<span key="dba14ac1fbe547a1bde27dba5d4a0272"><span offset-key="dba14ac1fbe547a1bde27dba5d4a0272:0">\[jerry\]$ sed = test.txt | sed 'N;s/\\n/\\t/'</span></span>

<img src="data:image/svg+xml;base64," class="r-h7gdob r-10ptun7 r-1vzi8xi" />

Copied!

<span key="32d7c6862a2d42c5ad45026b5950950f"><span offset-key="32d7c6862a2d42c5ad45026b5950950f:0">On executing the above code, you get the following result:</span></span>

1

<span key="b519bcf8c7674ee99c19e9ab3af922b1"><span offset-key="b519bcf8c7674ee99c19e9ab3af922b1:0">1 Line #1</span></span>

2

<span key="07f9a4dca3e6462ca778a77ee6edffd5"><span offset-key="07f9a4dca3e6462ca778a77ee6edffd5:0">2 Line #2</span></span>

<img src="data:image/svg+xml;base64," class="r-h7gdob r-10ptun7 r-1vzi8xi" />

Copied!

<span key="b6942b7b765b4a33ba5b81916d503d13"><span offset-key="b6942b7b765b4a33ba5b81916d503d13:0">The first SED expression prints line numbers followed by their contents, and the second SED expression merges these two lines and converts newline characters to TAB characters.</span></span>

## 

<span key="4cc2abfd276e402c92c7181dd287617f"><span offset-key="4cc2abfd276e402c92c7181dd287617f:0">cp Command</span></span>

<span key="2caa0bd432d8423cbc136f3dcb861509"><span offset-key="2caa0bd432d8423cbc136f3dcb861509:0">The "cp" command crates another copy of the file. The following SED script simulates this behavior.</span></span>

1

<span key="6a9ce4fb988c4244826773f518a72ec2"><span offset-key="6a9ce4fb988c4244826773f518a72ec2:0">\[jerry\]$ sed -n 'w dup.txt' data.txt</span></span>

2

<span key="059b859d2c8c433297c148e8f5fdad9b"><span offset-key="059b859d2c8c433297c148e8f5fdad9b:0">\[jerry\]$ diff data.txt dup.txt</span></span>

3

<span key="3199fbe017e940338d1f3be495e168c9"><span offset-key="3199fbe017e940338d1f3be495e168c9:0">\[jerry\]$ echo $?</span></span>

<img src="data:image/svg+xml;base64," class="r-h7gdob r-10ptun7 r-1vzi8xi" />

Copied!

<span key="96c5e8e218a84e4f9ab421426fbe4c5f"><span offset-key="96c5e8e218a84e4f9ab421426fbe4c5f:0">On executing the above code, you get the following result:</span></span>

1

<span key="6507e5241bd544fd9ca0ef9703e2397c"><span offset-key="6507e5241bd544fd9ca0ef9703e2397c:0">0</span></span>

<img src="data:image/svg+xml;base64," class="r-h7gdob r-10ptun7 r-1vzi8xi" />

Copied!

## 

<span key="1387ab3989eb41e39a3836983e16e52c"><span offset-key="1387ab3989eb41e39a3836983e16e52c:0">Expand Command</span></span>

<span key="f2710f92fe4c490489dc200f2501ee67"><span offset-key="f2710f92fe4c490489dc200f2501ee67:0">The "expand" command converts TAB characters to whitespaces. The following code shows its simulation.</span></span>

1

<span key="54b076b0c301421a969c899ff2b1588c"><span offset-key="54b076b0c301421a969c899ff2b1588c:0">\[jerry\]$ echo -e "One\\tTwo\\tThree" &gt; test.txt</span></span>

2

<span key="65738d9bc2764fbd86a42139103bdeb9"><span offset-key="65738d9bc2764fbd86a42139103bdeb9:0">\[jerry\]$ expand test.txt &gt; expand.txt</span></span>

3

<span key="99f79845f58b4ab1ae594c98588a5c07"><span offset-key="99f79845f58b4ab1ae594c98588a5c07:0">\[jerry\]$ sed 's/\\t/ /g' test.txt &gt; new.txt</span></span>

4

<span key="b98945fd1de842bb874915efdb8e4df1"><span offset-key="b98945fd1de842bb874915efdb8e4df1:0">\[jerry\]$ diff new.txt expand.txt</span></span>

5

<span key="82a1a97af38641efbee01404fc0474bd"><span offset-key="82a1a97af38641efbee01404fc0474bd:0">\[jerry\]$ echo $?</span></span>

<img src="data:image/svg+xml;base64," class="r-h7gdob r-10ptun7 r-1vzi8xi" />

Copied!

<span key="695487dcd9b649d38ff8920bb57eedc2"><span offset-key="695487dcd9b649d38ff8920bb57eedc2:0">On executing the above code, you get the following result:</span></span>

1

<span key="fd6f7ed896dc46c08e491b3ea945d82d"><span offset-key="fd6f7ed896dc46c08e491b3ea945d82d:0">0</span></span>

<img src="data:image/svg+xml;base64," class="r-h7gdob r-10ptun7 r-1vzi8xi" />

Copied!

## 

<span key="de3a09e6663a4a0093de5a33568fdfd7"><span offset-key="de3a09e6663a4a0093de5a33568fdfd7:0">Tee Command</span></span>

<span key="b4ee992a8fb74f94b205167ed806ea15"><span offset-key="b4ee992a8fb74f94b205167ed806ea15:0">The "tee" command dumps the data to the standard output stream as well as file. Given below is the simulation of the "tee" command.</span></span>

1

<span key="f6a8f2fa9754463081b01d6a9e92cf21"><span offset-key="f6a8f2fa9754463081b01d6a9e92cf21:0">\[jerry\]$ echo -e "Line #1\\nLine #2" | tee test.txt</span></span>

2

<span key="b3a6dd94358441f59562c89ea369eeb6"><span offset-key="b3a6dd94358441f59562c89ea369eeb6:0">Line #1</span></span>

3

<span key="ccb3d3bb7bfa44a1851253b24ed28664"><span offset-key="ccb3d3bb7bfa44a1851253b24ed28664:0">Line #2</span></span>

<img src="data:image/svg+xml;base64," class="r-h7gdob r-10ptun7 r-1vzi8xi" />

Copied!

<span key="e701cc0b007b4d8d88820d4a1832a1b3"><span offset-key="e701cc0b007b4d8d88820d4a1832a1b3:0">Let us simulate the command using SED.</span></span>

1

<span key="24c39c9245a54af1bb3d0d12b9ad777f"><span offset-key="24c39c9245a54af1bb3d0d12b9ad777f:0">\[jerry\]$ sed -n 'p; w new.txt' test.txt</span></span>

<img src="data:image/svg+xml;base64," class="r-h7gdob r-10ptun7 r-1vzi8xi" />

Copied!

<span key="5abddb1fccb147b8859219de31078bd2"><span offset-key="5abddb1fccb147b8859219de31078bd2:0">On executing the above code, you get the following result:</span></span>

1

<span key="c62a7be60b794daf8b7c38a2e623ac39"><span offset-key="c62a7be60b794daf8b7c38a2e623ac39:0">Line #1</span></span>

2

<span key="92dbe1056b23442face61f7217d1dda3"><span offset-key="92dbe1056b23442face61f7217d1dda3:0">Line #2</span></span>

<img src="data:image/svg+xml;base64," class="r-h7gdob r-10ptun7 r-1vzi8xi" />

Copied!

## 

<span key="edbc657e456f413281309a0309ceca4b"><span offset-key="edbc657e456f413281309a0309ceca4b:0">cat -s Command</span></span>

<span key="8b4dea267cf0465393a59e05bad65401"><span offset-key="8b4dea267cf0465393a59e05bad65401:0">UNIX "cat -s" command suppresses repeated empty output lines. The following code shows the simulation of "cat -s" command.</span></span>

1

<span key="b140dc4d4a634757820d6f5f7c75859b"><span offset-key="b140dc4d4a634757820d6f5f7c75859b:0">\[jerry\]$ echo -e "Line #1\\n\\n\\n\\nLine #2\\n\\n\\nLine #3" &gt; test.txt</span></span>

2

<span key="7017d94d4d004d7099160c0e38c3755a"><span offset-key="7017d94d4d004d7099160c0e38c3755a:0">\[jerry\]$ cat -s test.txt</span></span>

<img src="data:image/svg+xml;base64," class="r-h7gdob r-10ptun7 r-1vzi8xi" />

Copied!

<span key="9410452be63743029b80d00a8188cca0"><span offset-key="9410452be63743029b80d00a8188cca0:0">On executing the above code, you get the following result:</span></span>

1

<span key="538c03f0593c42f8a79e5385344a2545"><span offset-key="538c03f0593c42f8a79e5385344a2545:0">Line #1</span></span>

2

<span key="4afab63a690a49abb240004bf091f96e"><span offset-key="4afab63a690a49abb240004bf091f96e:0">Line #2</span></span>

3

<span key="af6b8fe4bb574afebc3e52f97563c6cb"><span offset-key="af6b8fe4bb574afebc3e52f97563c6cb:0">Line #3</span></span>

<img src="data:image/svg+xml;base64," class="r-h7gdob r-10ptun7 r-1vzi8xi" />

Copied!

<span key="d63263d5c824455fade4a922ec7e06bf"><span offset-key="d63263d5c824455fade4a922ec7e06bf:0">Let us simulate the command using SED.</span></span>

1

<span key="13d522ace54e41979c0063aa410aba81"><span offset-key="13d522ace54e41979c0063aa410aba81:0">\[jerry\]$ sed '1s/^$//p;/./,/^$/!d' test.txt</span></span>

<img src="data:image/svg+xml;base64," class="r-h7gdob r-10ptun7 r-1vzi8xi" />

Copied!

<span key="7817886afb744b9eb84eda62cfecc684"><span offset-key="7817886afb744b9eb84eda62cfecc684:0">On executing the above code, you get the following result:</span></span>

1

<span key="20a9b65ceec942e79e11a31535848991"><span offset-key="20a9b65ceec942e79e11a31535848991:0">Line #1</span></span>

2

<span key="6baffd8891364f2ebf172adcb78740c4"><span offset-key="6baffd8891364f2ebf172adcb78740c4:0">Line #2</span></span>

3

<span key="5017c5c144354b1c908fdbd371d9aa57"><span offset-key="5017c5c144354b1c908fdbd371d9aa57:0">Line #3</span></span>

<img src="data:image/svg+xml;base64," class="r-h7gdob r-10ptun7 r-1vzi8xi" />

Copied!

## 

<span key="f810f3995d3940f1bbfeff4c0199fe2a"><span offset-key="f810f3995d3940f1bbfeff4c0199fe2a:0">grep Command</span></span>

<span key="158e5995ac4f4615ab98be2e93fac427"><span offset-key="158e5995ac4f4615ab98be2e93fac427:0">By default, the "grep" command prints a line when a pattern match succeeds. The following code shows its simulation.</span></span>

1

<span key="2ac9ea5d22d940758c273f07a790fdb2"><span offset-key="2ac9ea5d22d940758c273f07a790fdb2:0">\[jerry\]$ echo -e "Line #1\\nLine #2\\nLine #3" &gt; test.txt</span></span>

2

<span key="f643e271b7ad4611b303c78a222403fc"><span offset-key="f643e271b7ad4611b303c78a222403fc:0">\[jerry\]$ grep "Line #1" test.txt</span></span>

<img src="data:image/svg+xml;base64," class="r-h7gdob r-10ptun7 r-1vzi8xi" />

Copied!

<span key="47702bfb66374f6c9fe3117737d1db17"><span offset-key="47702bfb66374f6c9fe3117737d1db17:0">On executing the above code, you get the following result:</span></span>

1

<span key="8a25d26b95a14694b521c5b2b7324c6e"><span offset-key="8a25d26b95a14694b521c5b2b7324c6e:0">Line #1</span></span>

<img src="data:image/svg+xml;base64," class="r-h7gdob r-10ptun7 r-1vzi8xi" />

Copied!

<span key="c9d3ed5b24a1460c992e0af4f96c5fc6"><span offset-key="c9d3ed5b24a1460c992e0af4f96c5fc6:0">Let us simulate the command using SED.</span></span>

1

<span key="74cd7a83c2e04c02a2d475ef02874139"><span offset-key="74cd7a83c2e04c02a2d475ef02874139:0">\[jerry\]$ sed -n '/Line #1/p' test.txt</span></span>

<img src="data:image/svg+xml;base64," class="r-h7gdob r-10ptun7 r-1vzi8xi" />

Copied!

<span key="4acdb56d50c74a54b5d5629e39214f37"><span offset-key="4acdb56d50c74a54b5d5629e39214f37:0">On executing the above code, you get the following result:</span></span>

1

<span key="b52e44ca9b22425b95aa5d79a0edd65d"><span offset-key="b52e44ca9b22425b95aa5d79a0edd65d:0">Line #1</span></span>

<img src="data:image/svg+xml;base64," class="r-h7gdob r-10ptun7 r-1vzi8xi" />

Copied!

## 

<span key="f69fbf7eeb8747d7ac685ee2717ffa15"><span offset-key="f69fbf7eeb8747d7ac685ee2717ffa15:0">grep -v Command</span></span>

<span key="f107d86ad6804888a9ba6ffd38cd3b1a"><span offset-key="f107d86ad6804888a9ba6ffd38cd3b1a:0">By default, the "grep -v" command prints a line when a pattern match fails. The following code shows its simulation.</span></span>

1

<span key="d35332b430ff46cd9d44cc401cf61638"><span offset-key="d35332b430ff46cd9d44cc401cf61638:0">\[jerry\]$ echo -e "Line #1\\nLine #2\\nLine #3" &gt; test.txt</span></span>

2

<span key="d64314c2646b4ecb92bb0d63ecdf6f98"><span offset-key="d64314c2646b4ecb92bb0d63ecdf6f98:0">\[jerry\]$ grep -v "Line #1" test.txt</span></span>

<img src="data:image/svg+xml;base64," class="r-h7gdob r-10ptun7 r-1vzi8xi" />

Copied!

<span key="d5b0da2cee554146b0890bd57f2529f7"><span offset-key="d5b0da2cee554146b0890bd57f2529f7:0">On executing the above code, you get the following result:</span></span>

1

<span key="5cc993cb1ef24b09a05b8fbdbb5bb169"><span offset-key="5cc993cb1ef24b09a05b8fbdbb5bb169:0">Line #2</span></span>

2

<span key="57a64f2fbaf942c28391a3e40da1ba71"><span offset-key="57a64f2fbaf942c28391a3e40da1ba71:0">Line #3</span></span>

<img src="data:image/svg+xml;base64," class="r-h7gdob r-10ptun7 r-1vzi8xi" />

Copied!

<span key="b7c16486749b461888e03475240ce27e"><span offset-key="b7c16486749b461888e03475240ce27e:0">Let us simulate the command using SED.</span></span>

1

<span key="f54b9b0232e3498d89effd93ff9e9e10"><span offset-key="f54b9b0232e3498d89effd93ff9e9e10:0">\[jerry\]$ sed -n '/Line #1/!p' test.txt</span></span>

<img src="data:image/svg+xml;base64," class="r-h7gdob r-10ptun7 r-1vzi8xi" />

Copied!

<span key="53b830bea9b44b4684d88fb7fcb007ce"><span offset-key="53b830bea9b44b4684d88fb7fcb007ce:0">On executing the above code, you get the following result:</span></span>

1

<span key="9c165eb43c754a3d8c91cd739b0b8f02"><span offset-key="9c165eb43c754a3d8c91cd739b0b8f02:0">Line #2</span></span>

2

<span key="867fac76cc5f407495d1f4d21775e428"><span offset-key="867fac76cc5f407495d1f4d21775e428:0">Line #3</span></span>

## 

<span key="f1182ad661fe4bde9b528319a1670d74"><span offset-key="f1182ad661fe4bde9b528319a1670d74:0">tr Command</span></span>

<span key="9874f7ec86d2400aa5b8f51d46f8a5f4"><span offset-key="9874f7ec86d2400aa5b8f51d46f8a5f4:0">The "tr" command translates characters. Given below is its simulation.</span></span>

1

<span key="4aafccdc2afc4989a12b77a176c674a4"><span offset-key="4aafccdc2afc4989a12b77a176c674a4:0">\[jerry\]$ echo "ABC" | tr "ABC" "abc"</span></span>

<img src="data:image/svg+xml;base64," class="r-h7gdob r-10ptun7 r-1vzi8xi" />

Copied!

<span key="67fda8078dd148e4a0f260c35951a5d3"><span offset-key="67fda8078dd148e4a0f260c35951a5d3:0">On executing the above code, you get the following result:</span></span>

1

<span key="38dee56870bb42028ad56103b2496ee5"><span offset-key="38dee56870bb42028ad56103b2496ee5:0">abc</span></span>

<img src="data:image/svg+xml;base64," class="r-h7gdob r-10ptun7 r-1vzi8xi" />

Copied!

<span key="b4113ef055ba4612b0bb6ef0d4eb710e"><span offset-key="b4113ef055ba4612b0bb6ef0d4eb710e:0">Let us simulate the command using SED.</span></span>

1

<span key="41feed10eed547c4b867c2e98b7c730e"><span offset-key="41feed10eed547c4b867c2e98b7c730e:0">\[jerry\]$ echo "ABC" | sed 'y/ABC/abc/'</span></span>

<img src="data:image/svg+xml;base64," class="r-h7gdob r-10ptun7 r-1vzi8xi" />

Copied!

<span key="eceb0e9a5d8d456dbba1a8834f1ab87b"><span offset-key="eceb0e9a5d8d456dbba1a8834f1ab87b:0">On executing the above code, you get the following result:</span></span>

1

<span key="a9deda70c7f743ed978413d0cb1c4f0b"><span offset-key="a9deda70c7f743ed978413d0cb1c4f0b:0">abc</span></span>

<img src="data:image/svg+xml;base64," class="r-h7gdob r-10ptun7 r-1vzi8xi" />
